headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2009 Apartment Investment & Management Company Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and Gener
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2009 Apartment Investment & Management Company Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and General Counsel. Please proceed.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainti
componenttext: Thank you. Good morning and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today.  Also, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures such as funds from operations either defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on Aimco's website.Participants on today's call will be Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO, who will provide opening remarks; Tim Beaudin, Aimco's President and COO, who will speak to property operations, redevelopment activities and asset sale; and Ernie Freedman, our CFO, who will review fourth quarter financial results, debt to capital markets activity and guidance for the first quarter and full year 2010. I will now turn the call to Terry Considine, our CEO. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa. And thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in Aimco. Page 2 of the earnings release provides a summary of accomplishments during the fourth quarter and during 2009. But I'd like to start to emphasize six items only.  First, n
componenttext: Thank you, Lisa. And thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in Aimco. Page 2 of the earnings release provides a summary of accomplishments during the fourth quarter and during 2009. But I'd like to start to emphasize six items only.  First, notwithstanding the great recession, net operating income for property operations has been generally stable and flat sequentially from the third quarter and only slightly down for the full year. In part, this is due to the asset class, in part to the good work of Tony D'Alto, Rob Walker, Eric Resker and their teams. Second, notwithstanding turbulent capital markets, we sold $1.3 billion of properties last year. The market for multi-family property is liquid, and pricing has improved over the past three quarters or so.Third, because we sold off the bottom of our portfolio, the quality in average rents of our retained portfolio have continued to improve. In our conventional portfolio, our average rents are 105% of the local market averages. Fourth, reduced property sales proceeds to reduce recourse debt by 85%. And project building has worked to reduce near-term property debt maturities and to maintain the weighted average maturity of our property debt at 8.6 years.  Fifth, we've reduced off-site costs including G&A by $86 million. Our run rate starting this year is down 45% from 2008. Six, notwithstanding the volatile economy, FFO and other items were within the guidance given at the start of 2009 and make the fourth quarter the 16th quarter in a row for results within guidance.  Looking forward, as we make our plans for 2010, we expect business conditions to remain difficult as the economy adjust to reduce stimulus spending, increase regulation, higher taxes and eventually, higher interest rates. Notwithstanding these concerns, here are five reasons for optimism. First, we like our simplified business model, focused on operations and an opportunistic amount of redevelopment. Second, we like our allocation to the top 20 markets. Our expected growth is about average for the nation but it is less volatile because of the diversification across 20 markets. Third, we expect property valuations to increase somewhat. And any increase in GAV or gross asset value will be magnified by Aimco's property debt and preferred stock leverage to produce a still greater increase in net asset value.Fourth, we expect to continue to upgrade our B/B+ portfolio by capital recycling. That is, selling lower rated properties and investing the proceeds to redevelop or purchase properties with rents between 100% and 125% of local market averages. Given the current market pricing for acquisitions, we expect redevelopment may prove the more attractive way to invest in the top 20 markets. And we have a deep pipeline of redevelopment opportunities that we will access as the local markets recover.Fifth, we expect to repay all recourse debt in the next few months. As a result, we have limited entity risk. We also have quite limited responding risk and repricing risk. Even so we are working to extend property debt maturities in 2011 to '14 and to lock in current interest rates. We prefer somewhat lower leverage and expect coverage ratios will improve as property incomes recover from cyclical lows and by the scheduled amortization of our property debt. And we'd like our long dated a fixed rate leverage as a hedge against higher inflation and increased interest rates.Finally and on a different matter, it was one year ago that we reduced our dividend in order to retain cash to repay term debt. It is the board's view that once the term that is fully paid and the economy's clearly recovered, it is time to consider increasing the dividend as a percent of AFFO. For a review of operations, I'd like to turn the call to Tim Beaudin, our President and Chief Operating Officer. Tim?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss our fourth quarter and full year 2009 operating results, redevelopment activities and asset sales. Second, I will provide some color around what we are seeing operationally so far this year. And finally, I wi
componenttext: Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss our fourth quarter and full year 2009 operating results, redevelopment activities and asset sales. Second, I will provide some color around what we are seeing operationally so far this year. And finally, I will wrap up with how we are looking at recycling capital in 2010.First, operating results. Total portfolio NOI, which includes same-store conventional properties, conventional redevelopment properties and affordable properties, was down 3.2% for the fourth quarter and down just 50 basis points for the year. Conventional redevelopment NOI was up 12.2% for the quarter and up 11.9% for the year. As we pulled back our redevelopment activities during 2009, we completed virtually all of our open projects and brought 681 units online, increasing average daily occupancy in our redevelopment portfolio from 87.7% in December of 2008 to 95.5% for the month of December 2009.Affordable property NOI was 6.9% higher during the fourth quarter and up 9.9% for the year. Our allocation to this affordable portfolio provide for reduced revenue volatility as a result of predictable rent increases available to providers of affordable housing, such as Aimco. While the conventional redev and affordable property portfolios are substantially smaller than the same store conventional portfolio, we are very pleased that the positive operating results produced by these other portfolios almost entirely offset a 4.2% decline in same store conventional NOI during the year.As to same store conventional results, NOI was down 6.3% for the quarter with a revenue decline of 3.2% and expense growth of 2.2%. Revenue declines were driven by a 4.8 decline in average rents, which was only partially offset by a 70-basis-point increase in occupancy to 95.4% and a 90-basis-point increase in utility reimbursements and other income. During the quarter, same store conventional new lease rates were down 10.7%, while rental rates for renewing residents were down about 1% when compared to the expiring leases. The gap between new leases and renewal rents tightened about 200 basis points from third quarter level.In an environment where new lease rates have been challenging, we are very focused on resident retention. During the fourth quarter of 2009, we were able to retain approximately 67% of our customers, which was an increase of 50 basis points compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. We saw a sequential improvement from residential retention throughout the fourth quarter with December finishing at 68% or 250 basis points over December of 2008.For the full year 2009, same store conventional NOI was down 4.2% with revenue down 2.5% as compared to 2008, almost entirely attributable to a 2.5% decline in average rents. For the year, same store conventional expense growth was held in check with only a 30-basis-point increase compared to 2008. We continue to see the benefits of the earning of our contract renegotiated efforts undertaken during 2009 and additional expense reductions were achieved by lowering turn costs, administrative costs, marketing costs and utility expense. These savings were offset by higher insurance expense and by higher repairs and maintenance costs as we focused on product quality. For the full year 2009, our same store conventional property operating margin was 61.1% or just 20 basis points below that of our 2008 same store conventional portfolio despite declining revenues.  From an operating standpoint, 2009 was a challenging year for the apartment industry. However, we are pleased with the results that Aimco's operating team has achieved. As to conventional redevelopment, we invested $56 million during the year and completed 33 of the 37 projects that were active at the beginning of 2009. We took advantage of the short cycle nature of our redevelopment program by reducing the scope of several projects, thereby reducing potential expenditures and $47 million. We begin 2010 with four projects in process which we expect will require $7 million to complete.  Beyond this, we do not expect significant redevelopment activity in 2010. However, we have a pipeline of redevelopment candidates within our portfolio and a platform in place that will allow us to ramp up our investment if we see the opportunity to achieve attractive returns. As to 2009 asset sales, during the fourth quarter, we sold 32 properties for $533 million with net proceeds at Aimco of $154 million. We sold a total of 90 properties during 2009 for $1.3 billion, with net proceeds to Aimco of $407 million. We had aggressive sales targets for 2009 and we feel good about what we accomplished. We saw pricing stabilized in the last half of the year. And it appears that values are continuing to firm.  After being a net seller since 2002, we begin 2010 with a substantially improved portfolio with average rents that are 45% higher than they were seven years ago, 30% higher than those of the assets we sold in 2009, 5% above the average local market rents and average rents in our target markets that are comparable to those of the peer REITs on a market-by-market basis.Now looking ahead, we were just a month or so in 2010 but I would like to give you a bit of color on what we see operationally so far. Since the beginning of January, we have been able to increase new lease rents in a number of our markets, most notably Washington D.C., South Florida, Chicago and Denver. However, we continue to see pressure on rents in our Phoenix, Tampa and Orlando. We have continued to hold occupancy coming into 2010 and ended up January with a monthly same store average daily occupancy above 95.5%. While higher occupancy should continue to provide some pricing power in a number of markets, we remain cautious overall given continued economic uncertainty nationally.In 2010, our focus is to maximize total revenue by balancing rate and occupancy. We have confidence that Tony D'Alto and his team will continue to provide excellent customer service to our residents and maximize the profitability of our operating portfolio over the coming year. By the end of 2010, we expect to substantially all of our conventional redevelopment properties to be stabilized and included in our same store conventional portfolio operating results. In 2010, we are turning our attention recycling capital for proceeds from asset sales generally used to improve portfolio quality. We may sell somewhere between 5% and 10% of the portfolio in 2010, but volumes are dependent upon the availability of attractive opportunities to redeploy that capital and our markets by investing our properties the redevelopment or acquisitions. We do not expect to see a great deal of any seriously distressed asset sales in the multifamily space, but we are keeping our ear to the ground and looking for acquisition opportunities. In summary, we are going to spend 2010 operating our quality portfolio well and continuing to improve portfolio quality and concentrate capital and our target markets. With that, I will turn it over to Ernie.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects. First, our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2009. Second, fourth quarter debt capital market activities. Third, a recent amendment to our credit agreement, which p
componenttext: Thank you, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects. First, our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2009. Second, fourth quarter debt capital market activities. Third, a recent amendment to our credit agreement, which provides for more flexibility relative to our debt covenants. And finally, I will provide first quarter and full year 2010 guidance.  Before I discuss our results, I would like to point out that a change in GAAP occurred during the fourth quarter, the application of which reduced diluted shares outstanding used in Aimco's FFO per share computations for the fourth quarter and full year 2008. This change had no effect on fourth quarter or full year 2009 FFO per share results. Additional details may be found in the earnings release we issued this morning.Now for 2009 financial results. Fourth quarter FFO, before operating real estate impairment charges, was $0.26 per share. Included in the $0.26 per share result was a $0.10 per share non-cash impairment of our interest in Casden Properties LLC. And any organize to buy, re-entitle and develop land parcels in Southern California. Aimco's initial interest in the LLC was $50 million and was written down to $31 million at the end of 2008. An additional impairment of $21 million before tax was required in 2009 due to the continued decline of land values in Southern California, reducing Aimco's interest to $10 million at year end.Excluding this impairment, fourth quarter FFO was $0.36 per share, which was at the mid-point of guidance. Included in our fourth quarter results were restructuring charges at $0.06 net of tax. We had contemplated some but not all of these charges in our fourth quarter guidance. The better-than-anticipated operating results and results through investment management activities helped to offset the additional restructuring costs.Full year 2009 FFO per share before the effect of the Casden impairment was $1.65, which was at the midpoint of guidance provided last quarter and consistent with guidance provided one year ago. Turning to our debt capital market activities since the end of the third quarter, we have repaid $205 million of our term debt, leaving us with the balance today of $55 million. As Tim mentioned, we have seen some improvement in asset values over the last few months. And we are careful to balance the timing of term debt repayment with achieving optimal pricing on asset sales. Based on our current sales pipeline and other sources of cash, we expect to continue to pay down our term debt in the first quarter. We will aim to have it completely paid by the end of the second quarter.We have made similar progress extending our property debt maturities to refinancing, repayment and property sales, Aimco has eliminated all 2010 property debt maturities. We currently have four loans with appropriate collateral, including $100 million that mature in 2011. We plan to refinance these loans at their respective maturity dates, but we will continue to work with our lending partners to seek an earlier refinance, if possible.We are now focused on loan maturities that occur during 2012 through 2014, looking to extend our loans beyond that period to reduce refunding risks and to lock in current interest rates. In connection with our term debt, and our line of credit, we are subject to certain covenants including debt service and fixed charge coverage minimums. Aimco's fourth quarter debt service and fixed charge coverage ratios were 159 and 136, compared to covenants in place during the period of 150 and 130, respectively. Earlier this week, we and our lenders agreed to amend our credit agreement to provide for a reduction in debt service and fixed charge coverage covenants to 140 and 120 respectively, to at least October 1, 2011. Based on our current projections, we expect that we will remain in compliance with these requirements.Looking ahead to 2010, we will continue our efforts to one, maintain property income across our separate portfolios. Two, complete repayment of our term debt. And three, concentrate our investment capital in our target market. After consideration of the funds necessary to repay our term debt, we are largely funded to internal sources. The combination of proceeds from property sales and excess refinance proceeds of approximately $80 million are needed to balance out 2010 cash flows.2010 FFO is projected to range from $1.25 to $1.35 per share. The year-over-year decline from 2009 is primarily due to $0.23 per share dilution from 2009 property sales, $0.09 per share from operations due to earning of lower rents and increased expenses and $0.12 per share due to lower investment management activities. All partially offset by $0.09 per share in lower off-site cost including G&A. Finally, there were several miscellaneous one-time items that net to zero including restructuring charges in 2009.Particular assumptions for 2010 include, first for property operations, we expect total portfolio net operating income, which includes our same store conventional properties, conventional redevelopment properties and our affordable properties to decline year-over-year, 1% to 3%. Regarding same store conventional net operating income, our release this morning contains an inconsistency around our projection for 2010 results. We have provided on our Outlook page within the release, we anticipate a year-over-year same store conventional net operating income decline of 2% to 5%, which includes 0.5% to 2% decline in revenue and 1.5% to 2.5% increase in expenses. Our 2010 guidance also includes property management expense of $45 million.Second, for recurring investment management activities, our guidance assumes $11 million of income after tax, which includes $34 million of revenue, $10 million of expenses and $13 million of taxes. Third, for non-recurring investment management activities, guidance includes $3 million to $6 million of income after tax, which includes $7 million to $10 million of revenue, approximately $2 million of expenses and approximately $2 million of taxes. Non-recurring net income represents approximately 3% of our expected 2010 FFO.  Finally, our guidance includes $53 million of G&A expense. First quarter 2010 FFO is projected to be $0.26 to $0.30 per share for the year-over-year same store conventional net operating income decline of 5.5% to 6.5%.Before we take questions, I would like to remind everyone of our upcoming Investor Day to be held in New York City, February 17. And in Chicago on February 18. The New York event will be webcast and the details of that will be described in a press release sometime next week. If you're interested in attending one of these events and have not already done so, please contact Elizabeth Coalson to sign up. With that, we will now open the call for questions. Please limit your questions to two per time in the queue. Operator, I'll turn it over to you for the first question.

componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Rob. I'll speak to how we look at revenue guidance for 2010. Basically, it's a property by bottoms-up process where we're really focused on the demand drivers in each individual market, leasing velocity that we're seeing, et cetera. What
componenttext: Michael, this is Rob. I'll speak to how we look at revenue guidance for 2010. Basically, it's a property by bottoms-up process where we're really focused on the demand drivers in each individual market, leasing velocity that we're seeing, et cetera. What we do is we roll those numbers up and then utilize third-party information providers typically, REIS, PPR or AxioMetrics as a barometer at a market level and the total roll-off level to compare how we're seeing it versus the market comparisons overall from third-party sources. So it's implicit in that is employment expectations from a third-party providers but our approach again as a bottoms up based on what we see on the ground on a property-by-property the property basis

componenttext: In terms of -- you talked a little bit more about being more transaction neutral in the current year here. What kind of spread do you expect on investments relative to where you could sell versus where you'll be looking to buy unless you're upgrading the quality of the portfolio?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Terry, Michael. I think right now the spread -- if you're selling at the same quality, it will be neutral. If you're selling and getting a different quality, the spreads could be as wide as 100 to 150 basis points. So it sells from the bottom of o
componenttext: This is Terry, Michael. I think right now the spread -- if you're selling at the same quality, it will be neutral. If you're selling and getting a different quality, the spreads could be as wide as 100 to 150 basis points. So it sells from the bottom of our portfolio, you may buy at the top of other portfolio. Looking at that, one of the questions I mentioned is, because I'm not sure that's going to be an attractive rate at which we would want to invest, and I think it may well be that we'll end up investing more in redevelopment where we would look to have premiums of say, 20% to the acquisition rate. So this acquisition rate where 6% we'd be wanting to the redevelopment at 7.2%.

componenttext: This is Ernie. Specific with equity, any equity issuance would have to be dependent on a share price consistent with what we think NAV is. And more importantly, a compelling use for those proceeds. And today, we still feel that we're still trading at a discount NAVs. So today, as we stand and we're not looking at equity issuance. But of course, if things were to change with our share prices, some what we can consider.

componenttextpreview: We did seek it. And as we look at the environment out there and third-party and experts are projecting a very wide range of possibilities for revenue growth in 2010 as I'm sure many of you have seen. For the entire U.S., PPR and REITs are currently almost
componenttext: We did seek it. And as we look at the environment out there and third-party and experts are projecting a very wide range of possibilities for revenue growth in 2010 as I'm sure many of you have seen. For the entire U.S., PPR and REITs are currently almost 400 basis points apart with their projecting. And in some markets, as many as 1,000 basis points apart as to what their expectations are around revenue growth. Our view fall similar between the two of those. And given the possibility, the worse than expected condition, we thought it was prudent in the right time to seek an amendment. And along those lines, I would like to take a moment and thanks our bank group for their continued support. Bank of America, KeyBanc, and Wells Fargo, were there for us when we renewed our line of credit in a very difficult capital markets last April. And we greatly appreciate their confidence in us and improving our amendments today. So in regards to bumping up to our new levels, at our low point in the guidance range that I gave you it today, we would still have some room, not before bumping up against.

componenttext: Michael, it's Terry again. We would like to increase our investment in Washington and in New York and to reallocate our investment in suburban Boston into urban Boston. We'd like to buy in Seattle. We'd like to buy in the Bay area. And we'd like to buy in San Diego. Now those are not unique goals for real estate investors. Those are all regarded as very good market. And so, I think that our investment activity will be focused on ones that have some opportunity for value add, whether it's redevelopment or completion perhaps of a installed project, but the current pricing that I see is not compelling.

componenttextpreview: That's correct, Michael. Tim mentioned it and now our redevelopment portfolio specifically at the end of 2008 and the occupancy in the high 80s, around 88%, and we were able to get that up to 95% as we slowdown that work and have less units that were not
componenttext: That's correct, Michael. Tim mentioned it and now our redevelopment portfolio specifically at the end of 2008 and the occupancy in the high 80s, around 88%, and we were able to get that up to 95% as we slowdown that work and have less units that were not filled up. So there's nothing we need to take as big a pot this year from redevelopment as there was in the year 2009.

componenttext: Our next question is from Andrew McCulloch of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kind of a follow up on that question, on the 2% to 5% decline in NOI guidance, the wording in your press release implies that, that incorporates redevelopment properties as they stabilized. Am I reading that right?
componenttext: Kind of a follow up on that question, on the 2% to 5% decline in NOI guidance, the wording in your press release implies that, that incorporates redevelopment properties as they stabilized. Am I reading that right?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we'll do, Andy, with any properties in the first quarter that stabilize, we will move those into the same-store population and we keep that population that's set for the rest of the year. There will be additional property that will move into the
componenttext: Yes, what we'll do, Andy, with any properties in the first quarter that stabilize, we will move those into the same-store population and we keep that population that's set for the rest of the year. There will be additional property that will move into the same-store population in quarters two, three and four. Those aren't contemplated in our guidance because we want to have one set of number for the year look. But as we do quarter-to-quarter looks, you'll see the population will change a bit around within Haynesville.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: If property is ruined as they stabilize, won't that inflate your projected growth? Because the redevelopment property stabilizes in the quarter, it won't be stabilized in the prior year period?
componenttext: If property is ruined as they stabilize, won't that inflate your projected growth? Because the redevelopment property stabilizes in the quarter, it won't be stabilized in the prior year period?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me clarify that, Andy, when we say as they stabilize, that actually been stabilized for a 12-month period, that's when they move in.
componenttext: Let me clarify that, Andy, when we say as they stabilize, that actually been stabilized for a 12-month period, that's when they move in.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: So they've been stabilized for a full year before they roll in.
componenttext: So they've been stabilized for a full year before they roll in.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Exactly. They got to be stabilized for 12 months before you consider that. So even though we run down the program significantly in 2009, that's why not many moved in, in 2009 because they have to have 12 months of stable operations.
componenttext: Exactly. They got to be stabilized for 12 months before you consider that. So even though we run down the program significantly in 2009, that's why not many moved in, in 2009 because they have to have 12 months of stable operations.

componenttextpreview: There were two pieces to that. One, we agreed to raise our unused fee, five basis points, from 45 basis points to 50 basis points. That will cost us about $90,000 a year. And then secondly, as the one-time fee for the lead bank putting this together, as w
componenttext: There were two pieces to that. One, we agreed to raise our unused fee, five basis points, from 45 basis points to 50 basis points. That will cost us about $90,000 a year. And then secondly, as the one-time fee for the lead bank putting this together, as well for those who are participating as a one-time charge, that's a bit less than $900,000.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010

componenttext: Given that you expect some improvement in pricing power towards the second half of the year and the rents have fallen as much as they have, in the context of the lower turnover that took place last year, can you give us some thoughts about turnover expectations for 2010?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, turnover expectations for 2010 is a maintenance will continue to be a main focus for us. We will stay very much focused on retaining the current customers and focus on customer service. And we expect to improve somewhat year-over-year in terms of our
componenttext: Yes, turnover expectations for 2010 is a maintenance will continue to be a main focus for us. We will stay very much focused on retaining the current customers and focus on customer service. And we expect to improve somewhat year-over-year in terms of our total retention.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'll check with transcript for what the expectation for -- what 2009 was for total turnover. But just a sort of -- as I think about that in the past, we had talked about how the tenants that get a concession will get the free month and then will e
componenttext: I guess I'll check with transcript for what the expectation for -- what 2009 was for total turnover. But just a sort of -- as I think about that in the past, we had talked about how the tenants that get a concession will get the free month and then will end up paying whatever it is the asking rent is on the apartment. Has that changed at all? Are these tenants used to paying, I guess, a higher ticket check as opposed to a reduced one that incorporates the concession?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to make sure I understand your question because it's market specific, in several markets where we have concessions, it's not an issue in the sense that frankly, they're not significant. Obviously, in markets where there are no concessions, the tenant
componenttext: Just to make sure I understand your question because it's market specific, in several markets where we have concessions, it's not an issue in the sense that frankly, they're not significant. Obviously, in markets where there are no concessions, the tenant would be more sensitive to the increase. I don't know if I'm understanding your question exactly.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I was just asking if you guys are still making tenants pay whatever the asking rent is and not effectively amortizing it on a monthly basis over the course of the lease so they're used to paying that higher rent, but I can go off line.
componenttext: I guess I was just asking if you guys are still making tenants pay whatever the asking rent is and not effectively amortizing it on a monthly basis over the course of the lease so they're used to paying that higher rent, but I can go off line.

componenttext: Yes, we can talk off line but generally speaking, yes, we are.

componenttext: Through the quarter, I think you're probably seeing Houston and Dallas. It's picked up currently as a matter of fact, I think I noted those were a couple of places where we increased rents. To go back specifically at the time, I think we had a little bit higher move out number than expected and adjusted for occupancy. But at the moment, we're very highly occupied in more increasing rents.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is from Rich Anderson of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010

componenttext: I guess I wanted to just go back to this same-store pool question if I may because when I'm looking on Page 2, it says as conventional redevelopment properties are stabilized during 2010, they will be added to the same-store results. And I know you said that, that meant 2009. It just seems such like a blatant, either the world's most blatant typo or there's something more to it. So if I may, can you tell me which redevelopment assets will be added to the same-store pool specifically? Or tell us, or maybe off line or something like that so we can see that they're not in the redevelopment schedule now? I'm not convinced.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, we can. I can see that we've created an ambiguity and concern. And I just want to clarify, we're not doing anything new or different about our same-store portfolio. Before our property moves from redev to the same-store portfolio, it has to have bee
componenttext: Rich, we can. I can see that we've created an ambiguity and concern. And I just want to clarify, we're not doing anything new or different about our same-store portfolio. Before our property moves from redev to the same-store portfolio, it has to have been stabilized for 12 months. We can go back and we can show you the properties that will -- because there has been a certain amount of change and there has been a fair amount of properties moving from redevelopment into same store during 2010, but we could come up with a schedule at the beginning of the year and I don't know that -- I assume we can do that in our projection for the balance of 2010 on what we expected with it.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Ernie. We've actually done that in terms making sure we put our numbers together and we anticipate all but about two or three assets will be moved in during the year but we can definitely walk you through.
componenttext: Rich, this is Ernie. We've actually done that in terms making sure we put our numbers together and we anticipate all but about two or three assets will be moved in during the year but we can definitely walk you through.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: It all comes back to the bottom line anyway, it's just that it's more how the data is presented in terms of the same store. So it's not a big deal, I just want to make sure we understand, it's apples to apples with your peers. The second question is, the
componenttext: It all comes back to the bottom line anyway, it's just that it's more how the data is presented in terms of the same store. So it's not a big deal, I just want to make sure we understand, it's apples to apples with your peers. The second question is, the fixed charge coverage ratio of 1.36x today and the whole deal about resetting your covenants and good news there. But your peers, I don't know if there is anyone in the multi-family space or maybe that's below two times in a fixed charge coverage basis. I know you guys kind of have a different model from a balance sheet perspective and I understand the advantages of secured debt model for you guys, so no question there. But maybe you can explain a little bit further to the audience why it's okay for Aimco to operate at that level of leverage where your peers are to use a phrase in order of magnitude greater than you in some cases? Can you just go through that for me?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Ernie. Let me address one thing specific about the number you're quoting, the 1.36. Our coverage is, by definition, wouldn't be lower than anyone else in the space because of amortization required from our property which build a layer of saf
componenttext: Rich, this is Ernie. Let me address one thing specific about the number you're quoting, the 1.36. Our coverage is, by definition, wouldn't be lower than anyone else in the space because of amortization required from our property which build a layer of safety. If you take out the amortization, that was up our coverages by about 25 to 30 basis points. So yes, still trailing others. If you want to compare apples in apples, it's important to take that into consideration. And we do like the fact that the amortization builds in from discipline and does build into safety with regards to that when it comes to how we view leverage. That said, Terry alluded to in his comments, we would like to improve leverage from the perspective of bringing it down and we hope to do that through NOI growing to the cyclical recovery but in addition, through the forced property debt amortization that's required. And so over time, we would expect that our coverage should improve for both of those things.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Jay Habermann of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Jay Habermann of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just following on Rich's question there, Terry, you mentioned possibly a dividend increase this year. Can you just balance that against obviously, the concerns over leverage or discontinued deleveraging?
componenttext: Just following on Rich's question there, Terry, you mentioned possibly a dividend increase this year. Can you just balance that against obviously, the concerns over leverage or discontinued deleveraging?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jay, in the first half of the year, we'll have continued deleveraging as we pay out the term debt and amortize this property debt. In the second half of the year, we will have scheduled payments of property debt which will provide for amortization and as
componenttext: Jay, in the first half of the year, we'll have continued deleveraging as we pay out the term debt and amortize this property debt. In the second half of the year, we will have scheduled payments of property debt which will provide for amortization and as people can see, expected better year-over-year comparisons. We'll look at our cash flows at that time and see what's the best allocation. The dividend is low as a percent of FFO in over a period of time. We want to increase the cash return to shareholders. We're not attracted to accelerating the amortization of the property debt because it doesn't make a lot of sense to pay off debt that has a weighted average cost of 5 1/2% in a weighted average maturity of nine years. We will just let that happen according to schedule. So I think, I don't know if that's responsive, but the answer is in looking at the dividend, we'll weigh it compared to other uses of corporate funds and try to find the right balance.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And my second question, you talk more about redevelopment obviously in the coming year or so, can you just balance that as well against you're going to see an environment where rents likely begin to increase in the coming 12 to 18 months and how you sort
componenttext: And my second question, you talk more about redevelopment obviously in the coming year or so, can you just balance that as well against you're going to see an environment where rents likely begin to increase in the coming 12 to 18 months and how you sort of manage redevelopment in that potential drag on earnings as you could see an accelerating earnings grow the cycle?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think just to go through the points that you raised. First of all, it would be our expectation that rents will be higher in 2011 and 2012 depending on the local market, local service gains. That strengthening demand will support property upgrades
componenttext: Well, I think just to go through the points that you raised. First of all, it would be our expectation that rents will be higher in 2011 and 2012 depending on the local market, local service gains. That strengthening demand will support property upgrades and particularly, attractive locations. So we'll see the opportunity. One of the things we like about redevelopment is that we can make those decisions and activities in a fairly short cycle way. So as we gear up, we can jump in and see if it's working and if it's not working, we can trouble back. I don't expect that we would see it in the volumes in which we are operating in 2008 because at least for right now, I'm still quite cautious about the economy and concerns about double dip and these other issues.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is from Rich Anderson of BMO Capital markets.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, while you're back though, I wanted to thank you for your question on same-store pool because I think one of the differences that I want you and the Street to see is that in Aimco, our same-store pool this year will change the fair amount from last y
componenttext: Rich, while you're back though, I wanted to thank you for your question on same-store pool because I think one of the differences that I want you and the Street to see is that in Aimco, our same-store pool this year will change the fair amount from last year. First of all, we sold $1.3 billion, that will come out of the same store. And secondly, we have a large redevelopment program in 2006, 2007 and 2008 and so that we're stabilized for 12 months so there's not any change in the rules around same store, they will come in. You have a different population, significantly different population at significantly higher rents, significantly better locations and significantly higher operating margins. And so that's something you can look forward to seeing in 2010.

componenttext: I was wondering on looking what you disposed of or sold in '09 as well as what you are looking and have looked at to acquire. You obviously selling and generally the central broadly defined part of the country and trying to buy in Coast, can you differentiate kind of what cap rates, what yields you've seen on sales, maybe how they're different geographically? And then also, what you're seeing on purchases and maybe even throwing it where it looks most attractive? I know where you want to buy but maybe what's looking most attractive at the moment?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jay, I think the conclusion I have is that for the moment, I don't see extraordinary investment opportunities. We are looking in a number of markets, as we've mentioned earlier, and there's activity going on. But prices are relatively high and so I want t
componenttext: Jay, I think the conclusion I have is that for the moment, I don't see extraordinary investment opportunities. We are looking in a number of markets, as we've mentioned earlier, and there's activity going on. But prices are relatively high and so I want to be selective about where we invest new capital. I think I would like to have a higher return than I see in most of the offerings that are available to us. And so, I'm thinking that over time, we'll end up with more of a value-added component to what we do.

We have many, many opportunities, many unsolicited opportunities to sell our high-quality assets which reflects the invested demand out there. But for us, we're quite focused on just selling off the bottom. Tim, do you want to give the detail?

componenttext: I would also say that majority of the transactions individually have been somewhere in the 7% range and there's not been a lot of outliers to that. I think part of that comes one, as you identify that most of the properties have been sold within defined markets outside of the Coast. And two, that the average rents on these on a dollar range. And so I think, that tends to bring together some consistency as to the type of buyer and type of cap rates that they're trying to acquire it. So there have not been a lot of outliers outside that 7% range.

componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2009 Apartment Investment & Management Company Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and Gener
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2009 Apartment Investment & Management Company Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and General Counsel. Please proceed.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainti
componenttext: Thank you. Good morning and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today.  Also, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures such as funds from operations either defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on Aimco's website.Participants on today's call will be Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO, who will provide opening remarks; Tim Beaudin, Aimco's President and COO, who will speak to property operations, redevelopment activities and asset sale; and Ernie Freedman, our CFO, who will review fourth quarter financial results, debt to capital markets activity and guidance for the first quarter and full year 2010. I will now turn the call to Terry Considine, our CEO. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa. And thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in Aimco. Page 2 of the earnings release provides a summary of accomplishments during the fourth quarter and during 2009. But I'd like to start to emphasize six items only.  First, n
componenttext: Thank you, Lisa. And thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in Aimco. Page 2 of the earnings release provides a summary of accomplishments during the fourth quarter and during 2009. But I'd like to start to emphasize six items only.  First, notwithstanding the great recession, net operating income for property operations has been generally stable and flat sequentially from the third quarter and only slightly down for the full year. In part, this is due to the asset class, in part to the good work of Tony D'Alto, Rob Walker, Eric Resker and their teams. Second, notwithstanding turbulent capital markets, we sold $1.3 billion of properties last year. The market for multi-family property is liquid, and pricing has improved over the past three quarters or so.Third, because we sold off the bottom of our portfolio, the quality in average rents of our retained portfolio have continued to improve. In our conventional portfolio, our average rents are 105% of the local market averages. Fourth, reduced property sales proceeds to reduce recourse debt by 85%. And Patti Fielding has worked to reduce near-term property debt maturities and to maintain the weighted average maturity of our property debt at 8.6 years.  Fifth, we've reduced off-site costs including G&A by $86 million. Our run rate starting this year is down 45% from 2008. Six, notwithstanding the volatile economy, FFO and other items were within the guidance given at the start of 2009 and make the fourth quarter the 16th quarter in a row for results within guidance.  Looking forward, as we make our plans for 2010, we expect business conditions to remain difficult as the economy adjusts to reduced stimulus spending, increased regulation, higher taxes and eventually, higher interest rates. Notwithstanding these concerns, here are five reasons for optimism. First, we like our simplified business model, focused on operations and an opportunistic amount of redevelopment. Second, we like our allocation to the top 20 markets. Our expected growth is about average for the nation but it is less volatile because of the diversification across 20 markets. Third, we expect property valuations to increase somewhat. And any increase in GAV or gross asset value will be magnified by Aimco's property debt and preferred stock leverage to produce a still greater increase in net asset value.Fourth, we expect to continue to upgrade our B/B+ portfolio by capital recycling. That is, selling lower rated properties and investing the proceeds to redevelop or purchase properties with rents between 100% and 125% of local market averages. Given the current market pricing for acquisitions, we expect redevelopment may prove the more attractive way to invest in the top 20 markets. And we have a deep pipeline of redevelopment opportunities that we will access as the local markets recover.Fifth, we expect to have repaid all recourse debt in the next few months. As a result, we have limited entity risk. We also have quite limited refunding risk and re-pricing risk. Even so we are working to extend property debt maturities in 2011 to '14 and to lock in current interest rates. We prefer somewhat lower leverage and expect coverage ratios will improve as property incomes recover from cyclical lows and by the scheduled amortization of our property debt. And we'd like our long dated and fixed rate leverage as a hedge against higher inflation and increased interest rates.Finally and on a different matter, it was one year ago that we reduced our dividend in order to retain cash to repay term debt. It is the board's view that once the term debt is fully paid and the economy's clearly recovering, it will be time to consider increasing the dividend as a percent of AFFO. For a review of operations, I'd like to turn the call to Tim Beaudin, our President and Chief Operating Officer. Tim?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss our fourth quarter and full year 2009 operating results, redevelopment activities and asset sales. Second, I will provide some color around what we are seeing operationally so far this year. And finally, I wi
componenttext: Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss our fourth quarter and full year 2009 operating results, redevelopment activities and asset sales. Second, I will provide some color around what we are seeing operationally so far this year. And finally, I will wrap up with how we are looking at recycling capital in 2010.First, operating results. Total portfolio NOI, which includes same-store conventional properties, conventional redevelopment properties and affordable properties, was down 3.2% for the fourth quarter and down just 50 basis points for the year. Conventional redevelopment NOI was up 12.2% for the quarter and up 11.9% for the year. As we pulled back our redevelopment activities during 2009, we completed virtually all of our open projects and brought 681 units online, increasing average daily occupancy in our redevelopment portfolio from 87.7% in December of 2008 to 95.5% for the month of December 2009.Affordable property NOI was 6.9% higher during the fourth quarter and up 9.9% for the year. Our allocation to this affordable portfolio provide for reduced revenue volatility as a result of predictable rent increases available to providers of affordable housing, such as Aimco. While the conventional redev and affordable property portfolios are substantially smaller than the same-store conventional portfolio, we are very pleased that the positive operating results produced by these other portfolios almost entirely offset a 4.2% decline in same store conventional NOI during the year.As to same store conventional results, NOI was down 6.3% for the quarter with a revenue decline of 3.2% and expense growth of 2.2%. Revenue declines were driven by a 4.8 decline in average rents, which was only partially offset by a 70-basis-point increase in occupancy to 95.4% and a 90-basis-point increase in utility reimbursements and other income. During the quarter, same store conventional new lease rates were down 10.7%, while rental rates for renewing residents were down about 1% when compared to the expiring leases. The gap between new leases and renewal rents tightened about 200 basis points from third quarter level.In an environment where new lease rates have been challenging, we are very focused on resident retention. During the fourth quarter of 2009, we were able to retain approximately 67% of our customers, which was an increase of 50 basis points compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. We saw a sequential improvement from residential retention throughout the fourth quarter with December finishing at 68% or 250 basis points over December of 2008.For the full year 2009, same store conventional NOI was down 4.2% with revenue down 2.5% as compared to 2008, almost entirely attributable to a 2.5% decline in average rents. For the year, same store conventional expense growth was held in check with only a 30-basis-point increase compared to 2008. We continue to see the benefits of the earning of our contract renegotiated efforts undertaken during 2009 and additional expense reductions were achieved by lowering turn costs, administrative costs, marketing costs and utility expense. These savings were offset by higher insurance expense and by higher repairs and maintenance costs as we focused on product quality. For the full year 2009, our same store conventional property operating margin was 61.1% or just 20 basis points below that of our 2008 same store conventional portfolio despite declining revenues.  From an operating standpoint, 2009 was a challenging year for the apartment industry. However, we are pleased with the results that Aimco's operating team has achieved. As to conventional redevelopment, we invested $56 million during the year and completed 33 of the 37 projects that were active at the beginning of 2009. We took advantage of the short cycle nature of our redevelopment program by reducing the scope of several projects, thereby reducing potential expenditures and $47 million. We begin 2010 with four projects in process which we expect will require $7 million to complete.  Beyond this, we do not expect significant redevelopment activity in 2010. However, we have a pipeline of redevelopment candidates within our portfolio and a platform in place that will allow us to ramp up our investment if we see the opportunity to achieve attractive returns. As to 2009 asset sales, during the fourth quarter, we sold 32 properties for $533 million with net proceeds at Aimco of $154 million. We sold a total of 90 properties during 2009 for $1.3 billion, with net proceeds to Aimco of $407 million. We had aggressive sales targets for 2009 and we feel good about what we accomplished. We saw pricing stabilized in the last half of the year. And it appears that values are continuing to firm.  After being a net seller since 2002, we begin 2010 with a substantially improved portfolio with average rents that are 45% higher than they were seven years ago, 30% higher than those of the assets we sold in 2009, 5% above the average local market rents and average rents in our target markets that are comparable to those of the peer REITs on a market-by-market basis.Now looking ahead, we were just a month or so in 2010 but I would like to give you a bit of color on what we see operationally so far. Since the beginning of January, we have been able to increase new lease rents in a number of our markets, most notably Washington D.C., South Florida, Chicago and Denver. However, we continue to see pressure on rents in our Phoenix, Tampa and Orlando. We have continued to hold occupancy coming into 2010 and ended up January with a monthly same store average daily occupancy above 95.5%. While higher occupancy should continue to provide some pricing power in a number of markets, we remain cautious overall given continued economic uncertainty nationally.In 2010, our focus is to maximize total revenue by balancing rate and occupancy. We have confidence that Tony D'Alto and his team will continue to provide excellent customer service to our residents and maximize the profitability of our operating portfolio over the coming year. By the end of 2010, we expect to substantially all of our conventional redevelopment properties to be stabilized and included in our same store conventional portfolio operating results. In 2010, we are turning our attention recycling capital for proceeds from asset sales generally used to improve portfolio quality. We may sell somewhere between 5% and 10% of the portfolio in 2010, but volumes are dependent upon the availability of attractive opportunities to redeploy that capital and our markets by investing our properties the redevelopment or acquisitions. We do not expect to see a great deal of any seriously distressed asset sales in the multifamily space, but we are keeping our ear to the ground and looking for acquisition opportunities. In summary, we are going to spend 2010 operating our quality portfolio well and continuing to improve portfolio quality and concentrate capital and our target markets. With that, I will turn it over to Ernie.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects. First, our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2009. Second, fourth quarter debt capital market activities. Third, a recent amendment to our credit agreement, which p
componenttext: Thank you, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects. First, our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2009. Second, fourth quarter debt capital market activities. Third, a recent amendment to our credit agreement, which provides for more flexibility relative to our debt covenants. And finally, I will provide first quarter and full year 2010 guidance.  Before I discuss our results, I would like to point out that a change in GAAP occurred during the fourth quarter, the application of which reduced diluted shares outstanding used in Aimco's FFO per share computations for the fourth quarter and full year 2008. This change had no effect on fourth quarter or full year 2009 FFO per share results. Additional details may be found in the earnings release we issued this morning.Now for 2009 financial results. Fourth quarter FFO, before operating real estate impairment charges, was $0.26 per share. Included in the $0.26 per share result was a $0.10 per share non-cash impairment of our interest in Casden Properties LLC. And any organize to buy, re-entitle and develop land parcels in Southern California. Aimco's initial interest in the LLC was $50 million and was written down to $31 million at the end of 2008. An additional impairment of $21 million before tax was required in 2009 due to the continued decline of land values in Southern California, reducing Aimco's interest to $10 million at year end.Excluding this impairment, fourth quarter FFO was $0.36 per share, which was at the mid-point of guidance. Included in our fourth quarter results were restructuring charges at $0.06 net of tax. We had contemplated some but not all of these charges in our fourth quarter guidance. The better-than-anticipated operating results and results through investment management activities helped to offset the additional restructuring costs.Full year 2009 FFO per share before the effect of the Casden impairment was $1.65, which was at the midpoint of guidance provided last quarter and consistent with guidance provided one year ago. Turning to our debt capital market activities since the end of the third quarter, we have repaid $205 million of our term debt, leaving us with the balance today of $55 million. As Tim mentioned, we have seen some improvement in asset values over the last few months. And we are careful to balance the timing of term debt repayment with achieving optimal pricing on asset sales. Based on our current sales pipeline and other sources of cash, we expect to continue to pay down our term debt in the first quarter. We will aim to have it completely paid by the end of the second quarter.We have made similar progress extending our property debt maturities to refinancing, repayment and property sales, Aimco has eliminated all 2010 property debt maturities. We currently have four loans with appropriate collateral, including $100 million that mature in 2011. We plan to refinance these loans at their respective maturity dates, but we will continue to work with our lending partners to seek an earlier refinance, if possible.We are now focused on loan maturities that occur during 2012 through 2014, looking to extend our loans beyond that period to reduce refunding risks and to lock in current interest rates. In connection with our term debt, and our line of credit, we are subject to certain covenants including debt service and fixed charge coverage minimums. Aimco's fourth quarter debt service and fixed charge coverage ratios were 159 and 136, compared to covenants in place during the period of 150 and 130, respectively. Earlier this week, we and our lenders agreed to amend our credit agreement to provide for a reduction in debt service and fixed charge coverage covenants to 140 and 120 respectively, to at least October 1, 2011. Based on our current projections, we expect that we will remain in compliance with these requirements.Looking ahead to 2010, we will continue our efforts to one, maintain property income across our separate portfolios. Two, complete repayment of our term debt. And three, concentrate our investment capital in our target market. After consideration of the funds necessary to repay our term debt, we are largely funded to internal sources. The combination of proceeds from property sales and excess refinance proceeds of approximately $80 million are needed to balance out 2010 cash flows.2010 FFO is projected to range from $1.25 to $1.35 per share. The year-over-year decline from 2009 is primarily due to $0.23 per share dilution from 2009 property sales, $0.09 per share from operations due to earning of lower rents and increased expenses and $0.12 per share due to lower investment management activities. All partially offset by $0.09 per share in lower off-site cost including G&A. Finally, there were several miscellaneous one-time items that net to zero including restructuring charges in 2009.Particular assumptions for 2010 include, first for property operations, we expect total portfolio net operating income, which includes our same store conventional properties, conventional redevelopment properties and our affordable properties to decline year-over-year, 1% to 3%. Regarding same store conventional net operating income, our release this morning contains an inconsistency around our projection for 2010 results. We have provided on our Outlook page within the release, we anticipate a year-over-year same store conventional net operating income decline of 2% to 5%, which includes 0.5% to 2% decline in revenue and 1.5% to 2.5% increase in expenses. Our 2010 guidance also includes property management expense of $45 million.Second, for recurring investment management activities, our guidance assumes $11 million of income after tax, which includes $34 million of revenue, $10 million of expenses and $13 million of taxes. Third, for non-recurring investment management activities, guidance includes $3 million to $6 million of income after tax, which includes $7 million to $10 million of revenue, approximately $2 million of expenses and approximately $2 million of taxes. Non-recurring net income represents approximately 3% of our expected 2010 FFO.  Finally, our guidance includes $53 million of G&A expense. First quarter 2010 FFO is projected to be $0.26 to $0.30 per share for the year-over-year same store conventional net operating income decline of 5.5% to 6.5%.Before we take questions, I would like to remind everyone of our upcoming Investor Day to be held in New York City, February 17. And in Chicago on February 18. The New York event will be webcast and the details of that will be described in a press release sometime next week. If you're interested in attending one of these events and have not already done so, please contact Elizabeth Coalson to sign up. With that, we will now open the call for questions. Please limit your questions to two per time in the queue. Operator, I'll turn it over to you for the first question.

componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Rob. I'll speak to how we look at revenue guidance for 2010. Basically, it's a property by bottoms-up process where we're really focused on the demand drivers in each individual market, leasing velocity that we're seeing, et cetera. What
componenttext: Michael, this is Rob. I'll speak to how we look at revenue guidance for 2010. Basically, it's a property by bottoms-up process where we're really focused on the demand drivers in each individual market, leasing velocity that we're seeing, et cetera. What we do is we roll those numbers up and then utilize third-party information providers typically, REIS, PPR or AxioMetrics as a barometer at a market level and the total roll-off level to compare how we're seeing it versus the market comparisons overall from third-party sources. So it's implicit in that is employment expectations from a third-party providers but our approach again as a bottoms up based on what we see on the ground on a property-by-property the property basis

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Terry, Michael. I think right now the spread -- if you're selling at the same quality, it will be neutral. If you're selling and getting a different quality, the spreads could be as wide as 100 to 150 basis points. So it sells from the bottom of o
componenttext: This is Terry, Michael. I think right now the spread -- if you're selling at the same quality, it will be neutral. If you're selling and getting a different quality, the spreads could be as wide as 100 to 150 basis points. So it sells from the bottom of our portfolio, you may buy at the top of other portfolio. Looking at that, one of the questions I mentioned is, because I'm not sure that's going to be an attractive rate at which we would want to invest, and I think it may well be that we'll end up investing more in redevelopment where we would look to have premiums of say, 20% to the acquisition rate. So this acquisition rate where 6% we'd be wanting to the redevelopment at 7.2%.

But of course, if things were to change with our share prices, some what we can consider.

componenttext: Secondly, just a little bit more detail on the changing covenants, I assume that you initiated the discussion? Or perhaps not. Could you just tell us a little bit about how that came about? And is there any risk that you could bump up against the revised covenants?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: We did seek it. And as we look at the environment out there and third-party and experts are projecting a very wide range of possibilities for revenue growth in 2010 as I'm sure many of you have seen. For the entire U.S., PPR and REITs are currently almost
componenttext: We did seek it. And as we look at the environment out there and third-party and experts are projecting a very wide range of possibilities for revenue growth in 2010 as I'm sure many of you have seen. For the entire U.S., PPR and REITs are currently almost 400 basis points apart with their projecting. And in some markets, as many as 1,000 basis points apart as to what their expectations are around revenue growth. Our view fall similar between the two of those. And given the possibility, the worse than expected condition, we thought it was prudent in the right time to seek an amendment. And along those lines, I would like to take a moment and thanks our bank group for their continued support. Bank of America, KeyBanc, and Wells Fargo, were there for us when we renewed our line of credit in a very difficult capital markets last April. And we greatly appreciate their confidence in us and improving our amendments today. So in regards to bumping up to our new levels, at our low point in the guidance range that I gave you it today, we would still have some room, not before bumping up against.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Levy of Macquarie.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, just on the acquisitions, could you give any possible color as to where these properties might be located?
componenttext: I was wondering, just on the acquisitions, could you give any possible color as to where these properties might be located?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, it's Terry again. We would like to increase our investment in Washington and in New York and to reallocate our investment in suburban Boston into urban Boston. We'd like to buy in Seattle. We'd like to buy in the Bay area. And we'd like to buy in
componenttext: Michael, it's Terry again. We would like to increase our investment in Washington and in New York and to reallocate our investment in suburban Boston into urban Boston. We'd like to buy in Seattle. We'd like to buy in the Bay area. And we'd like to buy in San Diego. Now those are not unique goals for real estate investors. Those are all regarded as very good market. And so, I think that our investment activity will be focused on ones that have some opportunity for value add, whether it's redevelopment or completion perhaps of a installed project, but the current pricing that I see is not compelling.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, kind of just a follow up to that, may I ask whether any assets have been sold so far this year?
componenttext: I guess, kind of just a follow up to that, may I ask whether any assets have been sold so far this year?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've only sold one asset so far. I mean, obviously with the improving market, we still have I think roughly $250 million under some level of contract. But you know it's an improving market, if people come back and have contingencies or issues that they'r
componenttext: We've only sold one asset so far. I mean, obviously with the improving market, we still have I think roughly $250 million under some level of contract. But you know it's an improving market, if people come back and have contingencies or issues that they're looking to be waived or price reductions, we just aren't going down that path right now. So we've been very cautious but we still have a lot of activity and we completed one asset sale to date.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it would be realistic for me to assume or for us to assume rather that there will be $250 million plus the one asset that's already sold this year because those $250 million are already under contract, right?
componenttext: So it would be realistic for me to assume or for us to assume rather that there will be $250 million plus the one asset that's already sold this year because those $250 million are already under contract, right?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, they're in the contract but not all this hard on their money. So I imagine a couple of those rule fall out. But I would suspect over the year, we will do between $200 million and $500 million worth of sales for various different reasons.
componenttext: Well, they're in the contract but not all this hard on their money. So I imagine a couple of those rule fall out. But I would suspect over the year, we will do between $200 million and $500 million worth of sales for various different reasons.

componenttext: That's correct, Michael. Tim mentioned it and now our redevelopment portfolio specifically at the end of 2008 and the occupancy in the high 80s, around 88%, and we were able to get that up to 95% as we slowdown that work and have less units that were not filled up. So there's nothing we need to take as big a pot this year from redevelopment as there was in the year 2009.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kind of a follow up on that question, on the 2% to 5% decline in NOI guidance, the wording in your press release implies that, that incorporates redevelopment properties as they stabilized. Am I reading that right?
componenttext: Kind of a follow up on that question, on the 2% to 5% decline in NOI guidance, the wording in your press release implies that, that incorporates redevelopment properties as they stabilized. Am I reading that right?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we'll do, Andy, with any properties in the first quarter that stabilize, we will move those into the same-store population and we keep that population that's set for the rest of the year. There will be additional property that will move into the
componenttext: Yes, what we'll do, Andy, with any properties in the first quarter that stabilize, we will move those into the same-store population and we keep that population that's set for the rest of the year. There will be additional property that will move into the same-store population in quarters two, three and four. Those aren't contemplated in our guidance because we want to have one set number for the year look. But as we do quarter-to-quarter looks, you'll see the population will change a bit around -- within same store.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: If properties roll in as they stabilize, won't that inflate your projected growth? Because the redevelopment property, if it stabilizes in the quarter, it won't be stabilized in the prior year period?
componenttext: If properties roll in as they stabilize, won't that inflate your projected growth? Because the redevelopment property, if it stabilizes in the quarter, it won't be stabilized in the prior year period?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me clarify that, Andy. When we say as they stabilize, and they have actually been stabilized for a 12-month period, that's when they move in.
componenttext: Yes, let me clarify that, Andy. When we say as they stabilize, and they have actually been stabilized for a 12-month period, that's when they move in.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: So they've been stabilized for a full year before they roll in.
componenttext: So they've been stabilized for a full year before they roll in.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Exactly. They got to be stabilized for 12 months before we consider that. So even though we wound down the program significantly in 2009, that's why not many moved in, in 2009. So they hadn't had 12 months of stable operations.
componenttext: Exactly. They got to be stabilized for 12 months before we consider that. So even though we wound down the program significantly in 2009, that's why not many moved in, in 2009. So they hadn't had 12 months of stable operations.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010

componenttext: No, it shouldn't because again, it's based on 12 months of similar performance.

componenttext: Sure. Hi, this is Tony D'Alto. You had a second question about Miami, in particular?
