componenttext: First to be clear, it's in the last 30 days, is what I'm referencing. Secondly is, our demand is quite strong coming into January and as we look into February. And our occupancies are significantly higher than where we were a year ago. So we have the pricing power.

componenttext: Yes, let me address that. Without giving guidance too much further in here, what I can tell you is like a lot of folks have seen, we're going to finish earning into our gain to lease from the first half of the year and anticipating better results in the second half of the year. But clearly, second half results are expected to be stronger than first half results.

componenttext: Well, it really goes back to what Robert said, and I'll let him jump in as well. But as we look at our assets on an asset-by-asset basis and project where we think things are going to go and as we work through the gain to lease and in terms of the leases that are rolling over here at the first part of the year, we feel that the second half as we've laid it, and you can tell from our guidance, lays out to be a stronger half than the first half.

componenttext: There were two pieces to that. One, we agreed to raise our unused fee, five basis points, from 45 basis points to 50 basis points. That will cost us about $90,000 a year. And then secondly, as the one-time fee for the lead bank putting this together, as well for those who are participating as a one-time charge, that's a bit less than $900,000.

componenttext: No, no other changes. It was just to those that we discussed.

componenttext: Yes, turnover expectations for 2010 is a maintenance will continue to be a main focus for us. We will stay very much focused on retaining the current customers and focus on customer service. And we expect to improve somewhat year-over-year in terms of our total retention.

componenttext: I guess I'll check with transcript for what the expectation for -- what 2009 was for total turnover. componenttext: Rich, we can. I can see that we've created an ambiguity and concern. And I just want to clarify, we're not doing anything new or different about our same-store portfolio. Before our property moves from redev to the same-store portfolio, it has to have been stabilized for 12 months. We can go back and we can show you the properties that will -- because there has been a certain amount of change and there has been a fair amount of properties moving from redevelopment into same store during 2010, but we could come up with a schedule at the beginning of the year and I don't know that -- I assume we can do that in our projection for the balance of 2010 on what we expected with it.

componenttext: It all comes back to the bottom line anyway, it's just that it's more how the data is presented in terms of the same store. So it's not a big deal, I just want to make sure we understand, it's apples to apples with your peers. The second question is, the fixed charge coverage ratio of 1.36x today and the whole deal about resetting your covenants and good news there. But your peers, I don't know if there is anyone in the multi-family space or maybe that's below two times in a fixed charge coverage basis. I know you guys kind of have a different model from a balance sheet perspective and I understand the advantages of secured debt model for you guys, so no question there. But maybe you can explain a little bit further to the audience why it's okay for Aimco to operate at that level of leverage where your peers are to use a phrase in order of magnitude greater than you in some cases? Can you just go through that for me?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Ernie. Let me address one thing specific about the number you're quoting, the 1.36. Our coverage is, by definition, wouldn't be lower than anyone else in the space because of amortization required from our property which build a layer of saf
componenttext: Rich, this is Ernie. Let me address one thing specific about the number you're quoting, the 1.36. Our coverage is, by definition, wouldn't be lower than anyone else in the space because of amortization required from our property which build a layer of safety. If you take out the amortization, that was up our coverages by about 25 to 30 basis points. So yes, still trailing others. If you want to compare apples in apples, it's important to take that into consideration. And we do like the fact that the amortization builds in from discipline and does build into safety with regards to that when it comes to how we view leverage. That said, Terry alluded to in his comments, we would like to improve leverage from the perspective of bringing it down and we hope to do that through NOI growing to the cyclical recovery but in addition, through the forced property debt amortization that's required. And so over time, we would expect that our coverage should improve for both of those things.

componenttext: Just following on Rich's question there, Terry, you mentioned possibly a dividend increase this year. Can you just balance that against obviously, the concerns over leverage or discontinued deleveraging?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jay, in the first half of the year, we'll have continued deleveraging as we pay out the term debt and amortize this property debt. In the second half of the year, we will have scheduled payments of property debt which will provide for amortization and as
componenttext: Jay, in the first half of the year, we'll have continued deleveraging as we pay out the term debt and amortize this property debt. In the second half of the year, we will have scheduled payments of property debt which will provide for amortization and as people can see, expected better year-over-year comparisons. We'll look at our cash flows at that time and see what's the best allocation. The dividend is low as a percent of FFO in over a period of time. We want to increase the cash return to shareholders. We're not attracted to accelerating the amortization of the property debt because it doesn't make a lot of sense to pay off debt that has a weighted average cost of 5 1/2% in a weighted average maturity of nine years. We will just let that happen according to schedule. So I think, I don't know if that's responsive, but the answer is in looking at the dividend, we'll weigh it compared to other uses of corporate funds and try to find the right balance.

componenttext: And my second question, you talk more about redevelopment obviously in the coming year or so, can you just balance that as well against you're going to see an environment where rents likely begin to increase in the coming 12 to 18 months and how you sort of manage redevelopment in that potential drag on earnings as you could see an accelerating earnings grow the cycle?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think just to go through the points that you raised. First of all, it would be our expectation that rents will be higher in 2011 and 2012 depending on the local market, local service gains. That strengthening demand will support property upgrades
componenttext: Well, I think just to go through the points that you raised. First of all, it would be our expectation that rents will be higher in 2011 and 2012 depending on the local market, local service gains. That strengthening demand will support property upgrades and particularly, attractive locations. So we'll see the opportunity. One of the things we like about redevelopment is that we can make those decisions and activities in a fairly short cycle way. So as we gear up, we can jump in and see if it's working and if it's not working, we can trouble back. I don't expect that we would see it in the volumes in which we are operating in 2008 because at least for right now, I'm still quite cautious about the economy and concerns about double dip and these other issues.

componenttext: Rich, while you're back though, I wanted to thank you for your question on same-store pool because I think one of the differences that I want you and the Street to see is that in Aimco, our same-store pool this year will change the fair amount from last year. First of all, we sold $1.3 billion, that will come out of the same store. And secondly, we have a large redevelopment program in 2006, 2007 and 2008 and so that we're stabilized for 12 months so there's not any change in the rules around same store, they will come in. You have a different population, significantly different population at significantly higher rents, significantly better locations and significantly higher operating margins. And so that's something you can look forward to seeing in 2010.

componenttext: Jay, I think the conclusion I have is that for the moment, I don't see extraordinary investment opportunities. We are looking in a number of markets, as we've mentioned earlier, and there's activity going on. But prices are relatively high and so I want to be selective about where we invest new capital. I think I would like to have a higher return than I see in most of the offerings that are available to us. And so, I'm thinking that over time, we'll end up with more of a value-added component to what we do.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Quarter 2010 Apartment Investment and Management Company Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And now I would like to turn the call over to Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and General Counsel. Please proceed.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrea. Good morning, and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgments including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and u
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrea. Good morning, and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgments including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties. A description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. 
Also, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures, such as funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on AIMCO's website. 
The participant on today's call will be Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO, will provide opening remarks; Tim Beaudin, AIMCO's President and Chief Operating Officer, who will speak to property operations, redevelopment activities and asset sales; Ernie Freedman, CFO, review first quarter financial results, debt capital markets activity and guidance for the second quarter and full year 2010. I will now turn the call to Terry Considine, our CEO. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and thanks all of you on this call for your interest in AIMCO. The focus of this call will be AIMCO's first quarter results, but before turning the call over to my colleagues, I would like to offer some general observations. First, this i
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and thanks all of you on this call for your interest in AIMCO. The focus of this call will be AIMCO's first quarter results, but before turning the call over to my colleagues, I would like to offer some general observations. First, this is a good time to invest in Apartment. Supply and demand fundamentals are quite good, with net new supplies very positive over the next five years, while demand is highly predictable and growing. 
The number of men and women aged 20 to 34 will increase by 4 million or 6% over the next five years. Most of these will live in apartments at one time or another. And as a result, demand for rental apartments is projected to increase by almost 1 million units and the predictable results will be rent increases. The second reason to invest in Apartment is that apartments are real or hard assets. And while I recognize that there is little currently measured inflation, there is widespread concern that the enormous increase in money supply and financial liquidity may translate into monetary inflation. And if so, apartments are likely to hold their real value. 
So this is a good time to invest in apartments and an even better time to invest in AIMCO. We have a simple business plan. We own and operate about 100,000 apartments, primarily BB+ in quality. Our properties are generally located in the top 20 U.S. markets. Besides owning and operating apartments, we create value by redeveloping opportunistically and we refinance and we finance at the property level with low-risk, non-recourse, long-dated, fixed-rate and advertising property debt that provides a low cost of capital and an interesting hedge against inflation. 
It seems to me that the AIMCO share price tends to benefit more than the share prices of other apartment REITs. As the apartment market recovers and as the stock market understands more clearly 60 valuation factors. First, we hold high-quality assets; Secondly, we're reliable operator; third, we have limited balance sheet risk; fourth, we have a high quality of earnings; fifth, our shares are priced at a discount to the shares of Apartment REIT peers; and sixth, the financial leverage of our low-risk, non-recourse property debt and preferred stocks' magnified upside in a rising market. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call to Tim Beaudin to review operations. Tim?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss our first quarter operating results; provide some color around what we see heading into the leasing season; and finally, provide a brief update on what we are seeing on the capital recycling front. First, o
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss our first quarter operating results; provide some color around what we see heading into the leasing season; and finally, provide a brief update on what we are seeing on the capital recycling front. 
First, operating results. AIMCO'S portfolio primary consist of same-store properties and redevelopment properties, with 80% of the NOI coming from same-store and 15% provided by redevelopment. The remaining 5% of our NOI is generated by other conventional properties. Total portfolio NOI was down 2% in the first quarter compared to first quarter last year. A total same-store NOI decline of 4.3% was somewhat offset by gains in the redevelopment. 
Our same-store properties are comprised of conventional same-store and affordable same-store. Conventional same-store NOI was down 5.4% compared to the first quarter of 2009, 10 basis points better than the high end of our guidance provided last quarter. Conventional same-store revenue declined 1.8%, driven by a 5.5% decline in average rents, partially offset by a 2.7% increase in occupancy to 96%. Lower rates were further offset by a decrease in bad debt expense of more than 22% and a 3.6% increase in other rental income served to offset the decline in average rents. 
Conventional same-store expenses increased 3.9%, primarily due to increased snow removal cost in the Northeast; repairs and maintenance; and marketing expenses, partially offset by lower churn cost and administrative expenses. Affordable same-store NOI was 3.2% higher compared to first quarter 2009, with revenues up 2.9% and expenses up 2.7%. While this is just 11% of AIMCO's NOI, our allocation to affordable property serves offset the volatility of our conventional portfolio, provide revenue growth that over time is similar to that of the conventional properties, expand our investment opportunities and provide helpful positioning with government bodies benefiting AIMCO's business overall. 
Conventional redevelopment NOI was up 14 .6% compared to the first quarter of 2009, while affordable redevelopment NOI was up 10.2%. NOI gains in the redevelopment are probably a function of lease up of units that were off-line a year ago. As we head in the leasing season, we are cautiously optimistic for several reasons. First, we have had a great deal of success from retaining our residents. During the first quarter of 2010, we retained 68% of our customers, which is up 120 basis points over first quarter 2009 and represents an all-time high for AIMCO. Second, our apartments are full. First quarter 2010 occupancy was 96% overall and north of 95% in nearly all of our markets. April average daily occupancy is holding steady and demand remains steady. 
Third, the decline in transacted rents appears to be slowing. For the quarter, conventional same-store new lease rent were 7% lower than the expiring lease rates. While renewal rate were 10 basis points higher than the expiring lease rates. Since the beginning of the year, we have been able to increase conventional same-store new lease rents month-over-month in the majority of our markets, with Southern California and Florida being notable exceptions. We saw our new and renewal lease rates improved throughout quarter, and the gap between new and renewal rates has narrowed from a negative 5.5% during the fourth quarter to a negative 3% for the first quarter of 2010. 
While we have not seen a robust recovery, we are encouraged to see signs of improvement, and we will see what the next few months bring. As to our capital recycling, our strategy is to sell 5% to 10% of our portfolio annually, but proceeds generally used to improve portfolio quality to redevelopment or acquisitions within our target markets. However, sales volumes in any given quarter or year will be dependent on the availability of attractive opportunities to redeploy capital. We are still very focused in repaying the $35 million of our term debt. So proceeds from asset sales will be used primarily for that purpose until the balance is fully paid. 
During the first quarter, we sold 12 properties for $83 million with net proceeds to AIMCO of $17 million. We currently have five conventional properties under contract with hard money that are expected to close in the next 30 days or so, and about a dozen affordable properties that we expect to close during the second half of the year. We have more than 20 conventional properties that are listed, in some stage of negotiation or under contract, and nearly twice that amount of affordable properties in a similar stages of marketing. 
We are seeing strong buyer interest in the properties we are selling, with multiple offers on  every property. Cap rates are dropping and pricing is improving in virtually every market when compared to last year, parts of Florida being the exception. But prices remained well below peak levels due to a lower projected NOIs. 
In summary, we are pleased with our first quarter results, and our plans for the future remained simple and unchanged. We are going to focus on operating our portfolio well and continuing to improve portfolio quality and concentrating capital in our target markets. With that, I will turn it over to Ernie. Ernie?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects. First, our financial results for the first quarter; second, our balance sheet; and third, I will provide second quarter and full year 2010 guidance. Before I discuss the results, I would
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects. First, our financial results for the first quarter; second, our balance sheet; and third, I will provide second quarter and full year 2010 guidance. 
Before I discuss the results, I would like to point out that we have made a number of changes to our earnings release and supplement schedules for 2010, which we hope you'll to be an improvement. As you spend time reviewing our supplemental schedule and have any questions or feedback, please reach out to Elizabeth Coalson or me. 
Now for our first quarter financial results. First quarter pro forma FFO was $0.32 per share or $0.02 per share above the high point of guidance provided in February. Higher-than-anticipated occupancy in our redevelopment portfolio and lower offsite costs were partially offset by lower-than-expected transaction income. Variances in offsite costs and transaction income are the result of timing differences, and we expect these to be offset over in the coming quarters. 
Turning to the balance sheet. We have retained $55 million of our term debt in 2010, including $10 million in April, leaving us with a balance of $35 million today. We expect that this will be fully repaid from property sale proceeds over the next few months. We have no 2010 property debt maturities and we currently have four loans with appropriate collateral totaling $100 million that mature in 2011 then refinance these loans closer to the respective maturity dates, but we will continue to work with our lending partners to seek an earlier refinance as possible. 
We continue to focus a loan maturities occurring during 2012 through 2014 looking to extend our loans beyond that period to reduce refunding risks and to lock in current interest rates. As we look past the next few year's projected economic growth, we plan to reduce somewhat AIMCO's financial leverage by typical recovery of property income and by scheduled amortization of our property debt, which averages about $80 million per year over the next few years. 
At the guidance, second quarter 2010 pro forma FFO is projected to be $0.28 to $0.34 per share, with a year-over-year conventional same-store NOI decline of 5% to 6%. On April 1, two properties were moved into our conventional same-store portfolio in the conventional redevelopment portfolio. Our second quarter 2010 conventional same-store NOI guidance includes the reclassification of these properties. 
Projected full year 2010 pro forma FFO is unchanged from our last update and is expected to range from $1.25 to $1.35 per share. Our projection of full year conventional same-store NOI decline of 2% to 5% as well as our total portfolio NOI decline of 1% to 3% also remains unchanged. 
With that, we will now open the call up for questions. Please limit your questions to two per time in the queue.

componenttext: Well, the good news is that we're basically seeing recovery in most markets. It's relative of course in places like Phoenix and Miami, less so relative to rate increases but are doing fairly well. I'd point out that we only have two markets in our entire portfolio that's below 95%. So I think that the Coast of course where we're seeing the Northeast and Southern California and pretty much every place outside of Phoenix and Florida were very highly occupied and we've taken rate increases to the first quarter. And we feel very comfortable that we'll pretty well set up for the summer season. So in total, we're seeing it across the board, it's just relative levels of strength depending on the market.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the difference between the performance of As and Bs. And Terry, you made reference obviously AIMCO and compared the company to some of your peers. I'm just curious, if you're continuing to see the cap rates widen out between the As and
componenttext: Just going back to the difference between the performance of As and Bs. And Terry, you made reference obviously AIMCO and compared the company to some of your peers. I'm just curious, if you're continuing to see the cap rates widen out between the As and Bs? I mean, do you feel that the expectations for rent growth from the more Class A assets are just getting too high at this point in terms of growth over the next two or three years?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that the asset pricing is more optimistic than the that data providers' rent projection. And that gives rise to which of the two is right. It could be that rates will grow faster, that rental rates will grow faster. And if so, that will be because
componenttext: I think that the asset pricing is more optimistic than the that data providers' rent projection. And that gives rise to which of the two is right. It could be that rates will grow faster, that rental rates will grow faster. And if so, that will be because of either real demand recovery in the job markets in this time of very limited supply or it will be because of the monetary inflation creeping into the economy. For the moment, I think we have to wait and see.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the reason I asked is as I think about AIMCO, you referenced at your Analyst Day that markets such as New York and Boston and San Francisco where you have below-average rents versus the market. I mean, do you expect your portfolio to maintain the
componenttext: I guess the reason I asked is as I think about AIMCO, you referenced at your Analyst Day that markets such as New York and Boston and San Francisco where you have below-average rents versus the market. I mean, do you expect your portfolio to maintain the same rent growth say that of your peers, similarly positioned in those markets?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I think in those markets, benchmarking against the market, we expect rent growth to be comparable to or similar to that of the market. I wouldn't go through in benchmark against specific peers without looking at their exact properties.
componenttext: I think in those markets, benchmarking against the market, we expect rent growth to be comparable to or similar to that of the market. I wouldn't go through in benchmark against specific peers without looking at their exact properties.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, the question on asset sales, can you give us a sense of the dollar amount that your looking at? I mean, you mentioned the number of properties but what potentially dollar amount you currently have listed today? And then I guess in contras
componenttext: And then lastly, the question on asset sales, can you give us a sense of the dollar amount that your looking at? I mean, you mentioned the number of properties but what potentially dollar amount you currently have listed today? And then I guess in contrast, what are you looking at in terms of acquisition opportunities and the spread between where you're selling and where you're potentially buying?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: We've talked about in our today's guidance, but I don't recall whether we gave guidance to it, but that we would sell probably $300 million in assets and generate $100 million in cash or corporate purposes primarily repayment of the term debt. And that's
componenttext: We've talked about in our today's guidance, but I don't recall whether we gave guidance to it, but that we would sell probably $300 million in assets and generate $100 million in cash or corporate purposes primarily repayment of the term debt. And that's well underway, as Tim mentioned in his remarks. Going forward, further sales will be connected to our opportunity to reinvest the proceeds on an accretive basis, either in acquisitions or redevelopment. And in looking at that, we don't focus as much on NOI cap rates or NOI differences as we do on free cash flow internal rates of return, and we would expect that it would be accretive and not diluted.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: But you talked about asset sales being offset by acquisitions? It sounds like maybe perhaps that could be shifting toward redevelopment? Is that sort of the direction you're moving?
componenttext: But you talked about asset sales being offset by acquisitions? It sounds like maybe perhaps that could be shifting toward redevelopment? Is that sort of the direction you're moving?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: We're looking at both. It just really goes back to your first question that some acquisitions are priced at a level that's not attractive to us. And that will lead us to more value-added activities like redevelopment after we require a higher spread, then
componenttext: We're looking at both. It just really goes back to your first question that some acquisitions are priced at a level that's not attractive to us. And that will lead us to more value-added activities like redevelopment after we require a higher spread, then it would be available from the acquisition activity. But we're also seeing some interesting acquisition opportunities. We'll just going to have to play them out, which of those we do.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jeff Donnelly of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jeff Donnelly of Wells Fargo.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little about maybe what's happened subsequent to quarter end as it relates to your revenues? Have you seen trends retreat, hold or accelerate?
componenttext: Can you talk a little about maybe what's happened subsequent to quarter end as it relates to your revenues? Have you seen trends retreat, hold or accelerate?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: We are actually holding quite well. As a matter of fact, April will have a higher occupancy than March. And in terms of revenues, we're right where we anticipate it would be.
componenttext: We are actually holding quite well. As a matter of fact, April will have a higher occupancy than March. And in terms of revenues, we're right where we anticipate it would be.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Does the continued improvement in occupancy lead you to think that you ought to be getting more aggressive on rents sooner or...
componenttext: Does the continued improvement in occupancy lead you to think that you ought to be getting more aggressive on rents sooner or...

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've actually been taking rate actions and obviously increased occupancies will give us more opportunities to do more of that as we move forward.
componenttext: Yes, we've actually been taking rate actions and obviously increased occupancies will give us more opportunities to do more of that as we move forward.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: And just expense side, we have the revenue certainly coming back, how do you think about your expenses as being rolled forward in 2010 and '11? Or is there anything that stands out to you as an area that could come back a little quicker than [indiscernibl
componenttext: And just expense side, we have the revenue certainly coming back, how do you think about your expenses as being rolled forward in 2010 and '11? Or is there anything that stands out to you as an area that could come back a little quicker than [indiscernible]?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: By the way, this is Tony, Jeff. We remain very focused on expenses. And as you could see from our reporting, the major material impact in our increase was based on weather. Everything else was a function of the timing or source of other expenditures in di
componenttext: By the way, this is Tony, Jeff. We remain very focused on expenses. And as you could see from our reporting, the major material impact in our increase was based on weather. Everything else was a function of the timing or source of other expenditures in different markets. We expect to be right within what we plan to be, which is baked into our guidance.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you guys describe yourself as a BB+ owner of apartments that by that, I think the definition you guys published where your rents stand versus your competitors, that will actually puts you at something closer to a B-, if you will, amount of foot ha
componenttext: I think you guys describe yourself as a BB+ owner of apartments that by that, I think the definition you guys published where your rents stand versus your competitors, that will actually puts you at something closer to a B-, if you will, amount of foot hairs. But if the goal is move towards that B+ level, I suspect that means selling out of more assets. Is there a theme towards the majority of those assets, the ones that might drag you down a little bit? Is there a theme to where reside maybe geographically?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, this is Ernie. We're always will be calling our portfolio a little bit fell of the bottom, and that should continue to improve. Our rents are certainly local market averages. After fourth quarter reported in our more recent supplementals in the four
componenttext: Jeff, this is Ernie. We're always will be calling our portfolio a little bit fell of the bottom, and that should continue to improve. Our rents are certainly local market averages. After fourth quarter reported in our more recent supplementals in the fourth quarter, in the most recent supplementals here that we're about 103% on local market averages. In our view, we view the assets somewhere between 90 and 125. So over time, we will expect the 103 to continue to improve and maybe get closer to 105% 110%. In terms of where those assets are, they're generally located in our non-target markets. We will continue to focus our sales efforts on the bottom of the portfolio, as well as on our non-target markets to improve our standing against local market averages.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: There may be a math on this, but I would think that like your target markets, which are similar to the large and urban markets that the gap between the high end of the market and the low end of the market in rent will be fairly wide to the point being tha
componenttext: There may be a math on this, but I would think that like your target markets, which are similar to the large and urban markets that the gap between the high end of the market and the low end of the market in rent will be fairly wide to the point being that you could very easily be, I guess call it, below the mean in that market but still have pretty high rents, if you will, in absolute terms. But it's better than like a more I guess secondary market. I guess I would assume that the gap between the high and more rent would be pretty tight, so it will to be at the mean or the above. Is that logic make sense? I mean I guess the question is, is there a chance that as you exit secondary markets that you'll actually solidify your position as a more B- portfolio?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Based in our numbers we presented at our Investor Day, our non-target markets are right on top of local market averages, they're about 100% and 101%. At Investor Day, we reported that we were at 104% for the entire portfolio. Could that potentially work o
componenttext: Based in our numbers we presented at our Investor Day, our non-target markets are right on top of local market averages, they're about 100% and 101%. At Investor Day, we reported that we were at 104% for the entire portfolio. Could that potentially work out for someone else this portfolio?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mike Levy of Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mike Levy of Macquarie.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a bit about the strategy with the term loan. If the capital markets are as open as they seem and the assets that you may sell to pay off the term loan is generating decent cash flow and the loan isn't due for another year
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a bit about the strategy with the term loan. If the capital markets are as open as they seem and the assets that you may sell to pay off the term loan is generating decent cash flow and the loan isn't due for another year and presumably prices are going to do nothing but continue to rise, at least for the assets that you're selling, why sell now? Why not just wait until later in the year when pricing is better and sell then?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Terry. Our policy is not to have recourse debt. And the term loan was an exception to that. It was a mistake on my part, I just wanted to get rid of it. It will be paid off in the next month or two or three. And at that point, we'll have
componenttext: Michael, this is Terry. Our policy is not to have recourse debt. And the term loan was an exception to that. It was a mistake on my part, I just wanted to get rid of it. It will be paid off in the next month or two or three. And at that point, we'll have a very low cost, very long-dated and attractive return.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to home in on the earlier question, obviously, rents seem to be rising. I was wondering if you guys have seen any slowdown in rental rates in the past couple of weeks at the pace at which rents seem to be rising, that is?
componenttext: Just to home in on the earlier question, obviously, rents seem to be rising. I was wondering if you guys have seen any slowdown in rental rates in the past couple of weeks at the pace at which rents seem to be rising, that is?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: No. In a word.
componenttext: No. In a word.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: At the Investor Day about 10 weeks ago, Ernie mentioned that he thought an appropriate entity was around $20, I think. With that in mind and given the current share price, do you guys have any view about an equity offering and what you might use the proce
componenttext: At the Investor Day about 10 weeks ago, Ernie mentioned that he thought an appropriate entity was around $20, I think. With that in mind and given the current share price, do you guys have any view about an equity offering and what you might use the proceeds for?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, this Ernie. That's exactly the right point in. What is the use of proceeds? The NAV discussion we had at Investor Day when we presented an NAV based on just September 31, were we thought values were. And I think most people think that up from the
componenttext: Michael, this Ernie. That's exactly the right point in. What is the use of proceeds? The NAV discussion we had at Investor Day when we presented an NAV based on just September 31, were we thought values were. And I think most people think that up from the Street, the values could be up, say 5% and so at year-end. And so that being the case, in doing the math, our NAV would be plus or minus $3 higher than where we were before. That said, you raised a key point in the use the proceeds. So I think the answer is, there's an attractive use of proceeds and it makes the most sense for our shareholders and it's not going to be dilutive, we would definitely consider equity.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you looking at assets to acquire? I think you sort of touched on this earlier. Has there been anything that has come to market, for which you would possibly bid?
componenttext: Are you looking at assets to acquire? I think you sort of touched on this earlier. Has there been anything that has come to market, for which you would possibly bid?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Terry. Generally, we have seen the assets that has come to market and have had the opportunity to bid. We are looking at possible acquisition and we'll see how they turn out. Most likely, they will be funded by proceeds from sale of our l
componenttext: Michael, this is Terry. Generally, we have seen the assets that has come to market and have had the opportunity to bid. We are looking at possible acquisition and we'll see how they turn out. Most likely, they will be funded by proceeds from sale of our lower-rated assets. In terms of acquisition volumes, if we were to acquire a $300 million of assets, that would be funded by $300 million of sales of lower-rated properties currently in our portfolio.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you seeing -- I know that obviously, it seems like there's more Class A assets that are coming on to the market and the bidding process for those is intensely competitive, but in past conversations, I think you had mentioned that you might be looking
componenttext: Are you seeing -- I know that obviously, it seems like there's more Class A assets that are coming on to the market and the bidding process for those is intensely competitive, but in past conversations, I think you had mentioned that you might be looking at something not in the Class A area. So are you seeing opportunities in the class B+ or A- areas? And is the acquisition environment as competitive in that section or in that corner in the market?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, your making very good point. There's a certain amount of histrionics that gets into to these calls. Every part of the business is competitive. And whether it's true for B assets or A assets or C assets, whether it's true for value added by loans,
componenttext: Michael, your making very good point. There's a certain amount of histrionics that gets into to these calls. Every part of the business is competitive. And whether it's true for B assets or A assets or C assets, whether it's true for value added by loans, discounts and so forth. It's a very efficient, very liquid, very competitive market.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Eric Wolfe of Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question is from Eric Wolfe of Citigroup.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to piggyback back off that equity raise question, if you were to raise today, do you know how much property that you could prepay without incurring a penalty?
componenttext: Just to piggyback back off that equity raise question, if you were to raise today, do you know how much property that you could prepay without incurring a penalty?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, we wouldn't be interested to raise equity to pay off property that, which has a weighted average maturity of almost nine years at a weighted average cost of sub-6%. That wouldn't be attractive at all.
componenttext: Eric, we wouldn't be interested to raise equity to pay off property that, which has a weighted average maturity of almost nine years at a weighted average cost of sub-6%. That wouldn't be attractive at all.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as your occupancy, it's pretty high right now. Looks like your expectations for the second quarter is an average of 95.5%. So to meet that midpoint of your guidance, you'd need to average about that 94% for the rest of the year. I'm just wondering
componenttext: As far as your occupancy, it's pretty high right now. Looks like your expectations for the second quarter is an average of 95.5%. So to meet that midpoint of your guidance, you'd need to average about that 94% for the rest of the year. I'm just wondering if we can take from that, that you're going to much more aggressive on rate in the back half of the year or if that's just some conservatism built into the guidance.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Ernest now. Regarding full year guidance, we'll -- like other's have done, we'll take a look at the half way through the year, because it's perfect to reset guidance at that point based on activity and what were seeing for the rest of the year.
componenttext: This is Ernest now. Regarding full year guidance, we'll -- like other's have done, we'll take a look at the half way through the year, because it's perfect to reset guidance at that point based on activity and what were seeing for the rest of the year. Well address changing full year guidance at that point.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: What do you attribute the record high in renewal rates to? I mean, anecdotally, you've seen less tenants price shopping, are they just more comfortable with their jobs? What are you hearing from them?
componenttext: What do you attribute the record high in renewal rates to? I mean, anecdotally, you've seen less tenants price shopping, are they just more comfortable with their jobs? What are you hearing from them?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the combination. Obviously, some of the changes in the economy and the consumers are coming out. People are feeling a little more comfortable and confident. We work very hard on service and contacts with our residents. We take a lot of initiatives
componenttext: I think the combination. Obviously, some of the changes in the economy and the consumers are coming out. People are feeling a little more comfortable and confident. We work very hard on service and contacts with our residents. We take a lot of initiatives along those lines over the last couple of years. So It's part of a concerted effort to keep them. And so far, it's been successful.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Swett of Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Swett of Morgan Keegan.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: First question for Tim, on the question of redevelopments, can you just talk to the amount of potential redevelopment product that you still have in the portfolio? And just what's the state of the tax credits indication businesses and how that impacts whe
componenttext: First question for Tim, on the question of redevelopments, can you just talk to the amount of potential redevelopment product that you still have in the portfolio? And just what's the state of the tax credits indication businesses and how that impacts whether you're looking at affordable or conventional redevelopments?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: On the redevelopment side, we still have a pretty decent pipeline there. As you know, we've wound that down to basically finishing up some projects. We're currently going through it with Terry right now, somewhere between five and 10 that we think makes s
componenttext: On the redevelopment side, we still have a pretty decent pipeline there. As you know, we've wound that down to basically finishing up some projects. We're currently going through it with Terry right now, somewhere between five and 10 that we think makes some good solid economic sense. We're still fairly cautious about seeing what the economy does and everything that goes along with that. But on an annual basis, I'd say you could see us doing, if things get back to some level of normalcy, back to $50 million to $100 million of capital spend on specific to rebid. And if the market improves beyond that, than we'd go and argue with Terry that we ought to do more of it. So I don't think there's a big issue with that one that -- about [indiscernible] product. This is really  matter of timing and getting comfortable with financing markets. You remember in the past, those things were self financing and that market's a little bit tougher right now. Second issue you brought up had to do with tax credits, and that market continues to be tough from a pricing perspective. The number of people buying, the tax credits has dwindled, and  so the pricing related to that has gone down. Being able to come up with  a capital stack that makes those deals make sense is more challenging today than it's been in the past. So we have a couple that we're going to finish up. We have some more of that could bring to the market if and when that pricing recovers. And so we'll just watch it and see what happens and work our way through it.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: For Terry, in the past you've certainly preferred to pay higher cap rates than lower Cap rates, and your comments on finding better value opportunities. Can you also just talk about how where pricing is today? Does it make you look differently, at which m
componenttext: For Terry, in the past you've certainly preferred to pay higher cap rates than lower Cap rates, and your comments on finding better value opportunities. Can you also just talk about how where pricing is today? Does it make you look differently, at which markets, where you might interested to buy, or is it really just trying to find those better value add opportunities within those markets?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, right now, I would say we're in the process of price discovery and in trying to get a better understanding of what's available. Transaction volumes have been relatively limited. And so there's not a flood of opportunities. And some of them are pric
componenttext: Steve, right now, I would say we're in the process of price discovery and in trying to get a better understanding of what's available. Transaction volumes have been relatively limited. And so there's not a flood of opportunities. And some of them are priced at prices we don't want to pay. We are focusing on the geography that are sold out in our market allocation policies. And so we'd like to increase our weightings to markets we'd like to upgrade our locations. For example, in Boston and New York. So those are the dynamics. Those are markets that are attractive to other people too. And trying to find opportunity there, we're discovering that in many cases, we'll want to take on some additional element of adding value, whether it's in the lease up or construction completion or some other activities that will give us a higher return, for redevelopment from our own portfolio. That's exactly the kind of internal discussions we're having.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Karin Ford of Keybanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Karin Ford of Keybanc.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, just wanted to see if we could get your updated thoughts on the dividend, given now better visibility, better environment, the term loan now down to $35 million. Just If you had any updated thoughts there?
componenttext: Terry, just wanted to see if we could get your updated thoughts on the dividend, given now better visibility, better environment, the term loan now down to $35 million. Just If you had any updated thoughts there?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Karin, you may remember that the last quarter we talked about it and we see that over time, that the dividends is low relative to our profitability. Our practice has been to set it once a year, and the boards sets that and they did in our January meeting,
componenttext: Karin, you may remember that the last quarter we talked about it and we see that over time, that the dividends is low relative to our profitability. Our practice has been to set it once a year, and the boards sets that and they did in our January meeting, so I don't expect to see a change at all in the next few quarters. And going forward beyond that, there will be a balance between the use of profitability for dividend increases and the reduction of property debts that Ernie mentioned in his remarks. And so, built in to our intermediate term forecast that we reviewed with the board earlier this week, we're expecting to give a priority to property debt reduction for the next year or two or three, and to look at dividend increases in that context.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question just relates to Florida. It seems like it's not recovering as fast as some of the other markets are. Can you just talk about what might be holding back Florida as you're looking forward?
componenttext: Second question just relates to Florida. It seems like it's not recovering as fast as some of the other markets are. Can you just talk about what might be holding back Florida as you're looking forward?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, your right. It's not recovering as fast. But there are signs that it is recovering in many of the markets, Orlando being probably the weakest, followed by Jacksonville relative to the last several months. We have fairly high occupancies north of
componenttext: Actually, your right. It's not recovering as fast. But there are signs that it is recovering in many of the markets, Orlando being probably the weakest, followed by Jacksonville relative to the last several months. We have fairly high occupancies north of 95%, except in Orlando. And it's very price sensitive because they're still quite a bit of a shadow market and other opportunities for people to find housing outside of rental. So there's competition. And I think it's just going to take some time to work through that. But we're seeing, again sequentially, we were able to raise rates in most places in Florida as well, from the fourth quarter to the first quarter. So it's slower, more painful but it's kind of inching along.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Salinsky of RBC.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Salinsky of RBC.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: First question, just going back to the operations. you talked about -- you gave detail in the press release about leasing trends and how it had improved in March. Can you talk about renewal and new leasing rates in April as well? Just kind of give us a se
componenttext: First question, just going back to the operations. you talked about -- you gave detail in the press release about leasing trends and how it had improved in March. Can you talk about renewal and new leasing rates in April as well? Just kind of give us a sense of how that's trending?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: We're just closing April but we're trending forward. We continue to make progress. Again, we've made sequential revenue gains. We're very focused on revenue, the rates themselves are relative. You look at last year, we had lower occupancies and a little b
componenttext: We're just closing April but we're trending forward. We continue to make progress. Again, we've made sequential revenue gains. We're very focused on revenue, the rates themselves are relative. You look at last year, we had lower occupancies and a little bit higher rates. And this year, we have both, higher occupancies and some rate improvements. It's just on a year-over-year, I think we've listed new lease rates were down 7%, which was significantly less than a fourth quarter, which was double-digit and we were positive in renewals. So we're positive both in rate and in the percentage of people renewing. So that trend is continuing, and hopefully, it will continue. There's no net gains in the employment picture, so we're cautiously optimistic.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: But is it safe to say that the April trends have been better then March trends?
componenttext: But is it safe to say that the April trends have been better then March trends?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Just given the commentary about cap rates dropping right now, and you guys have been a fairly substantial seller over the past couple of years here. Just curious as to why you're not moving forward? Maybe selling some more. I mean I know the acquisition o
componenttext: Just given the commentary about cap rates dropping right now, and you guys have been a fairly substantial seller over the past couple of years here. Just curious as to why you're not moving forward? Maybe selling some more. I mean I know the acquisition opportunities may not be there, but with pricing coming down, do you chance to maybe you could place it in the proceeds later in the cycle? Why not take advantage of the year-over-year headwinds a little bit more?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Terry. First as part of our basic plan, we are selling in the magnitude of $300 million of assets this year. So to that extent we're taking advantage of that. We're selling off the bottom of our portfolio, we're getting very attractive fr
componenttext: Michael, this is Terry. First as part of our basic plan, we are selling in the magnitude of $300 million of assets this year. So to that extent we're taking advantage of that. We're selling off the bottom of our portfolio, we're getting very attractive free cash flow internal rate of return pricing on that. Second, we talked about maybe expanding it. But I'm not attracted to is selling properties to hold cash with an unclear use of proceeds. And so our further sales will be connected to our expected use of proceeds.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010

componenttext: Mike, just if I could go add to what Tony had to say because there's sort of a sub text here that I'd like to clarify. And that is what's happening in apartment market as far as rental revenue and pricing? I just want to be clear. Our first quarter is up over our fourth quarter. Our February is better than our January. Our March was better than our February. Our April was better than our March. Our renewal rates have gone positive. Our new lease rate, which are negative, are less negative. Things are going the right direction and we're just cautious about getting ahead of ourselves.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Those are exactly the right questions and so we're thinking about them just as you've mentioned. But our thinking about our cost of equity would not be as current return. They would be what our expected IRR would be over time. And so when we look at our p
componenttext: Those are exactly the right questions and so we're thinking about them just as you've mentioned. But our thinking about our cost of equity would not be as current return. They would be what our expected IRR would be over time. And so when we look at our preferred, we think we might well refund our Series G at a lower cost, but we're not -- with a new issuance of preferred. But again, we're not attracted to issuing common equity to invest in levered equities at returns in our preferred to the average of 8%. We think our equity is commanding a higher rate return as is.

componenttext: I would tell you that in general terms we're marketing properties individually. We're taking them out through our typical process, is to solicit multiple broker depending to value. We will interview and select a broker based upon their particular qualifications. But generally speaking, particularly on the conventional side, we're selling on one off. componenttext: I might add to that. This is Tim again, and John alluded to it, but we tend to list properties for sale. We like the option process in a rising market like what we're seeing right now with the amount of capital chasing deals. We like the idea of finding out how aggressive people will get in this market. And so almost exclusively, there's always an exception here or there. We are listing properties and working through the option process.

componenttext: Our next question is from Joe Gagan of Atlantic Equity Research.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: The first question is, the  unemployment rates are close to what they were at the peak and the Apartment business really started to fall in the third quarter of '09, which was later than other industries. So my question is, you've said many times that thi
componenttext: The first question is, the  unemployment rates are close to what they were at the peak and the Apartment business really started to fall in the third quarter of '09, which was later than other industries. So my question is, you've said many times that things are improving sequentially quarter-by-quarter, but the employment rates are near the highs, right? And the  number of people who are long-term unemployed is at records, which I think would adversely affect the apartment industry. People moving back to home with their parents or moving back with friends. So although companies like Intel and Apple have done very well and a lot of companies with international businesses have done well, your tenants are not the CEO of Intel, right? So I'm just wondering why you think, given the regular people in America aren't doing better, that things are getting better for you?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, this is Terry Considine. I think you're exactly right to point to the high levels of unemployment, the high levels of underemployment, the high levels of discouraged workers. If you wanted to bring it closer to home in the Real Estate business, it'd
componenttext: Joe, this is Terry Considine. I think you're exactly right to point to the high levels of unemployment, the high levels of underemployment, the high levels of discouraged workers. If you wanted to bring it closer to home in the Real Estate business, it'd also be fair to point out that there's still a considerable inventory of single-family homes to be foreclosed and moved through the process that are being absorbed. So those are negative facts. The positive facts are that the demographics are quite strong. and that the number of youngsters between 21 to 34, which is the primary pool of apartment renters, is a very large number compared to previous age cohorts. In other words, if you look at the number of people that were born in 1980, who would be 30 today, and the number of people that were born in 1975, as you drop off the older group and bought their own housing, there's a significant increase in rentals demand.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: So you're advocating that there's an increase in the 22 to 34 that became that age between January and April of 2010 compared to what it was in September?
componenttext: So you're advocating that there's an increase in the 22 to 34 that became that age between January and April of 2010 compared to what it was in September?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010

componenttext: That would be a very precise indication. I think that the general reason why we've gone through this entire recession with much lower declines in occupancies and property incomes is because of that very strong demographic demand.

componenttext: But my question was specifically this, is that the economy hasn't got better for regular people. And the unemployment rates haven't fallen, yet you and other people in the apartment industry have pounded the table, saying that rental prices got better between January and now. I'm just wondering, why would that be when your tenants don't have -- the number of them having jobs hasn't increased, the number of them -- their level income hasn't increased. Why do you think that is?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I'll try it again. I think there's a large number of employed people in our target ages. I think they're confident has improved. I think many people feel the economy bottomed perhaps three quarters ago. We've had three quarters of positive growth tha
componenttext: Joe, I'll try it again. I think there's a large number of employed people in our target ages. I think they're confident has improved. I think many people feel the economy bottomed perhaps three quarters ago. We've had three quarters of positive growth that will add to confidence. And so the employed members of our target markets, I think, feel more upbeat. Let me just cut through this because I may not know the right answer. But I do know what happened and the fact is that we are highly occupied and our revenues are up quarter-over-quarter, month-over-month and are positive in our Renewal business. And I'm not out here beating the drums trying to talk to you into believing about the future. I'm just telling you what's already happened through the end of April.
