componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michelle Ko of Bank of America.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering, given the positive commentary of some of your peers over the last couple of days, we were somewhat surprised that you weren't more enthusiastic and didn't increase your 2010 Same Store guidance. I was just wondering, does this pertai
componenttext: I was just wondering, given the positive commentary of some of your peers over the last couple of days, we were somewhat surprised that you weren't more enthusiastic and didn't increase your 2010 Same Store guidance. I was just wondering, does this pertain because of AIV's lower price points, which might not be as volatile as some of the higher price points and you might not see as much upside during the recovery?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michelle this is Ernie, I'd be happy to address that. First, I'd like to point out that we were pleased with how it came out in the first quarter. We did perform a little bit better than guidance range. Then I would also point out that when you look at th
componenttext: Michelle this is Ernie, I'd be happy to address that. First, I'd like to point out that we were pleased with how it came out in the first quarter. We did perform a little bit better than guidance range. Then I would also point out that when you look at the range of any of the company's put out at the beginning of the year, we were at the higher end of those ranges. We feel very comfortable to keep our guidance at that point. And so I wouldn't take it as a view of that we're not enthusiastic. When you talk about where we think the market is and how it's performing, we feel very comfortable that we're going to be able to perform within the range that we've laid out for the rest of the year.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: And then could you also just comment on which markets you think are deteriorating or recovering faster than what you had expected? And which markets were you might see job growth come back first?
componenttext: And then could you also just comment on which markets you think are deteriorating or recovering faster than what you had expected? And which markets were you might see job growth come back first?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michelle, I'll ask Tony D'Alto to address that.
componenttext: Michelle, I'll ask Tony D'Alto to address that.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the good news is that we're basically seeing recovery in most markets. It's relative of course. Places like Phoenix and Miami less so relative to rate increases, but are doing fairly well. I'd point out that we only have two markets in our entire po
componenttext: Well, the good news is that we're basically seeing recovery in most markets. It's relative of course. Places like Phoenix and Miami less so relative to rate increases, but are doing fairly well. I'd point out that we only have two markets in our entire portfolio that's below 95%. So I think that the Coast of course where we're seeing the Northeast and Southern California and pretty much every place outside of Phoenix and Florida were very highly occupied and we've taken rate increases to the first quarter. And we feel very comfortable that we'll be pretty well set up for the summer season. So in total, we're seeing it across the board, it's just relative levels of strength depending on the market.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess when do you expect to see Same Store revenue growth year-over-year and also sequentially?
componenttext: I guess when do you expect to see Same Store revenue growth year-over-year and also sequentially?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michelle, this is Ernie. I can address that. Based on the guidance numbers that we provided for the second quarter and then doing the math in the second half of the year, so there is a possibility within our guidance range, that we can see that coming up
componenttext: Michelle, this is Ernie. I can address that. Based on the guidance numbers that we provided for the second quarter and then doing the math in the second half of the year, so there is a possibility within our guidance range, that we can see that coming up in the second half of the year. Sequentially, we did see revenue growth from the fourth quarter to the first quarter. Year-over-year, I think you'll be seeing it some time, based on the math, that there's a possibility you'll see that in the second half of the year.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jay Habermann of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jay Habermann of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the difference between the performance of As and Bs. And Terry, you made reference to obviously AIMCO when compared, the company to some of your peers, but I'm just curious, as you're continuing to see the cap rates widen out between As
componenttext: Just going back to the difference between the performance of As and Bs. And Terry, you made reference to obviously AIMCO when compared, the company to some of your peers, but I'm just curious, as you're continuing to see the cap rates widen out between As and Bs? I mean, do you feel that the expectations for rent growth from the more Class A assets are just getting too high at this point, in terms of growth over the next two or three years?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that the asset pricing is more optimistic than the data providers' rent projection. And that gives rise to which of the two is right. It could be that rates will grow faster, that rental rates will grow faster. And if so, that will be because of e
componenttext: I think that the asset pricing is more optimistic than the data providers' rent projection. And that gives rise to which of the two is right. It could be that rates will grow faster, that rental rates will grow faster. And if so, that will be because of either real demand recovery in the job markets in this time of very limited supply or it'll be because of the monetary inflation creeping into the economy. For the moment, I think we have to wait and see.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the reason I asked is as I think about AIMCO, you referenced at your Analyst Day that markets such as New York and Boston and San Francisco, where you have below-average rents versus the market, I mean, do you expect your portfolio to maintain the
componenttext: I guess the reason I asked is as I think about AIMCO, you referenced at your Analyst Day that markets such as New York and Boston and San Francisco, where you have below-average rents versus the market, I mean, do you expect your portfolio to maintain the same rent growth as, say, that of your peers, similarly positioned in those markets?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I think in those markets, benchmarking against the market, we expect rent growth to be in comparable to or similar to that of the market. I wouldn't go through in benchmark against specific peers without looking at their exact properties.
componenttext: I think in those markets, benchmarking against the market, we expect rent growth to be in comparable to or similar to that of the market. I wouldn't go through in benchmark against specific peers without looking at their exact properties.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, the question on asset sales, can you give us a sense of the dollar amount that your looking at? I mean, you mentioned the number of properties but what potentially dollar amount you -- or currently have listed today? And then I guess
componenttext: And then just lastly, the question on asset sales, can you give us a sense of the dollar amount that your looking at? I mean, you mentioned the number of properties but what potentially dollar amount you -- or currently have listed today? And then I guess in contrast, what are you looking at in terms of acquisition opportunities and the spread between where you're selling and where you potentially will be buying?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: We've talked about in our today's guidance, I don't recall whether we gave guidance to it, but that we would sell probably $300 million in assets and generate $100 million in cash or corporate purposes primarily repayment of the term debt. And that's well
componenttext: We've talked about in our today's guidance, I don't recall whether we gave guidance to it, but that we would sell probably $300 million in assets and generate $100 million in cash or corporate purposes primarily repayment of the term debt. And that's well underway, as Tim mentioned in his remarks. Going forward, further sales will be connected to our opportunity to reinvest the proceeds on a accretive basis, either in acquisitions or redevelopment. And in looking at that, we don't focus as much on NOI cap rates or NOI differences as we do on free cash flow internal rates of return, and we would expect that it would be accretive and not diluted.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: But you talked about asset sales being offset by acquisitions? It sounds like maybe perhaps that could be shifting toward Redevelopment? Is that sort of the direction you're moving?
componenttext: But you talked about asset sales being offset by acquisitions? It sounds like maybe perhaps that could be shifting toward Redevelopment? Is that sort of the direction you're moving?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: We're looking at both. It just really goes back to your first question that some acquisitions are priced at a level that's not attractive to us. And that will lead us to more value-added activities like redevelopment, after we will require a higher spread
componenttext: We're looking at both. It just really goes back to your first question that some acquisitions are priced at a level that's not attractive to us. And that will lead us to more value-added activities like redevelopment, after we will require a higher spread, then it would be available from the acquisition activity. But we're also seeing some interesting acquisition opportunities. We'll just going to have to play them out, which of those we do.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jeff Donnelly of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jeff Donnelly of Wells Fargo.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little about maybe what's happened subsequent to quarter end as it relates to your revenues? Have you seen trends retreat, hold or accelerate?
componenttext: Can you talk a little about maybe what's happened subsequent to quarter end as it relates to your revenues? Have you seen trends retreat, hold or accelerate?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: We are actually holding quite well. As a matter of fact, April will have a higher occupancy than March. And in terms of revenues, we're right where we anticipate we would be.
componenttext: We are actually holding quite well. As a matter of fact, April will have a higher occupancy than March. And in terms of revenues, we're right where we anticipate we would be.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Does the continued improvement in occupancy lead you to think that maybe you ought to be getting more aggressive on rents sooner or...
componenttext: Does the continued improvement in occupancy lead you to think that maybe you ought to be getting more aggressive on rents sooner or...

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've actually been taking rate actions and obviously increased occupancies will give us more opportunities to do more of that as we move forward.
componenttext: Yes, we've actually been taking rate actions and obviously increased occupancies will give us more opportunities to do more of that as we move forward.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: And just on the expense side, we have the revenue certainly coming back, how do you think about your expenses as being rolled forward in 2010 and '11? Or is there anything that stands out to you as an area that could come back a little quicker than [indis
componenttext: And just on the expense side, we have the revenue certainly coming back, how do you think about your expenses as being rolled forward in 2010 and '11? Or is there anything that stands out to you as an area that could come back a little quicker than [indiscernible]?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: By the way, this is Tony, Jeff. We remain very focused on expenses. And as you could see from our reporting, the major material impact in our increase was based on weather. Everything else was a function of the timing or source of other expenditures in di
componenttext: By the way, this is Tony, Jeff. We remain very focused on expenses. And as you could see from our reporting, the major material impact in our increase was based on weather. Everything else was a function of the timing or source of other expenditures in different markets. We expect to be right within what we plan to be, which is baked into our guidance.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you guys describe yourself as a B/B+ owner of apartments but by that, I think, the definition you guys published, where your rents stand versus your competitive set, will actually put you at something closer to a B-, if you will, not to put hairs,
componenttext: I think you guys describe yourself as a B/B+ owner of apartments but by that, I think, the definition you guys published, where your rents stand versus your competitive set, will actually put you at something closer to a B-, if you will, not to put hairs, but if the goal is to move towards that B+ level, I suspect that means selling out of more assets. Is there a theme towards the majority of those assets, the ones that might drag you down a little bit? Is there a theme to where they reside maybe geographically?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, this is Ernie. We're always will be calling our portfolio a little bit, fell of the bottom, and that should continue to improve. Our rents are certainly local market averages. After the fourth quarter reported in our more recent supplementals, on th
componenttext: Jeff, this is Ernie. We're always will be calling our portfolio a little bit, fell of the bottom, and that should continue to improve. Our rents are certainly local market averages. After the fourth quarter reported in our more recent supplementals, on the fourth quarter, in the most recent supplementals here that we're about 103% on local market averages. In our view, we view the assets somewhere between 90 and 125. So over time, we will expect the 103% to continue to improve and maybe get closer to 105% to 110%. In terms of where those assets are, they're generally located in our non-target markets. We will continue to focus our sales efforts on the bottom of the portfolio, as well as our non-target markets to improve our standing against local market averages.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: There may be a math on this, but I would think that like in your target markets, which I assume are sort of large in urban markets that the gap between the, I call it, the high end of the market and the low end of the market in rent will be fairly wide to
componenttext: There may be a math on this, but I would think that like in your target markets, which I assume are sort of large in urban markets that the gap between the, I call it, the high end of the market and the low end of the market in rent will be fairly wide to the point being that you could very easily be, and I guess call it, below the mean in that market but still have pretty high rents, if you will, in absolute terms. It's better than like a more, I guess, secondary market. I guess I would assume that the gap between the high and low rent would be pretty tight, so it will be easy to be at the mean or above. Does that logic make sense? I mean I guess the question is, is there a chance that as you exit secondary markets, you'll actually solidify your position as like a more B- portfolio?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, based on our numbers that we presented at our Investor Day, our non-target markets are right on top of local market 100% to 101%, at Investor Day, we reported that we were at 104% for the entire portfolio. At least ours are [ph] (28:25) such a gap t
componenttext: Well, based on our numbers that we presented at our Investor Day, our non-target markets are right on top of local market 100% to 101%, at Investor Day, we reported that we were at 104% for the entire portfolio. At least ours are [ph] (28:25) such a gap that, that complicated the theory. Could that potentially work out for someone else's portfolio? Possibly, but then as you see [ph] (28:32) the benchmark portfolio check.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mike Levy of Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mike Levy of Macquarie.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a bit about the strategy with the term loan. If the capital markets are as open as they seem, and the assets that you may sell to pay off the term loan is generating decent cash flow and the loan isn't due for another yea
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a bit about the strategy with the term loan. If the capital markets are as open as they seem, and the assets that you may sell to pay off the term loan is generating decent cash flow and the loan isn't due for another year and presumably prices are going to do nothing but continue to rise, at least for the assets that you're selling, why sell now? Why not just wait until later in the year when pricing is better and sell then?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Terry. Our policy is not to have recourse debt. And the term loan was an exception to that. It was a mistake on my part, and I just want to get rid of it. It will be paid off in the next month or two or three. And at that point, we'll hav
componenttext: Michael, this is Terry. Our policy is not to have recourse debt. And the term loan was an exception to that. It was a mistake on my part, and I just want to get rid of it. It will be paid off in the next month or two or three. And at that point, we'll have a very low cost, very long-dated and attractive [indiscernible].

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to home in on the earlier question, obviously, rents seem to be rising. I was wondering if you guys have seen any slowdown in rental rates in the past couple of weeks and that the pace at which rents seem to be rising, that is?
componenttext: Just to home in on the earlier question, obviously, rents seem to be rising. I was wondering if you guys have seen any slowdown in rental rates in the past couple of weeks and that the pace at which rents seem to be rising, that is?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: No. In a word.
componenttext: No. In a word.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: At the Investor Day about 10 weeks ago, Ernie mentioned that he thought an appropriate entity was around $20, I think. With that in mind and given the current share price, do you guys have any view about an equity offering and what you might use the proce
componenttext: At the Investor Day about 10 weeks ago, Ernie mentioned that he thought an appropriate entity was around $20, I think. With that in mind and given the current share price, do you guys have any view about an equity offering and what you might use the proceeds for?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, this Ernie. That's exactly the right point in. What is the use of proceeds? Specific -- the NAV discussion we had at Investor Day when we presented an NAV based on just September 31, where we thought values were. And I think most people think tha
componenttext: Michael, this Ernie. That's exactly the right point in. What is the use of proceeds? Specific -- the NAV discussion we had at Investor Day when we presented an NAV based on just September 31, where we thought values were. And I think most people think that up from the Street, the values could be up, say 5% that is year end. And so that being the case, in doing the math, our NAV would be plus or minus $3 higher than where we were before. That said, you raised a key point,  Michael, in use of proceeds. So I think the answer is, if there's an attractive use of proceeds and it makes the most sense for our shareholders and it's not going to be dilutive, we would definitely consider equity.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you looking at assets to acquire? I think you sort of touched on this earlier. Has there been anything that has come to market, for which you would possibly bid?
componenttext: Are you looking at assets to acquire? I think you sort of touched on this earlier. Has there been anything that has come to market, for which you would possibly bid?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Terry. Generally, we have seen the assets that have come to market and have had the opportunity to bid. We are looking at possible acquisition and we'll see how they turn out. Most likely, they will be funded by proceeds from sale of our
componenttext: Michael, this is Terry. Generally, we have seen the assets that have come to market and have had the opportunity to bid. We are looking at possible acquisition and we'll see how they turn out. Most likely, they will be funded by proceeds from sale of our lower-rated assets. So that in terms of acquisition volumes, if we were to acquire a $300 million of assets, that would be funded by $300 million of sales of lower-rated properties currently in our portfolio.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you seeing -- I know that obviously, it seems like there's more Class A assets that are coming on to the market and the bidding process for those is intensely competitive, but in past conversations, I think you had mentioned that you might be looking
componenttext: Are you seeing -- I know that obviously, it seems like there's more Class A assets that are coming on to the market and the bidding process for those is intensely competitive, but in past conversations, I think you had mentioned that you might be looking at something not in the Class A area. So are you seeing opportunities in the class B+ or A- areas? And is the acquisition environment as competitive in that section or in that corner of the market?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, you're making a very good point. There's a certain amount of histrionics that gets into these calls. Every part of the business is competitive. And whether it's true for B assets or A assets or C assets, whether it's true for value added by loans
componenttext: Michael, you're making a very good point. There's a certain amount of histrionics that gets into these calls. Every part of the business is competitive. And whether it's true for B assets or A assets or C assets, whether it's true for value added by loans, discounts and so forth. It's a very efficient, very liquid, very competitive market.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Eric Wolfe of Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question is from Eric Wolfe of Citigroup.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to piggyback back off that equity raise question, if you were to raise today, do you know how much property that you could prepay without incurring a penalty?
componenttext: Just to piggyback back off that equity raise question, if you were to raise today, do you know how much property that you could prepay without incurring a penalty?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, we wouldn't be interested to raise equity to pay off property that which has a weighted average maturity of almost nine years at a weighted average cost of sub-6%. That wouldn't be attractive at all.
componenttext: Eric, we wouldn't be interested to raise equity to pay off property that which has a weighted average maturity of almost nine years at a weighted average cost of sub-6%. That wouldn't be attractive at all.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as your occupancy, it's pretty high right now. Looks like your expectations for the second quarter is an average of 95.5%. So to meet that midpoint of your guidance, you'd need to average about 94% for the rest of the year. I'm just wondering if we
componenttext: As far as your occupancy, it's pretty high right now. Looks like your expectations for the second quarter is an average of 95.5%. So to meet that midpoint of your guidance, you'd need to average about 94% for the rest of the year. I'm just wondering if we can take from that, that you're going to be much more aggressive on rate in the back half of the year or if that's just some conservatism built into the guidance?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Ernie now. I can address that Eric. Regarding full year guidance, we'll -- like others have done, we'll take a look at the half way through the year, and it's appropriate to reset guidance at that point based on activity and what were seeing fo
componenttext: This is Ernie now. I can address that Eric. Regarding full year guidance, we'll -- like others have done, we'll take a look at the half way through the year, and it's appropriate to reset guidance at that point based on activity and what were seeing for the rest of the year. Well address changing full year guidance at that point.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: What do you attribute the record high in renewal rates to? I mean, anecdotally, you've seen less tenants price shopping, are they just more comfortable with their jobs? What are you hearing from them?
componenttext: What do you attribute the record high in renewal rates to? I mean, anecdotally, you've seen less tenants price shopping, are they just more comfortable with their jobs? What are you hearing from them?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a combination. I think, Obviously some of the changes in the economy and the consumers are coming out. People are feeling a little more comfortable and confident. We work very hard on service and contacts with our residents. We take a lot of
componenttext: I think it's a combination. I think, Obviously some of the changes in the economy and the consumers are coming out. People are feeling a little more comfortable and confident. We work very hard on service and contacts with our residents. We take a lot of initiatives along those lines over the last couple of years. So it's part of a concerted effort to keep them. And so far, it's been successful.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Swett of Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Swett of Morgan Keegan.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: First question for Tim, on the question of redevelopments, can you just talk to the amount of potential redevelopment product that you still have in the portfolio? And just what the state of the Tax Credit Syndication business is and how that impacts whet
componenttext: First question for Tim, on the question of redevelopments, can you just talk to the amount of potential redevelopment product that you still have in the portfolio? And just what the state of the Tax Credit Syndication business is and how that impacts whether you're looking at Affordable or Conventional redevelopments?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: On the Redevelopment side, we still have a pretty decent pipeline there. As you know, we've wound that down to basically finishing up some projects. We're currently going through it with Terry right now, somewhere between five and 10 that we think makes s
componenttext: On the Redevelopment side, we still have a pretty decent pipeline there. As you know, we've wound that down to basically finishing up some projects. We're currently going through it with Terry right now, somewhere between five and 10 that we think makes some good solid economic sense. We're still fairly cautious about seeing what the economy does and everything that goes along with that. But on an annual basis, I'd say you could see us doing, if things get back to some level of normalcy, back to $50 million to $100 million of capital spend on specific to rebid. And if the market improve beyond that, than we'd go and argue with Terry that we ought to do more of it. So I don't think there's a big issue with that one that -- about having product. This is really matter of timing and getting comfortable with financing markets. You remember in the past, those things were self financing and that market's a little bit tougher right now. Second issue you brought up had to do with tax credits, and that market continues to be tough from a pricing perspective. The number of people buying, the tax credits has dwindled, and  so the pricing related to that has gone down. Being able to come up with a capital stack that makes all the deals make sense is more challenging today than had been in the past. So we have a couple that we're going to finish up. We have some more that we could bring to the market if and when that pricing recovers. And so we'll just watch it and see what happens and work our way through it.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: For Terry, I know in the past you've certainly preferred to pay higher cap rates than lower Cap rates, and your comments on finding, I guess, better value opportunities. Can you also just talk about how, where pricing is today? Does it make you look diffe
componenttext: For Terry, I know in the past you've certainly preferred to pay higher cap rates than lower Cap rates, and your comments on finding, I guess, better value opportunities. Can you also just talk about how, where pricing is today? Does it make you look differently at which markets, where you might be interested to buy, or is it really just trying to find those better value add opportunities within those markets?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, right now, I would say we're in the process of price discovery, and in trying to get a better understanding of what's available. Transaction volumes have been relatively limited. And so there's not a flood of opportunities. And some of them are pri
componenttext: Steve, right now, I would say we're in the process of price discovery, and in trying to get a better understanding of what's available. Transaction volumes have been relatively limited. And so there's not a flood of opportunities. And some of them are priced at prices we don't want to pay. We are focusing on the geography that are spelled out in our market allocation policies. And so we'd like to increase our weightings to markets we'd like to upgrade our locations. For example, in Boston and New York. So those are the dynamics. Those are markets that are attractive to other people, too. And in trying to find opportunity there, we're discovering that in many cases, we'll want to take on some additional element of adding value, whether it's in the lease up or construction completion or some other activities that will give us a higher return, for Redevelopment from our own portfolio. That's exactly the kind of internal discussions we're having.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Karin Ford of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Karin Ford of KeyBanc.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, just wanted to see if we could get your updated thoughts on the dividend, given now better visibility, better environment, the term loan now down to $35 million. Just If you had any updated thoughts there?
componenttext: Terry, just wanted to see if we could get your updated thoughts on the dividend, given now better visibility, better environment, the term loan now down to $35 million. Just If you had any updated thoughts there?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Karin, you may remember that the last quarter we talked about it and we see that over time, that the dividends is low relative to our profitability. Our practice has been to set it once a year, and the board sets that and they did in our January meeting,
componenttext: Karin, you may remember that the last quarter we talked about it and we see that over time, that the dividends is low relative to our profitability. Our practice has been to set it once a year, and the board sets that and they did in our January meeting, so I don't expect to see a change at all in the next few quarters. And going forward beyond that, there will be a balance between the use of profitability for dividend increases and the reduction of property debt that Ernie mentioned in his remarks. And so, built in to our intermediate-term forecast that we reviewed with the board earlier this week, we're expecting to give a priority to property debt reduction for the next year or two or three, and to look at dividend increases in that context.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Second question just relates to Florida. It seems like it's not recovering as fast as some of the other markets are. Can you just talk about what might be holding back Florida as you're looking forward?
componenttext: Second question just relates to Florida. It seems like it's not recovering as fast as some of the other markets are. Can you just talk about what might be holding back Florida as you're looking forward?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, you're right. It's not recovering as fast. But there are signs that it is recovering in many of the markets, Orlando being probably the weakest, followed by Jacksonville relative to the last several months. We have fairly high occupancies north
componenttext: Actually, you're right. It's not recovering as fast. But there are signs that it is recovering in many of the markets, Orlando being probably the weakest, followed by Jacksonville relative to the last several months. We have fairly high occupancies north of 95%, except in Orlando. And it's very price sensitive because there's still quite a bit of a shadow market and other opportunities for people to find housing outside of rental. So there's competition. And I think it's just going to take some time to work through that. But we're seeing, again sequentially, we were able to raise rates in most places in Florida as well, from the fourth quarter to the first quarter. So it's slower, more painful but it's kind of inching along.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Salinsky of RBC.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Salinsky of RBC.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: First question, just going back to the operations. you talked about -- you gave detail in the press release about leasing trends and how it had improved in March. Can you talk about renewal and new leasing rates in April as well, just kind of give us a se
componenttext: First question, just going back to the operations. you talked about -- you gave detail in the press release about leasing trends and how it had improved in March. Can you talk about renewal and new leasing rates in April as well, just kind of give us a sense of how that's trending?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're just closing April but we're trending forward. We continue to make progress. Again, we've made sequential revenue gains. We're very focused on revenue, the rates themselves are relative. You look at last year, we had lower occupancies and a li
componenttext: Well, we're just closing April but we're trending forward. We continue to make progress. Again, we've made sequential revenue gains. We're very focused on revenue, the rates themselves are relative. You look at last year, we had lower occupancies and a little bit higher rates. And this year, we have both, higher occupancies and some rate improvements. It's just on a year-over-year, I think we've listed new lease rates were down 7%, which was significantly less than fourth quarter, which was double-digit and we were positive in renewals. So we're positive both in rate and in the percentage of people renewing. So that trend is continuing, and hopefully, it will continue. There's no net gains in the employment picture, so we're cautiously optimistic.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: But is it safe to say that the April trends have been better than March trends?
componenttext: But is it safe to say that the April trends have been better than March trends?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Just given the commentary about cap rates dropping right now, and you guys have been a fairly substantial seller over the past couple of years here, just curious as to why you're not moving forward? Maybe selling some more, I mean I know the acquisition o
componenttext: Just given the commentary about cap rates dropping right now, and you guys have been a fairly substantial seller over the past couple of years here, just curious as to why you're not moving forward? Maybe selling some more, I mean I know the acquisition opportunities may not be there, but with pricing coming down, do you chance to maybe you could place it in the proceeds later in the cycle? I mean why not take advantage of the year-over-year headwinds a little bit more?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, Terry. First as part of our basic plan, we are selling in the magnitude of $300 million of assets this year. So to that extent we're taking advantage of that, we're selling off the bottom of our portfolio, we were getting very attractive free cas
componenttext: Michael, Terry. First as part of our basic plan, we are selling in the magnitude of $300 million of assets this year. So to that extent we're taking advantage of that, we're selling off the bottom of our portfolio, we were getting very attractive free cash flow internal rate of return pricing on that. Second, we talked about maybe expanding it. What I'm not attracted to is selling properties to hold cash with an unclear use of proceeds. And so our further sales will be connected to our expected use of proceeds. Mike, just if I could go add to what Tony had to say because there's sort of a subtext here that I'd like to clarify. And that is what's happening in apartment market as far as rental revenue and pricing. I just want to be clear. Our first quarter is up over our fourth quarter. Our February is better than our January. Our March was better than our February. Our April was better than our March. I've got to get these months straight. Our renewal rates have gone positive. Our new lease rate, which are negative, are less negative. Things are going the right direction and we're just cautious about getting ahead of ourselves.

componenttextpreview: I'd like to go back to the equities for just one second. Considering the run price stock this year, notwithstanding today's performance, how does the buyback of the preferred sit into your thought process, given a cost of equity somewhere in the mid to hi
componenttext: I'd like to go back to the equities for just one second. Considering the run price stock this year, notwithstanding today's performance, how does the buyback of the preferred sit into your thought process, given a cost of equity somewhere in the mid to high fives and the preferred yielding price somewhere in the eights?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Haendel, those are exactly the right questions, and so we're thinking about them just as you've mentioned. But our thinking about our cost of equity would not be as current return. It would be what our expected IRR would be over time. And so when we
componenttext: Well, Haendel, those are exactly the right questions, and so we're thinking about them just as you've mentioned. But our thinking about our cost of equity would not be as current return. It would be what our expected IRR would be over time. And so when we look at our preferred, we think we might well refund our Series G at a lower cost, but we're not -- with a new issuance of preferred, but again, we're not attracted to issuing common equity to invest in levered equities at returns in our preferred to the average of 8%. We think our equity is commanding a higher rate return as is.

componenttext: I would tell you that in general terms we're marketing properties individually. We're taking them out through our typical process, is to solicit multiple broker depending to value. We will interview and select a broker based upon their particular qualifications. But generally speaking, particularly on the Conventional side, we're selling on one off. We do have a couple of small portfolios on the Affordable side right now that had been marketed as such and that are tied up as such right now. But these are not big meaningful portfolios, if you will, to the bottom line.

componenttext: I might add to that. This is Tim again, and John alluded to it, but we tend to list properties for sale. We like the option process in a rising market like we're seeing right now with the amount of capital chasing deals. We like the idea of finding out how aggressive people will get in this market. And so almost exclusively, there's always an exception here or there. We are listing properties and working through the option process.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Joe Gagan of Atlantic Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Joe Gagan of Atlantic Equity Research.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: The first question is, the  unemployment rates are close to what they were at the peak and the Apartment business really started to fall in the third quarter of '09, which was later than other industries. So my question is, you've said many times that thi
componenttext: The first question is, the  unemployment rates are close to what they were at the peak and the Apartment business really started to fall in the third quarter of '09, which was later than other industries. So my question is, you've said many times that things are improving sequentially quarter-by-quarter, but the unemployment rates are near the highs, right? And the number of people who are long-term unemployed is at records, which I think would adversely affect the apartment industry. People moving back at home with their parents or moving back with friends. So although companies like Intel and Apple have done very well and a lot of companies with international businesses have done well, your tenants are not the CEO of Intel, right? So I'm just wondering why you think, given the regular people in America aren't doing better, that things are getting better for you?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, this is Terry Considine. I'll take a crack at it. I think you're exactly right to point to the high levels of unemployment, the high levels of underemployment, the high levels of discouraged workers. If you wanted to bring it closer to home in the Re
componenttext: Joe, this is Terry Considine. I'll take a crack at it. I think you're exactly right to point to the high levels of unemployment, the high levels of underemployment, the high levels of discouraged workers. If you wanted to bring it closer to home in the Real Estate business, it'd also be fair to point out that there's still a considerable inventory of single-family homes to be foreclosed and moved through the process that are being absorbed. So those are negative facts. The positive facts are that the demographics are quite strong. And that the number of youngsters between 21 and 34, which is the primary pool of apartment renters, is a very large number compared to previous age cohorts. In other words, if you look at the number of people that were born in 1980, who would be 30 today, and the number of people that were born in 1975, as you drop off the older group and they bought their own housing, there's a significant increase in rentals demand.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: So you're advocating that there's an increase in the 22 to 34 that became that age between January and April of 2010 compared to what it was in September?
componenttext: So you're advocating that there's an increase in the 22 to 34 that became that age between January and April of 2010 compared to what it was in September?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that would be a very precise indication. I think that the general reason why we've gone through this entire recession with much lower declines in occupancies and property incomes is because of that very strong demographic demand.
componenttext: Well, that would be a very precise indication. I think that the general reason why we've gone through this entire recession with much lower declines in occupancies and property incomes is because of that very strong demographic demand.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: But my question was specifically this, is that the economy hasn't got better for regular people, and the unemployment rates haven't fallen, yet you and other people in the apartment industry have pounded the table, saying that rental prices got better bet
componenttext: But my question was specifically this, is that the economy hasn't got better for regular people, and the unemployment rates haven't fallen, yet you and other people in the apartment industry have pounded the table, saying that rental prices got better between January and now. I'm just wondering, why would that be when your tenants don't have -- the number of them having jobs hasn't increased, the number of them -- their level of income hasn't increased, why do you think that is?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I'll try it again. I think there's a large number of employed people in our target ages. I think their confidence has improved. I think many people feel the economy bottomed perhaps three quarters ago. We've had three quarters of positive growth that
componenttext: Joe, I'll try it again. I think there's a large number of employed people in our target ages. I think their confidence has improved. I think many people feel the economy bottomed perhaps three quarters ago. We've had three quarters of positive growth that will add to the confidence. And so the employed members of our target markets, I think, feel more upbeat. Let me just cut through this because I may not know the right answer, but I do know what happened and the fact is that we are highly occupied and our revenues are up quarter-over-quarter, month-over-month and are positive in our Renewal business. And I'm not out here beating the drums trying to talk to you into believing about the future. I'm just telling you what's already happened through the end of April.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2010 Apartment Investment & Management Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrea, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] And now, I'd like to turn the presentat
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2010 Apartment Investment & Management Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrea, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] And now, I'd like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and General Counsel. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrea. Good morning, and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and u
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrea. Good morning, and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. Also, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures, such as funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on AIMCO's website. 
The participants on today's call will be Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO, who will provide opening remarks; Tim Beaudin, AIMCO's President and Chief Operating Officer, who'll speak to property operations and capital recycling activities; and Ernie Freedman, our CFO, who'll review second quarter financial results, debt capital market's activity and guidance for the third quarter and full year 2010. I will now turn the call to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in AIMCO. On today's call, my colleagues and I will discuss second quarter results, give an update on our balance sheet and provide some comments about what we see as we look forward
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in AIMCO. On today's call, my colleagues and I will discuss second quarter results, give an update on our balance sheet and provide some comments about what we see as we look forward. 
First, our business is improving. Average daily occupancy is high. Renewal rates have been positive since February. During the second quarter, new lease rates were positive in several markets for the first time in more than a year. We expect total portfolio net operating income to be just about break-even with last year for all of 2010, and we project same-store net operating income to be about break-even for the second half of 2010. Second, our balance sheet is improving. We repaid the balance in our term debt earlier this week, leaving us with no recourse debt. 
Looking forward, we are cautious. The economy continues to recover, but the pace of recovery is slowing. Apartment demand will be better than the general economy because the demographics are attractive and because home ownership is not. And this demand will drive rent growth because apartment supply is expected to be fairly positive over the next few years. However, unsustainable federal deficits and expansive legislative agendas mean that wrenching change lies ahead with unpredictable consequences. In the face of these uncertainties, we remain focused on serving our residents and keeping high occupancies, maintaining our properties in good condition, controlling costs and refinancing property debt to extend maturities and lock in current interest. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call to Tim Beaudin, to review operations. Tim?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss second quarter and year-to-date operating results, with a focus on top line and rental rate trends we've seen so far this year, and I will also provide a brief update on our capital recycling activities. Fi
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss second quarter and year-to-date operating results, with a focus on top line and rental rate trends we've seen so far this year, and I will also provide a brief update on our capital recycling activities. 
First, property operations. AIMCO'S portfolio can be divided into five categories. Conventional Same Store, Affordable Same Store, Conventional Redevelopment, Affordable Redevelopment and Other.
On Page 2 of this morning's earnings release, we laid out the year-to-date financial performance of these portfolios and additional quarterly and year-to-date information related to the Conventional Same Store portfolio. You will find quarterly results for our entire portfolio on Page 23 of our supplemental schedules.
Moving on to results. Property NOI across our entire portfolio was up 1.2% for the quarter and year-to-date was just 40 basis points behind last year. Total same-store NOI, which includes Conventional and Affordable Same Store, was down 1.3% for the quarter and down 2.8% year-to-date. 
In our Conventional Same Store portfolio, NOI was down a little more than 1% for the quarter, a result almost 4% better than the high-end of our guidance with outperformance in both revenues and expenses. Year-to-date, Conventional Same Store NOI is down just over 3%. 
Affordable Same Store NOI was down 2.8% for the quarter and 20 basis points year-to-date. So far this year, expense growth in this portfolio has outpaced steady revenue gains. As to the top line, we saw strengthening revenue across our portfolio during the second quarter. Revenue for our entire portfolio was up 1% for the quarter and up 60 basis points year-to-date. Revenue for our total same-store portfolio was equal to last year for the quarter and down 60 basis points year-to-date. 
Conventional Same Store revenue for the quarter was down 50 basis points, with high occupancy at 95.6%, offsetting a year-over-year decline in average rental rates of about 4%. Year-to-date, Conventional Same Store revenue was down a little over 1%. 
Affordable Same Store revenue was up about 2.5% for the quarter and more than 2% year-to-date. Occupancy remained high to over 97%, with average rent up just over 1.5% for the quarter. 
Looking ahead, with a portfolio average daily occupancy of over 95% for the quarter, and the same for July, future revenue performance will be driven primarily by rate, which we're seeing moving in a generally positive direction. When we think about rate, we look at new lease rates and renewal rates. New leases are those where a vacant apartment
Is leased to a new customer. These account for about 1/3 of our business. Renewals of leases with existing customers account for the other 2/3 of our business. In measuring changes in rental rates, we compare the rate on newly executed leases whether new or renewal to the rate on the expiring lease for that specific apartment. New and renewal rate trends are pretty consistent across our Conventional portfolio. But today, I will speak specifically to rental rate trends in our Conventional Same Store portfolio. 
During the second quarter, new lease rates were down 2.3%. This compares to a 7% GAAP during the first quarter, so new lease rates are improving. In fact, new lease rates were up in several of our markets including Washington, D.C., Baltimore, Miami and San Francisco. We also continue to see acceleration in renewal rates. During the second quarter, renewal rates were up nearly 2%. This compares to a first quarter renewal rates that were up by 10 basis points. Renewal rates were higher at every one of our markets except one. A final point, so far this year, both new and renewal rates have been better each month than in the preceding months, so the trend has been positive.
Moving on to capital recycling. During the second quarter, we sold 11 properties for $102 million with net proceeds to AIMCO of $25 million. Our primary use of proceeds from after sales over last two years has been to repay our recourse term debt, now completely repaid. Going forward, proceeds from the sale of lower-rated assets will generally be used to improve portfolio quality to redevelopment or acquisitions within our target markets. 
Our plans for the future remain simple and unchanged. We are going to focus on operating our portfolio well and improving portfolio quality and concentrating capital in our target markets. 
With that, I will turn it over to Ernie. Ernie?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects: First, our financial results for the quarter; second, our balance sheet; and third, I will provide third quarter and updated full year 2010 guidance.At the second quarter financial resul
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects: First, our financial results for the quarter; second, our balance sheet; and third, I will provide third quarter and updated full year 2010 guidance.
At the second quarter financial results, second quarter pro forma FFO of $0.41 per share exceeded the high end of our guidance range by $0.07 and the midpoint of guidance by $0.10 per share. Our favorable results were achieved through: Property operating income of $0.06 per share above expectations, including $0.04 from Conventional Same Store, primarily due to higher occupancy and lower utility, cable expenses and property taxes; and $0.02 from Conventional Redevelopment [indiscernible](18:51) expectations. Utilities and marketing costs came in lower than anticipated. 
In addition, we have some one-time items in the second quarter that positively impacted results by a net $0.03. There were a couple of litigation matters that were settled during the quarter, which are reflected in other income that contributed an additional $0.06 to FFO, net of tax. And there were unfavorable one-time items of $0.03, primarily related to our decision considering the core state of the market for tax credit dried up previously deferred costs associated with potential tax credit transactions. These are reflected in investment management incentives.
Turning to our balance sheet, as Terry and Tim mentioned, earlier this week, we met our goal of fully repaying our term debt. Today, our only recourse debt obligation is a revolving line of credit, which other than collateralized letters of credit was undrawn at June 30. 
We have no 2010 property debt maturities. In 2011, we have four loans, appropriate collateral totaling $100 million. We plan to refinance these loans closer to the respective maturity date and will work with our lending partners to seek an early refinance if possible. 
During the first half of this year, we refinanced approximately $44 million of non-recourse property debt at a weighted average interest rate of 5.2%, extending maturity dates and locking in today's low rates for the next 10 years. Year-to-date, we have incurred prepayment penalty for approximately $2 million associated with our refinancing activities, which is included in interest expense.
We are looking for opportunities to extend 2012 through 2014 property debt maturities to reduce refunding risk and take advantage of current interest rates. We remain on plan to reduce somewhat AIMCO financial leverage, both by cyclical recovery of property income and by scheduled amortization of our property debts, which averages about $80 million per year over the next few years. 
Back to guidance, we are increasing projected full year 2010 pro forma FFO from a range of $1.25 to $1.35 per share to a range of $1.37 to $1.45 per share. At the midpoint, guidance has increased by $0.11, which reflects our $0.10 outperformance in the first half and an upward adjustment to expected second half NOI, somewhat offset by an anticipated decrease in nonrecurring income from investment management activities. 
Our updated guidance includes the following, which is also provided in our earnings release: Total portfolio NOI between 50 basis points above and 50 basis points below 2009, compared to our previous estimate of a decline of 1% to 3%; and Conventional Same Store NOI, 1% to 2% below 2009, compared to our previous expectation of a decline of 2% to 5%.  For Conventional Same Store revenue, we are narrowing our guidance from a decline of 50 basis points to 2% to a decline of 50 basis points to 1%. And for Conventional Same Store expenses, we are reducing our expense guidance from an increase of 1.5% to 2.5% to flat to an increase of 1%. We expect our nonrecurring investment management income, net of tax, to approximate $1 million for the full year, down from our previous guidance of $4.5 million at the midpoint. Lower guidance is based on the following: Nonrecurring revenue of $4 million to $6 million; and nonrecurring expenses of $4 million, which include $2 million of previously deferred cost written off during the second quarter. 
For the third quarter, pro forma FFO was projected to be $0.32 to $0.36 per share, with Conventional Same Store NOI between 50 basis points above and 50 basis points below third quarter of 2009 NOI.
With that, we will now open the call up for questions. Please limit your questions to two per time in the queue. Andrea, I'll turn it over to you for the first question.

componenttext: Michael, I can address that in terms of what's happening between the two quarters. Going from Third quarter to second quarter, in an earnings release, we talked about, from sequential basis, we do expect to be down roughly about 1% to 1.5% in terms of same-store NOI that a few want from me. In addition, in our Other operating platforms, Redevelopment, Affordable for non-same store, we do expect those to be down about $0.01, also on a sequential basis. Both of those have been driven both mainly by expenses. We would expect that seasonality and returns costs have expenses a little bit higher in the third quarter as we did in the second quarter. In addition, when we have the earnings from our sales activity, diluted impact of selling assets and paying off our term debt, that's going to be another $0.01 for us as well. And then with all the net one-timers, which I think you got about, I think, $0.38 to make sure folks are clear, we got a number that reported as $0.41. Of course, those aren't going to repeat. So those first three items I described put a little bit of a noise that makes us another $0.01. It's $0.04 difference that you talked about getting from $0.38 to the midpoint of our guidance for next quarter of $0.34.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, you talked a little bit about growing U.S. deficit and unpredictable sort of political agendas. Since AIV primarily a secured borrower, are you nervous at all about the change at the GSEs? And does this change your view at all about the appropriate
componenttext: Terry, you talked a little bit about growing U.S. deficit and unpredictable sort of political agendas. Since AIV primarily a secured borrower, are you nervous at all about the change at the GSEs? And does this change your view at all about the appropriate capital structure to use?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, I'm quite concerned about those macro issues you discussed, and I think it is very likely that there will be some change in the regulation and focus of the GSEs. What it is, and what that change will be, is a little bit unpredictable to me. I don't
componenttext: Eric, I'm quite concerned about those macro issues you discussed, and I think it is very likely that there will be some change in the regulation and focus of the GSEs. What it is, and what that change will be, is a little bit unpredictable to me. I don't think it creates a particular risk for the company. Remember, we owe them, not they us. And so, it would just mean that there'd be a change in our sources for property debt. Throughout all of this, we've diversified portfolio of lenders. We're fortunate to have a great many lenders besides the GSEs that provide property debt to us. Today, it's probably 1/3, 2/3, 1/3 or 60/40, something like that in terms of outstanding property debt. And today, the light companies and savings banks are quite competitive at the GSE. So if there is a reduced presence by the GSE, that will tend to result in some increase and interest rates compared to the alternative. But in case of AIMCO, because our debt is such long duration, it would bleed into our numbers over a long period of time.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010

componenttext: I just didn't know that maybe if a long-term goal was the sort of move [ph] (35:06) to a more unsecured-type balance sheet. I mean, I'm not thinking honestly just next year that may be over the next, say, five years or so?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: It could be if the world changed, but right now, I think, that would be the opposite of what I'd want to do. To me, as I look forward and I try to think that the economy is going to be unpredictable and variable, then I take a lot of comfort from the fact
componenttext: It could be if the world changed, but right now, I think, that would be the opposite of what I'd want to do. To me, as I look forward and I try to think that the economy is going to be unpredictable and variable, then I take a lot of comfort from the fact that we have no recourse debt, which means it'll be very hard for us to any risk. We have very limited refunding risk for the next few years, and we're working to reduce that even those with lots of runway to adjust to changing economy. So I recognize that today's corporate debt, if you look at the McDonald's transaction, for example, is quite cheap. But what the risk will be to that debt in an uncertain economy, I don't know and I've chosen to limit our risk to property-by-property basis.

componenttextpreview: First, just a couple of bookkeeping questions. First of all, in July, have we had any issuance under the ATM program? And also, as you're looking at new redevelopments, what's kind of the hurdle rate there or the targeted yield you guys need to move forwa
componenttext: First, just a couple of bookkeeping questions. First of all, in July, have we had any issuance under the ATM program? And also, as you're looking at new redevelopments, what's kind of the hurdle rate there or the targeted yield you guys need to move forward on those?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the question first on ATM. The answer is no. We got no issuance under the ATM program. And with regards to hurdle rates for redevelopments, we generally want to have a rate somewhere between 10% to 20% greater than what we think we can get f
componenttext: Let me answer the question first on ATM. The answer is no. We got no issuance under the ATM program. And with regards to hurdle rates for redevelopments, we generally want to have a rate somewhere between 10% to 20% greater than what we think we can get from acquisitions because of the risk. So of course, it's going to depend on the cap rate in that locality. So a lower cap rate market will have a lower increase in terms of the amount of yield compared to a higher cap rate. Generally, we look for 10% to 20%.

componenttext: No. 10% to 20% better return in an acquisition. So an acquisition, say, an acquisition [indiscernible](37:25), we want to be 10% or 20% better than that or closer towards that.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: And the second question is just a bigger picture question, one of your peers have kind of posed the idea that we could have the current growth rates to continue with just minimal job growth. Just curious as to what your thoughts are, Terry, on that?
componenttext: And the second question is just a bigger picture question, one of your peers have kind of posed the idea that we could have the current growth rates to continue with just minimal job growth. Just curious as to what your thoughts are, Terry, on that?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I hope so. It'd be very good news. If that were to occur, it would benefit AIMCO's diversified portfolio equally, and it would benefit AIMCO shareholders disproportionately because for some more leveraged in most of our peers. So I hope for that. I don't
componenttext: I hope so. It'd be very good news. If that were to occur, it would benefit AIMCO's diversified portfolio equally, and it would benefit AIMCO shareholders disproportionately because for some more leveraged in most of our peers. So I hope for that. I don't count on it because I think we're just in uncharted waters as to the economy. I do think that the Apartment business will do better than the overall economy for two reasons I've mentioned at the beginning: First, the demographics are quite good; and secondly, competitive appeal of own housing has been reduced by the excitement of the last two years. So I think we will do better than the economy, but I think the economy is quite unpredictable.
