componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2010 Apartment Investment & Management Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrea, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] And now, I'd like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and General Counsel. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrea. Good morning, and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and u
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrea. Good morning, and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. Also, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures, such as funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on AIMCO's website. 
The participants on today's call will be Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO, who will provide opening remarks; Tim Beaudin, AIMCO's President and Chief Operating Officer, who'll speak to property operations and capital recycling activities; and Ernie Freedman, our CFO, who'll review second quarter financial results, debt capital market's activity and guidance for the third quarter and full year 2010. I will now turn the call to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in AIMCO. On today's call, my colleagues and I will discuss second quarter results, give an update on our balance sheet and provide some comments about what we see as we look forward
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in AIMCO. On today's call, my colleagues and I will discuss second quarter results, give an update on our balance sheet and provide some comments about what we see as we look forward. 
First, our business is improving. Average daily occupancy is high. Renewal rates have been positive since February. During the second quarter, new lease rates were positive in several markets for the first time in more than a year. We expect total portfolio net operating income to be just about break-even with last year for all of 2010, and we project same-store net operating income to be about break-even for the second half of 2010. Second, our balance sheet is improving. We repaid the balance in our term debt earlier this week, leaving us with no recourse debt. 
Looking forward, we are cautious. The economy continues to recover, but the pace of recovery is slowing. Apartment demand will be better than the general economy because the demographics are attractive and because home ownership is not. And this demand will drive rent growth because apartment supply is expected to be fairly positive over the next few years. However, unsustainable federal deficits and expansive legislative agendas mean that wrenching change lies ahead with unpredictable consequences. In the face of these uncertainties, we remain focused on serving our residents and keeping high occupancies, maintaining our properties in good condition, controlling costs and refinancing property debt to extend maturities and lock in current interest. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call to Tim Beaudin, to review operations. Tim?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss second quarter and year-to-date operating results, with a focus on top line and rental rate trends we've seen so far this year, and I will also provide a brief update on our capital recycling activities. Fi
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss second quarter and year-to-date operating results, with a focus on top line and rental rate trends we've seen so far this year, and I will also provide a brief update on our capital recycling activities. 
First, property operations. AIMCO'S portfolio can be divided into five categories. Conventional Same Store, Affordable Same Store, Conventional Redevelopment, Affordable Redevelopment and Other.
On Page 2 of this morning's earnings release, we laid out the year-to-date financial performance of these portfolios and additional quarterly and year-to-date information related to the Conventional Same Store portfolio. You will find quarterly results for our entire portfolio on Page 23 of our supplemental schedules.
Moving on to results. Property NOI across our entire portfolio was up 1.2% for the quarter and year-to-date was just 40 basis points behind last year. Total same-store NOI, which includes Conventional and Affordable Same Store, was down 1.3% for the quarter and down 2.8% year-to-date. 
In our Conventional Same Store portfolio, NOI was down a little more than 1% for the quarter, a result almost 4% better than the high-end of our guidance with outperformance in both revenues and expenses. Year-to-date, Conventional Same Store NOI is down just over 3%. 
Affordable Same Store NOI was down 2.8% for the quarter and 20 basis points year-to-date. So far this year, expense growth in this portfolio has outpaced steady revenue gains. As to the top line, we saw strengthening revenue across our portfolio during the second quarter. Revenue for our entire portfolio was up 1% for the quarter and up 60 basis points year-to-date. Revenue for our total same-store portfolio was equal to last year for the quarter and down 60 basis points year-to-date. 
Conventional Same Store revenue for the quarter was down 50 basis points, with high occupancy at 95.6%, offsetting a year-over-year decline in average rental rates of about 4%. Year-to-date, Conventional Same Store revenue was down a little over 1%. 
Affordable Same Store revenue was up about 2.5% for the quarter and more than 2% year-to-date. Occupancy remained high to over 97%, with average rent up just over 1.5% for the quarter. 
Looking ahead, with a portfolio average daily occupancy of over 95% for the quarter, and the same for July, future revenue performance will be driven primarily by rate, which we're seeing moving in a generally positive direction. When we think about rate, we look at new lease rates and renewal rates. New leases are those where a vacant apartment
Is leased to a new customer. These account for about 1/3 of our business. Renewals of leases with existing customers account for the other 2/3 of our business. In measuring changes in rental rates, we compare the rate on newly executed leases whether new or renewal to the rate on the expiring lease for that specific apartment. New and renewal rate trends are pretty consistent across our Conventional portfolio. But today, I will speak specifically to rental rate trends in our Conventional Same Store portfolio. 
During the second quarter, new lease rates were down 2.3%. This compares to a 7% GAAP during the first quarter, so new lease rates are improving. In fact, new lease rates were up in several of our markets including Washington, D.C., Baltimore, Miami and San Francisco. We also continue to see acceleration in renewal rates. During the second quarter, renewal rates were up nearly 2%. This compares to a first quarter renewal rates that were up by 10 basis points. Renewal rates were higher at every one of our markets except one. A final point, so far this year, both new and renewal rates have been better each month than in the preceding months, so the trend has been positive.
Moving on to capital recycling. During the second quarter, we sold 11 properties for $102 million with net proceeds to AIMCO of $25 million. Our primary use of proceeds from after sales over last two years has been to repay our recourse term debt, now completely repaid. Going forward, proceeds from the sale of lower-rated assets will generally be used to improve portfolio quality to redevelopment or acquisitions within our target markets. 
Our plans for the future remain simple and unchanged. We are going to focus on operating our portfolio well and improving portfolio quality and concentrating capital in our target markets. 
With that, I will turn it over to Ernie. Ernie?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects: First, our financial results for the quarter; second, our balance sheet; and third, I will provide third quarter and updated full year 2010 guidance.At the second quarter financial resul
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects: First, our financial results for the quarter; second, our balance sheet; and third, I will provide third quarter and updated full year 2010 guidance.
At the second quarter financial results, second quarter pro forma FFO of $0.41 per share exceeded the high end of our guidance range by $0.07 and the midpoint of guidance by $0.10 per share. Our favorable results were achieved through: Property operating income of $0.06 per share above expectations, including $0.04 from Conventional Same Store, primarily due to higher occupancy and lower utility, cable expenses and property taxes; and $0.02 from Conventional Redevelopment [indiscernible](18:51) expectations. Utilities and marketing costs came in lower than anticipated. 
In addition, we have some one-time items in the second quarter that positively impacted results by a net $0.03. There were a couple of litigation matters that were settled during the quarter, which are reflected in other income that contributed an additional $0.06 to FFO, net of tax. And there were unfavorable one-time items of $0.03, primarily related to our decision considering the core state of the market for tax credit dried up previously deferred costs associated with potential tax credit transactions. These are reflected in investment management incentives.
Turning to our balance sheet, as Terry and Tim mentioned, earlier this week, we met our goal of fully repaying our term debt. Today, our only recourse debt obligation is a revolving line of credit, which other than collateralized letters of credit was undrawn at June 30. 
We have no 2010 property debt maturities. In 2011, we have four loans, appropriate collateral totaling $100 million. We plan to refinance these loans closer to the respective maturity date and will work with our lending partners to seek an early refinance if possible. 
During the first half of this year, we refinanced approximately $44 million of non-recourse property debt at a weighted average interest rate of 5.2%, extending maturity dates and locking in today's low rates for the next 10 years. Year-to-date, we have incurred prepayment penalty for approximately $2 million associated with our refinancing activities, which is included in interest expense.
We are looking for opportunities to extend 2012 through 2014 property debt maturities to reduce refunding risk and take advantage of current interest rates. We remain on plan to reduce somewhat AIMCO financial leverage, both by cyclical recovery of property income and by scheduled amortization of our property debts, which averages about $80 million per year over the next few years. 
Back to guidance, we are increasing projected full year 2010 pro forma FFO from a range of $1.25 to $1.35 per share to a range of $1.37 to $1.45 per share. At the midpoint, guidance has increased by $0.11, which reflects our $0.10 outperformance in the first half and an upward adjustment to expected second half NOI, somewhat offset by an anticipated decrease in nonrecurring income from investment management activities. 
Our updated guidance includes the following, which is also provided in our earnings release: Total portfolio NOI between 50 basis points above and 50 basis points below 2009, compared to our previous estimate of a decline of 1% to 3%; and Conventional Same Store NOI, 1% to 2% below 2009, compared to our previous expectation of a decline of 2% to 5%.  For Conventional Same Store revenue, we are narrowing our guidance from a decline of 50 basis points to 2% to a decline of 50 basis points to 1%. And for Conventional Same Store expenses, we are reducing our expense guidance from an increase of 1.5% to 2.5% to flat to an increase of 1%. We expect our nonrecurring investment management income, net of tax, to approximate $1 million for the full year, down from our previous guidance of $4.5 million at the midpoint. Lower guidance is based on the following: Nonrecurring revenue of $4 million to $6 million; and nonrecurring expenses of $4 million, which include $2 million of previously deferred cost written off during the second quarter. 
For the third quarter, pro forma FFO was projected to be $0.32 to $0.36 per share, with Conventional Same Store NOI between 50 basis points above and 50 basis points below third quarter of 2009 NOI.
With that, we will now open the call up for questions. Please limit your questions to two per time in the queue. Andrea, I'll turn it over to you for the first question.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, I can address that in terms of what's happening between the two quarters. Going from Third quarter to second quarter, in an earnings release, we talked about, from sequential basis, we do expect to be down roughly about 1% to 1.5% in terms of sam
componenttext: Michael, I can address that in terms of what's happening between the two quarters. Going from Third quarter to second quarter, in an earnings release, we talked about, from sequential basis, we do expect to be down roughly about 1% to 1.5% in terms of same-store NOI that a few want from me. In addition, in our Other operating platforms, Redevelopment, Affordable for non-same store, we do expect those to be down about $0.01, also on a sequential basis. Both of those have been driven both mainly by expenses. We would expect that seasonality and returns costs have expenses a little bit higher in the third quarter as we did in the second quarter. In addition, when we have the earnings from our sales activity, diluted impact of selling assets and paying off our term debt, that's going to be another $0.01 for us as well. And then with all the net one-timers, which I think you got about, I think, $0.38 to make sure folks are clear, we got a number that reported as $0.41. Of course, those aren't going to repeat. So those first three items I described put a little bit of a noise that makes us another $0.01. It's $0.04 difference that you talked about getting from $0.38 to the midpoint of our guidance for next quarter of $0.34.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, you talked a little bit about growing U.S. deficit and unpredictable sort of political agendas. Since AIV primarily a secured borrower, are you nervous at all about the change at the GSEs? And does this change your view at all about the appropriate
componenttext: Terry, you talked a little bit about growing U.S. deficit and unpredictable sort of political agendas. Since AIV primarily a secured borrower, are you nervous at all about the change at the GSEs? And does this change your view at all about the appropriate capital structure to use?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, I'm quite concerned about those macro issues you discussed, and I think it is very likely that there will be some change in the regulation and focus of the GSEs. What it is, and what that change will be, is a little bit unpredictable to me. I don't
componenttext: Eric, I'm quite concerned about those macro issues you discussed, and I think it is very likely that there will be some change in the regulation and focus of the GSEs. What it is, and what that change will be, is a little bit unpredictable to me. I don't think it creates a particular risk for the company. Remember, we owe them, not they us. And so, it would just mean that there'd be a change in our sources for property debt. Throughout all of this, we've diversified portfolio of lenders. We're fortunate to have a great many lenders besides the GSEs that provide property debt to us. Today, it's probably 1/3, 2/3, 1/3 or 60/40, something like that in terms of outstanding property debt. And today, the light companies and savings banks are quite competitive at the GSE. So if there is a reduced presence by the GSE, that will tend to result in some increase and interest rates compared to the alternative. But in case of AIMCO, because our debt is such long duration, it would bleed into our numbers over a long period of time.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I just didn't know that maybe if a long-term goal was the sort of move [ph] (35:06) to a more unsecured-type balance sheet. I mean, I'm not thinking honestly just next year that may be over the next, say, five years or so?
componenttext: I just didn't know that maybe if a long-term goal was the sort of move [ph] (35:06) to a more unsecured-type balance sheet. I mean, I'm not thinking honestly just next year that may be over the next, say, five years or so?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: It could be if the world changed, but right now, I think, that would be the opposite of what I'd want to do. To me, as I look forward and I try to think that the economy is going to be unpredictable and variable, then I take a lot of comfort from the fact
componenttext: It could be if the world changed, but right now, I think, that would be the opposite of what I'd want to do. To me, as I look forward and I try to think that the economy is going to be unpredictable and variable, then I take a lot of comfort from the fact that we have no recourse debt, which means it'll be very hard for us to any risk. We have very limited refunding risk for the next few years, and we're working to reduce that even those with lots of runway to adjust to changing economy. So I recognize that today's corporate debt, if you look at the McDonald's transaction, for example, is quite cheap. But what the risk will be to that debt in an uncertain economy, I don't know and I've chosen to limit our risk to property-by-property basis.

componenttextpreview: First, just a couple of bookkeeping questions. First of all, in July, have we had any issuance under the ATM program? And also, as you're looking at new redevelopments, what's kind of the hurdle rate there or the targeted yield you guys need to move forwa
componenttext: First, just a couple of bookkeeping questions. First of all, in July, have we had any issuance under the ATM program? And also, as you're looking at new redevelopments, what's kind of the hurdle rate there or the targeted yield you guys need to move forward on those?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the question first on ATM. The answer is no. We got no issuance under the ATM program. And with regards to hurdle rates for redevelopments, we generally want to have a rate somewhere between 10% to 20% greater than what we think we can get f
componenttext: Let me answer the question first on ATM. The answer is no. We got no issuance under the ATM program. And with regards to hurdle rates for redevelopments, we generally want to have a rate somewhere between 10% to 20% greater than what we think we can get from acquisitions because of the risk. So of course, it's going to depend on the cap rate in that locality. So a lower cap rate market will have a lower increase in terms of the amount of yield compared to a higher cap rate. Generally, we look for 10% to 20%.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I hope so. It'd be very good news. If that were to occur, it would benefit AIMCO's diversified portfolio equally, and it would benefit AIMCO shareholders disproportionately because for some more leveraged in most of our peers. So I hope for that. I don't
componenttext: I hope so. It'd be very good news. If that were to occur, it would benefit AIMCO's diversified portfolio equally, and it would benefit AIMCO shareholders disproportionately because for some more leveraged in most of our peers. So I hope for that. I don't count on it because I think we're just in uncharted waters as to the economy. I do think that the Apartment business will do better than the overall economy for two reasons I've mentioned at the beginning: First, the demographics are quite good; and secondly, competitive appeal of own housing has been reduced by the excitement of the last two years. So I think we will do better than the economy, but I think the economy is quite unpredictable.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2010 Apartment Investment & Management Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrea, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] And now I'd like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and General Counsel. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrea. Good morning, and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and u
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrea. Good morning, and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. Also, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures, such as funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on AIMCO's website. 
The participants on today's call will be Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO, who will provide opening remarks; Tim Beaudin, AIMCO's President and Chief Operating Officer, who'll speak to property operations and capital recycling activities; and Ernie Freedman, our CFO, who'll review second quarter financial results, debt capital market's activity and guidance for the third quarter and full year 2010. I will now turn the call to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in AIMCO. On today's call, my colleagues and I will discuss second quarter results, give an update on our balance sheet and provide some comments about what we see as we look forward
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in AIMCO. On today's call, my colleagues and I will discuss second quarter results, give an update on our balance sheet and provide some comments about what we see as we look forward. 
First, our business is improving. Average daily occupancy is high. Renewal rates have been positive since February. During the second quarter, new lease rates were positive in several markets for the first time in more than a year. We expect total portfolio net operating income to be just about break-even with last year for all of 2010, and we project same-store net operating income to be about break-even for the second half of 2010. Second, our balance sheet is improving. We repaid the balance in our term debt earlier this week, leaving us with no recourse debt. 
Looking forward, we are cautious. The economy continues to recover, but the pace of recovery is slowing. Apartment demand will be better than the general economy because the demographics are attractive and because home ownership is not. And this demand will drive rent growth because apartment supply is expected to be fairly positive over the next few years. However, unsustainable federal deficits and expansive legislative agendas mean that wrenching change lies ahead with unpredictable consequences. In the face of these uncertainties, we remain focused on serving our residents and keeping high occupancies, maintaining our properties in good condition, controlling costs and refinancing property debt to extend maturities and lock in current interest. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call to Tim Beaudin, to review operations. Tim?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss second quarter and year-to-date operating results, with a focus on top line and rental rate trends we've seen so far this year, and I will also provide a brief update on our capital recycling activities. Fi
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss second quarter and year-to-date operating results, with a focus on top line and rental rate trends we've seen so far this year, and I will also provide a brief update on our capital recycling activities. 
First, property operations. AIMCO'S portfolio can be divided into five categories. Conventional Same Store, Affordable Same Store, Conventional Redevelopment, Affordable Redevelopment and Other.
On Page 2 of this morning's earnings release, we laid out the year-to-date financial performance of these portfolios and additional quarterly and year-to-date information related to the Conventional Same Store portfolio. You will find quarterly results for our entire portfolio on Page 23 of our supplemental schedules.
Moving on to results. Property NOI across our entire portfolio was up 1.2% for the quarter and year-to-date was just 40 basis points behind last year. Total same-store NOI, which includes Conventional and Affordable Same Store, was down 1.3% for the quarter and down 2.8% year-to-date. 
In our Conventional Same Store portfolio, NOI was down a little more than 1% for the quarter, a result almost 4% better than the high-end of our guidance with outperformance in both revenues and expenses. Year-to-date, Conventional Same Store NOI is down just over 3%. 
Affordable Same Store NOI was down 2.8% for the quarter and 20 basis points year-to-date. So far this year, expense growth in this portfolio has outpaced steady revenue gains. As to the top line, we saw strengthening revenue across our portfolio during the second quarter. Revenue for our entire portfolio was up 1% for the quarter and up 60 basis points year-to-date. Revenue for our total same-store portfolio was equal to last year for the quarter and down 60 basis points year-to-date. 
Conventional Same Store revenue for the quarter was down 50 basis points, with high occupancy at 95.6%, offsetting a year-over-year decline in average rental rates of about 4%. Year-to-date, Conventional Same Store revenue was down a little over 1%. 
Affordable Same Store revenue was up about 2.5% for the quarter and more than 2% year-to-date. Occupancy remained high to over 97%, with average rent up just over 1.5% for the quarter. 
Looking ahead, with a portfolio average daily occupancy of over 95% for the quarter, and the same for July, future revenue performance will be driven primarily by rate, which we're seeing moving in a generally positive direction. When we think about rate, we look at new lease rates and renewal rates. New leases are those where a vacant apartment
Is leased to a new customer. These account for about 1/3 of our business. Renewals of leases with existing customers account for the other 2/3 of our business. In measuring changes in rental rates, we compare the rate on newly executed leases whether new or renewal to the rate on the expiring lease for that specific apartment. New and renewal rate trends are pretty consistent across our Conventional portfolio. But today, I will speak specifically to rental rate trends in our Conventional Same Store portfolio. 
During the second quarter, new lease rates were down 2.3%. This compares to a 7% GAAP during the first quarter, so new lease rates are improving. In fact, new lease rates were up in several of our markets including Washington, D.C., Baltimore, Miami and San Francisco. We also continue to see acceleration in renewal rates. During the second quarter, renewal rates were up nearly 2%. This compares to a first quarter renewal rates that were up by 10 basis points. Renewal rates were higher at every one of our markets except one. A final point, so far this year, both new and renewal rates have been better each month than in the preceding months, so the trend has been positive.
Moving on to capital recycling. During the second quarter, we sold 11 properties for $102 million with net proceeds to AIMCO of $25 million. Our primary use of proceeds from after sales over last two years has been to repay our recourse term debt, now completely repaid. Going forward, proceeds from the sale of lower-rated assets will generally be used to improve portfolio quality to redevelopment or acquisitions within our target markets. 
Our plans for the future remain simple and unchanged. We are going to focus on operating our portfolio well and improving portfolio quality and concentrating capital in our target markets. 
With that, I will turn it over to Ernie. Ernie?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects: First, our financial results for the quarter; second, our balance sheet; and third, I will provide third quarter and updated full year 2010 guidance.At the second quarter financial resul
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects: First, our financial results for the quarter; second, our balance sheet; and third, I will provide third quarter and updated full year 2010 guidance.
At the second quarter financial results, second quarter pro forma FFO of $0.41 per share exceeded the high end of our guidance range by $0.07 and the midpoint of guidance by $0.10 per share. Our favorable results were achieved through: Property operating income of $0.06 per share above expectations, including $0.04 from Conventional Same Store, primarily due to higher occupancy and lower utility, cable expenses and property taxes; and $0.02 from Conventional Redevelopment as occupancy exceeded our expectations, the utilities and marketing costs came in lower than anticipated. 
In addition, we have some one-time items in the second quarter that positively impacted results by a net $0.03. There were a couple of litigation matters that were settled during the quarter, which are reflected in other income that contributed an additional $0.06 to FFO, net of tax. And there were unfavorable one-time items of $0.03, primarily related to our decision considering the core state of the market for tax credit dried up previously deferred costs associated with potential tax credit transactions. These are reflected in investment management incentives.
Turning to our balance sheet, as Terry and Tim mentioned, earlier this week, we met our goal of fully repaying our term debt. Today, our only recourse debt obligation is a revolving line of credit, which other than collateralized letters of credit was undrawn at June 30. 
We have no 2010 property debt maturities. In 2011, we have four loans, appropriate collateral totaling $100 million. We plan to refinance these loans closer to their respective maturity date and will work with our lending partners to seek an early refinance if possible. 
During the first half of this year, we refinanced approximately $44 million of nonrecourse property debt at a weighted average interest rate of 5.2%, extending maturity dates and locking in today's low rates for the next 10 years. Year-to-date, we have incurred prepayment penalties of approximately $2 million associated with our refinancing activity, which is included in interest expense.
We are looking for opportunities to extend 2012 through 2014 property debt maturities to reduce refunding risks and take advantage of current interest rates. We remain on plan to reduce somewhat AIMCO financial leverage, both by cyclical recovery of property income and by scheduled amortization of our property debt, which averages about $80 million per year over the next few years. 
As to guidance, we are increasing projected full year 2010 pro forma FFO from a range of $1.25 to $1.35 per share to a range of $1.37 to $1.45 per share. At the midpoint, guidance has increased by $0.11, which reflects our $0.10 outperformance in the first half and an upward adjustment to expected second half NOI, somewhat offset by an anticipated decrease in nonrecurring income from investment management activities. 
Our updated guidance includes the following, which is also provided in our earnings release: Total portfolio NOI between 50 basis points above and 50 basis points below 2009, compared to our previous estimate of a decline of 1% to 3%; and Conventional Same Store NOI, 1% to 2% below 2009, compared to our previous expectation of a decline of 2% to 5%. For Conventional Same Store revenue, we are narrowing our guidance from a decline of 50 basis points to 2% to a decline of 50 basis points to 1%. And for Conventional Same Store expenses, we are reducing our expense guidance from an increase of 1.5% to 2.5% to flat to an increase of 1%. We expect our nonrecurring investment management income, net of tax, to approximate $1 million for the full year, down from our previous guidance of $4.5 million at the midpoint. Lower guidance is based on the following: Nonrecurring revenue of $4 million to $6 million; and nonrecurring expenses of $4 million, which include $2 million of previously deferred cost written-off during the second quarter. 
For the third quarter, pro forma FFO is projected to be $0.32 to $0.36 per share, with Conventional Same Store NOI between 50 basis points above and 50 basis points below third quarter of 2009 NOI.
With that, we will now open the call up for questions. Please limit your questions to two per time in the queue. Andrea, I'll turn it over to you for the first question.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Had to join late so apologies if you talked about this already. I was wondering if I can get more specifics about the second half guidance. What's really driving the lower earnings expectations from $0.38 pro forma this quarter to, I guess, $0.34 over the
componenttext: Had to join late so apologies if you talked about this already. I was wondering if I can get more specifics about the second half guidance. What's really driving the lower earnings expectations from $0.38 pro forma this quarter to, I guess, $0.34 over the next two quarters?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, I can address that in terms of what's happening between the two quarters. Going from Third quarter to second quarter, in an earnings release, we talked about, from sequential basis, we do expect to be down roughly about 1% to 1.5% in terms of sam
componenttext: Michael, I can address that in terms of what's happening between the two quarters. Going from Third quarter to second quarter, in an earnings release, we talked about, from sequential basis, we do expect to be down roughly about 1% to 1.5% in terms of same-store NOI that a few want from me. In addition, in our Other operating platforms, Redevelopment, Affordable for non-same store, we do expect those to be down about $0.01, also on a sequential basis. Both of those have been driven both mainly by expenses. We would expect that seasonality and returns costs have expenses a little bit higher in the third quarter as we did in the second quarter. In addition, when we have the earnings from our sales activity, diluted impact of selling assets and paying off our term debt, that's going to be another $0.01 for us as well. And then with all the net one-timers, which I think you got about, I think, $0.38 to make sure folks are clear, we got a number that reported as $0.41. Of course, those aren't going to repeat. So those first three items I described put a little bit of a noise that makes us another $0.01. It's $0.04 difference that you talked about getting from $0.38 to the midpoint of our guidance for next quarter of $0.34.

componenttext: Sure, Michael. And specifically in Miami, we had some very good real estate appeals that came through for us in the second quarter of 2009. But for two of our high-rise properties, we were able to get successful appeals completed for both that year as well as past years. That's why you're seeing a very large increase that extends year-over-year. We didn't have that same success in the same quarter here in 2010. That was the biggest increase you saw quarter-over-quarter from some of the different markets.

componenttext: Refinancing proceeds are part our sources of capital. So it's hard to trace money from one place to another. But broadly, I refer you back to Ernie's point that we expect going forward to slightly reduce our overall leverage through property debt amortization.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Eric Wolfe of Citi.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, you talked a little bit about the growing U.S. deficit and unpredictable sort of political agendas. Since AIV is primarily a secured borrower, are you nervous at all about a change of the GSEs? And does this change your view at all about the approp
componenttext: Terry, you talked a little bit about the growing U.S. deficit and unpredictable sort of political agendas. Since AIV is primarily a secured borrower, are you nervous at all about a change of the GSEs? And does this change your view at all about the appropriate capital structure to use?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, I'm quite concerned about those macro issues you discussed, and I think it is very likely that there will be some change in the regulation and focus of the GSEs. What it is, what that change will be, is a little bit unpredictable to me. I don't thin
componenttext: Eric, I'm quite concerned about those macro issues you discussed, and I think it is very likely that there will be some change in the regulation and focus of the GSEs. What it is, what that change will be, is a little bit unpredictable to me. I don't think it's created a particular risk to the company. Remember, we owe them, not they us. And so it really would just mean that there would be a change in our sources for property debt. Throughout all of this, we've diversified portfolio of lenders. We're fortunate to have a great many lenders besides the GSEs that provide property debt to us. Today, it's probably 2/3, 1/3 or 60-40, something like that in terms of outstanding property debt. And today, the life companies and savings banks are quite competitive with the GSEs. So if there is a reduced presence by the GSEs, that will tend to result in some increase in interest rates compared to the alternative. But in case of AIMCO, because our debt is such long duration, it would bleed into our numbers over a long period of time.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I just didn't know that maybe if a long-term goal was to sort of move to a more unsecured-type balance sheet. I mean, I'm not thinking, obviously, just next year, but maybe over the next, say, five years or so?
componenttext: I just didn't know that maybe if a long-term goal was to sort of move to a more unsecured-type balance sheet. I mean, I'm not thinking, obviously, just next year, but maybe over the next, say, five years or so?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: It could be if the world changed, but right now, I think, that would be the opposite of what I'd want to do. To me, as I look forward and if I think that the economy is going to be unpredictable and variable, then I take a lot of comfort from the fact tha
componenttext: It could be if the world changed, but right now, I think, that would be the opposite of what I'd want to do. To me, as I look forward and if I think that the economy is going to be unpredictable and variable, then I take a lot of comfort from the fact that we have no recourse debt, which means that it'd be very hard for us to have entity risk. We have very limited refunding risk for the next few years, and we're working to reduce that. Even so, we'll have lots of runway to adjust to changing economy. So I recognize that today's corporate debt, if you look at the McDonald's transaction, for example, is quite cheap. But what the risk will be to that debt in an uncertain economy, I don't know and I've chosen to limit our risk to property-by-property basis.

componenttextpreview: First, just a couple of bookkeeping questions. First of all, in July, have we had any issuance under the ATM program? And also, as you're looking at new redevelopments, what's kind of the hurdle rate there or the targeted yield you guys need to move forwa
componenttext: First, just a couple of bookkeeping questions. First of all, in July, have we had any issuance under the ATM program? And also, as you're looking at new redevelopments, what's kind of the hurdle rate there or the targeted yield you guys need to move forward on those?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the question first on ATM. The answer is no. We got no issuance under the ATM program. And with regards to hurdle rates for redevelopments, we generally want to have a rate somewhere between 10% to 20% greater than what we think we can get f
componenttext: Let me answer the question first on ATM. The answer is no. We got no issuance under the ATM program. And with regards to hurdle rates for redevelopments, we generally want to have a rate somewhere between 10% to 20% greater than what we think we can get from acquisitions because of the risk. So of course, it's going to depend on the cap rate in that locality. So a lower cap rate market will have a lower increase in terms of the amount of yield compared to a higher cap rate. Generally, we look for 10% to 20%.

componenttext: No. 10% to 20% better return in an acquisition. So an acquisition, say, an acquisition [indiscernible](37:25), we want to be 10% or 20% better than that or closer towards that.

componenttextpreview: And the second question is just a bigger picture question, one of your peers have kind of posed the idea that we could have the current growth rates to continue with just minimal job growth. Just curious as to what your thoughts are, Terry, on that?
componenttext: And the second question is just a bigger picture question, one of your peers have kind of posed the idea that we could have the current growth rates to continue with just minimal job growth. Just curious as to what your thoughts are, Terry, on that?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I hope so. It'd be very good news. If that were to occur, it would benefit AIMCO's diversified portfolio equally, and it would benefit AIMCO shareholders disproportionately because for some more leveraged in most of our peers. So I hope for that. I don't
componenttext: I hope so. It'd be very good news. If that were to occur, it would benefit AIMCO's diversified portfolio equally, and it would benefit AIMCO shareholders disproportionately because for some more leveraged in most of our peers. So I hope for that. I don't count on it because I think we're just in uncharted waters as to the economy. I do think that the Apartment business will do better than the overall economy for two reasons I've mentioned at the beginning: First, the demographics are quite good; and secondly, competitive appeal of own housing has been reduced by the excitement of the last two years. So I think we will do better than the economy, but I think the economy is quite unpredictable.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2010 Apartment Investment & Management Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrea, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] And now I'd like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and General Counsel. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrea. Good morning, and good afternoon. During this conference call, forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncer
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrea. Good morning, and good afternoon. During this conference call, forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. Also, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures, such as funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on AIMCO's website. 
The participants on today's call will be Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO, who will provide opening remarks; Tim Beaudin, AIMCO's President and Chief Operating Officer, who'll speak to property operations and capital recycling activities; and Ernie Freedman, our CFO, who'll review second quarter financial results, debt capital market's activity and guidance for the third quarter and full year 2010. I will now turn the call to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in AIMCO. On today's call, my colleagues and I will discuss second quarter results, give an update on our balance sheet and provide some comments about what we see as we look forward
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on this call for your interest in AIMCO. On today's call, my colleagues and I will discuss second quarter results, give an update on our balance sheet and provide some comments about what we see as we look forward. 
First, our business is improving. Average daily occupancy is high. Renewal rates have been positive since February. During the second quarter, new lease rates were positive in several markets for the first time in more than a year. We expect total portfolio net operating income to be just about breakeven with last year for all of 2010, and we project same-store net operating income to be about breakeven for the second half of 2010. Second, our balance sheet is improving. We repaid the balance on our term debt earlier this week, leaving us with no recourse debt. 
Looking forward, we are cautious. The economy continues to recover, but the pace of recovery is slowing. Apartment demand will be better than the general economy because the demographics are attractive and because home ownership is not, and this demand will drive rent growth because apartment supply is expected to be fairly positive over the next few years. However, unsustainable federal deficits and expansive legislative agendas mean that wrenching change lies ahead with unpredictable consequences. In the face of these uncertainties, we remain focused on serving our residents and keeping high occupancies, maintaining our properties in good condition, controlling costs and refinancing property debt to extend maturities and lock in current interest rates. With that, I'd like to turn the call to Tim Beaudin to review operations. Tim?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss second quarter and year-to-date operating results, with a focus on top line and rental rate trends we've seen so far this year, and I will also provide a brief update on our capital recycling activities. Fi
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. On today's call, I will discuss second quarter and year-to-date operating results, with a focus on top line and rental rate trends we've seen so far this year, and I will also provide a brief update on our capital recycling activities. 
First, property operations. AIMCO'S portfolio can be divided into five categories. Conventional Same Store, Affordable Same Store, Conventional Redevelopment, Affordable Redevelopment and Other.
On Page 2 of this morning's earnings release, we laid out the year-to-date financial performance of these portfolios and additional quarterly and year-to-date information related to the Conventional Same Store portfolio. You will find quarter results for our entire portfolio on Page 23 of our supplemental schedules.
Moving on to results. Property NOI across our entire portfolio was up 1.2% for the quarter and year-to-date was just 40 basis points behind last year. Total same-store NOI, which includes Conventional and Affordable Same Store, was down 1.3% for the quarter and down 2.8% year-to-date. 
In our Conventional Same Store portfolio, NOI was down a little more than 1% for the quarter, a result almost 4% better than the high end of our guidance with the outperformance in both revenues and expenses. Year-to-date, Conventional Same Store NOI is down just over 3%. 
Affordable Same Store NOI was down 2.8% for the quarter and 20 basis points year-to-date. So far this year, expense growth in this portfolio has outpaced steady revenue gains. As to the top line, we saw strengthening revenue across our portfolio during the second quarter. Revenue for our entire portfolio was up 1% for the quarter and up 60 basis points year-to-date. Revenue for our total same-store portfolio was equal to last year for the quarter and down 60 basis points year-to-date. 
Conventional Same Store revenue for the quarter was down 50 basis points, with high occupancy at 95.6%, offsetting a year-over-year decline in average rental rates of about 4%. Year-to-date, Conventional Same Store revenue was down a little over 1%. 
Affordable Same Store revenue was up about 2.5% for the quarter and more than 2% year-to-date. Occupancy remained high to over 97%, with average rent up just over 1.5% for the quarter. 
Looking ahead, with a portfolio average daily occupancy of over 95% for the quarter, and the same for July, future revenue performance will be driven primarily by rate, which we're seeing move in a generally positive direction. When we think about rate, we look at new lease rate and renewal rate. 
New leases are those where a vacant apartment
Is leased to a new customer. These account for about one-third of our business. Renewals of leases with existing customers account for the other two-thirds of our business. In measuring changes in rental rates, we compare the rate on newly executed leases whether new or renewal to the rate on the expiring lease for that specific apartment. New and renewal rate trends are pretty consistent across our Conventional portfolio. But today, I will speak specifically to rental rate trends in our Conventional Same Store portfolio. 
During the second quarter, new lease rates were down 2.3%. This compares to a 7% GAAP during the first quarter, so new lease rates are improving. In fact, new lease rates were up in several of our markets including Washington, D.C., Baltimore, Miami and San Francisco. We also continue to see acceleration in renewal rates. During the second quarter, renewal rates were up nearly 2%. This compares to a first quarter renewal rate that were up by 10 basis points. Renewal rates were higher at every one of our markets except one. 
A final point, so far this year, both new and renewal rate have been better each month than in the preceding months, so the trend has been positive.
Moving on to capital recycling. During the second quarter, we sold 11 properties for $102 million with net proceeds to AIMCO of $25 million. Our primary use of proceeds from asset sales over the last two years has been to repay our recourse term debt, now completely repaid. Going forward, proceeds from the sale of lower-rated assets will generally be used to improve portfolio quality to redevelopment or acquisitions within our target markets. 
Our plans for the future remain simple and unchanged. We are going to focus on operating our portfolio well and improving portfolio quality and concentrating capital in our target markets. With that, I will turn it over to Ernie. Ernie?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects: First, our financial results for the quarter; second, our balance sheet; and third, I will provide third quarter and updated full year 2010 guidance.At the second quarter financial resul
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. On today's call, I will cover the following subjects: First, our financial results for the quarter; second, our balance sheet; and third, I will provide third quarter and updated full year 2010 guidance.
At the second quarter financial results, second quarter pro forma FFO of $0.41 per share exceeded the high end of our guidance range by $0.07 and the midpoint of guidance by $0.10 per share. Our favorable results were achieved through: property operating income, $0.06 per share above expectations, including $0.04 from Conventional Same Store, primarily due to higher occupancy and lower utilities, cable expenses and property taxes; and $0.02 from Conventional Redevelopment. As occupancy exceeded our expectations, the utilities and marketing costs came in lower than anticipated. 
In addition, we have some onetime items in the second quarter that positively impacted results by a net $0.03. There were a couple of litigation matters that were settled during the quarter, which are reflected in other income that contributed an additional $0.06 to FFO, net of tax. And there were unfavorable onetime items of $0.03, primarily related to our decision considering the core state of the market for tax credit dried up previously deferred costs associated with potential tax credit transactions. These are reflected in investment management incentives.
Turning to our balance sheet, as Terry and Tim mentioned, earlier this week, we met our goal of fully repaying our term debt. Today, our only recourse debt obligation is a revolving line of credit, which other than collateralized letters of credit, was undrawn in June 30. 
We have no 2010 property debt maturities. In 2011, we have four loans, appropriate collateral totaling $100 million. We plan to refinance these loans closer to their respective maturity date and will work with our lending partners to seek an early refinance if possible. 
During the first half of this year, we refinanced approximately $44 million of nonrecourse property debt at a weighted average interest rate of 5.2%, extending maturity dates and locking in today's low rates for the next 10 years. Year-to-date, we have incurred prepayment penalties of approximately $2 million associated with our refinancing activity, which is included in interest expense.
We are looking for opportunities to extend 2012 through 2014 property debt maturities to reduce refunding risks and take advantage of current interest rates. We remain on plan to reduce somewhat AIMCO financial leverage, both by cyclical recovery of property income and by scheduled amortization of our property debt, which averages about $80 million per year over the next few years. 
As to guidance, we are increasing projected full year 2010 pro forma FFO from a range of $1.25 to $1.35 per share to a range of $1.37 to $1.45 per share. At the midpoint, guidance has increased by $0.11, which reflects our $0.10 outperformance in the first half and an upward adjustment to expected second half NOI, somewhat offset by an anticipated decrease in nonrecurring income from investment management activities. 
Our updated guidance includes the following, which is also provided in our earnings release: Total portfolio NOI between 50 basis points above and 50 basis points below 2009, compared to our previous estimate of a decline of 1% to 3%; and Conventional Same Store NOI, 1% to 2% below 2009, compared to our previous expectation of a decline of 2% to 5%. For Conventional Same Store revenue, we are narrowing our guidance from a decline of 50 basis points to 2% to a decline of 50 basis points to 1%. And for Conventional Same Store expenses, we are reducing our expense guidance from an increase of 1.5% to 2.5% to flat to an increase of 1%. We expect our nonrecurring investment management income, net of tax, to approximate $1 million for the full year, down from our previous guidance of $4.5 million at the midpoint. Lower guidance is based on the following: Nonrecurring revenue of $4 million to $6 million; and nonrecurring expenses of $4 million, which include $2 million of previously deferred cost written-off during the second quarter. 
For the third quarter, pro forma FFO is projected to be $0.32 to $0.36 per share, with Conventional Same Store NOI between 50 basis points above and 50 basis points below third quarter of 2009 NOI.
With that, we will now open the call up for questions. Please limit your questions to two per time in the queue. Andrea, I'll turn it over to you for the first question.

componenttext: Michael, I can address that in terms of what's happening between the two quarters. Going from third quarter to second quarter, in an earnings release, we talked about, from sequential basis, we do expect it to be down roughly about 1% to 1.5%. In terms of same-store NOI, that would be $0.01. In addition, in our Other operating platforms, Redevelopment, Affordable for non-same store, we do expect those to be down about $0.01 also on a sequential basis. Both of those have been driven both mainly by expenses. We've expected that seasonality and then returns costs have expenses a little bit higher in the third quarter as we did in the second quarter. In addition, where we have the earnings from our sales activities, the diluted impact of selling assets and paying off our term debt, that's going to be another $0.01 for us as well. And then with all the net one-timers, which I think you left out, I'd like to say in $0.38, but to make sure folks are clear, yes, the number that we reported was $0.41. Of course, those aren't going to repeat. So those first three items I described puts a little bit of a noise that makes us another $0.01. It's the $0.04 difference that you talked about getting from $0.38 to the midpoint of our guidance for next quarter of $0.34.

componenttextpreview: Terry, you talked a little bit about the growing U.S. deficit and unpredictable sort of political agendas. Since AIV is primarily a secured borrower, are you nervous at all about a change of the GSEs? And does this change your view at all about the approp
componenttext: Terry, you talked a little bit about the growing U.S. deficit and unpredictable sort of political agendas. Since AIV is primarily a secured borrower, are you nervous at all about a change of the GSEs? And does this change your view at all about the appropriate capital structure to use?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, I'm quite concerned about those macro issues you discussed, and I think it is very likely that there will be some change in the regulation and focus of the GSEs. What it is, what that change will be, is a little bit unpredictable to me. I don't thin
componenttext: Eric, I'm quite concerned about those macro issues you discussed, and I think it is very likely that there will be some change in the regulation and focus of the GSEs. What it is, what that change will be, is a little bit unpredictable to me. I don't think it's created a particular risk to the company. Remember, we owe them, not they us. And so it really would just mean that there would be a change in our sources for property debt. Throughout all of this, we've diversified portfolio of lenders. We're fortunate to have a great many lenders besides the GSEs that provide property debt to us. Today, it's probably 2/3, 1/3 or 60-40, something like that in terms of outstanding property debt. And today, the life companies and savings banks are quite competitive with the GSEs. So if there is a reduced presence by the GSEs, that will tend to result in some increase in interest rates compared to the alternative. But in case of AIMCO, because our debt is such long duration, it would bleed into our numbers over a long period of time.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I just didn't know that maybe if a long-term goal was to sort of move to a more unsecured-type balance sheet. I mean, I'm not thinking, obviously, just next year, but maybe over the next, say, five years or so?
componenttext: I just didn't know that maybe if a long-term goal was to sort of move to a more unsecured-type balance sheet. I mean, I'm not thinking, obviously, just next year, but maybe over the next, say, five years or so?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: It could be if the world changed, but right now, I think, that would be the opposite of what I'd want to do. To me, as I look forward and if I think that the economy is going to be unpredictable and variable, then I take a lot of comfort from the fact tha
componenttext: It could be if the world changed, but right now, I think, that would be the opposite of what I'd want to do. To me, as I look forward and if I think that the economy is going to be unpredictable and variable, then I take a lot of comfort from the fact that we have no recourse debt, which means that it'd be very hard for us to have entity risk. We have very limited refunding risk for the next few years, and we're working to reduce that. Even so, we'll have lots of runway to adjust to changing economy. So I recognize that today's corporate debt, if you look at the McDonald's transaction, for example, is quite cheap. But what the risk will be to that debt in an uncertain economy, I don't know, and I've chosen to limit our risk to property-by-property basis.

componenttextpreview: First, just a couple of bookkeeping questions. First of all, in July, have we had any issuance under the ATM program? And also, as you're looking at new redevelopments, what's kind of the hurdle rate there or the targeted yield you guys need to move forwa
componenttext: First, just a couple of bookkeeping questions. First of all, in July, have we had any issuance under the ATM program? And also, as you're looking at new redevelopments, what's kind of the hurdle rate there or the targeted yield you guys need to move forward on those?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the question first on ATM. The answer is no, we've got no issuance under the ATM program. And with regards to hurdle rates for redevelopments, we generally want to have a rate somewhere between 10% and 20% greater than what we think we could
componenttext: Let me answer the question first on ATM. The answer is no, we've got no issuance under the ATM program. And with regards to hurdle rates for redevelopments, we generally want to have a rate somewhere between 10% and 20% greater than what we think we could get from acquisitions because of the risk. So of course, it's going to depend on the cap rate in that locality. So a lower cap rate market will have a lower increase in terms of the amount of yield compared to a higher cap rate. Generally, look for 10% to 20%.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-30-2010
componenttextpreview: 10% to 20% cash on cash returns and 20% higher...
componenttext: 10% to 20% cash on cash returns and 20% higher...

componenttextpreview: I hope so. It'd be very good news. If that were to occur, it would benefit AIMCO's diversified portfolio equally, and it would benefit AIMCO shareholders disproportionately because we're somewhat more leveraged in most of our peers, so I hope for that. I
componenttext: I hope so. It'd be very good news. If that were to occur, it would benefit AIMCO's diversified portfolio equally, and it would benefit AIMCO shareholders disproportionately because we're somewhat more leveraged in most of our peers, so I hope for that. I don't count on it because I think we're just in uncharted waters as to the economy. I do think that the Apartment business will do better than the overall economy for two reasons I've mentioned at the beginning: First, the demographics are quite good; and secondly, competitive appeal of owned housing has been reduced by the excitement of the last two years. So I think we will do better than the economy, but I think the economy is quite unpredictable.
