headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Apartment Investment and Management Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrea and I will be coordinator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Apartment Investment and Management Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrea and I will be coordinator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
Now, Id like to turn the presentation over to your host for todays call, Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and General Counsel. Please proceed, maam.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrea. Good morning and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on managements judgment, including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrea. Good morning and good afternoon. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on managements judgment, including projections related to 2010 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today.
Also, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures, such as funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on AIMCOs Web site.
The participants on todays call will be Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO, who will provide opening remarks; Tim Beaudin, AIMCOs President and Chief Operating Officer, who will speak to property operations and capital recycling activities; and Ernie Freedman, our CFO, who will review third quarter financial results, debt capital markets activity, and guidance for the fourth quarter and full year 2010.
I will now turn the call to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you for your interest in AIMCO. AIMCO enjoyed a good third quarter beating FFO guidance and raising full year guidance. And by the way, AIMCO has met or beat guidance for the past 19 consecutive quarters.In a few mi
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you for your interest in AIMCO. AIMCO enjoyed a good third quarter beating FFO guidance and raising full year guidance. And by the way, AIMCO has met or beat guidance for the past 19 consecutive quarters.
In a few minutes, Tim and Ernie will provide their thoughts regarding our third quarter. Before they do Id like to offer them my thanks for jobs well done and add my own perspective on where weve been and what I see ahead.
For me the headline for third quarter is apartment markets are on the mend. Occupancies are quite high, and rental income is increasing. Now the last few years have of course been extremely difficult for the U.S. economy, but during that same time for a number of reasons, the apartment business has been better than the economy at large.
So looking back we can see that AIMCOs same-store income has been fairly stable, up 3.7% in 2008, down 3.3% in 2009, and in our revised guidance down say 50 bps for this year. So taken together our same-store net operating income during the past three years has been flat, notwithstanding the most volatile economy in a great many years.
Looking back, we can also see that our conventional same-store net operating income results have been better than peer averages that is better than our peers for the past one, three and five years.
And we can see that our conventional same-store operating margin actually improved during the recession and is now 61 year-to-date. These sustained outperformances are due to a great job by my AIMCO teammates. Its my privilege to work each day with terrific colleagues and they have my thanks.
As we look forward, my crystal ball is murky. There is an usually wide range of forecast for the overall economy. However, there is a general expectation that full recovery will take several years at a minimum. Even so just as in the recent past, apartments are expected to do better than the broader economy and AIMCO results are expected to be competitive with its peers.
For example, there is a great focus on rent growth. AIMCO rental rates are expected by third-party forecasters to increase about 16% cumulative over the next four years. This is above the average rent growth expected for all apartment REITs and only slightly say about 80 basis points cumulative over the four years or 20 basis points a year behind the California-centric portfolios, which of course declined more during the downturn and so have more ground to recover.
Given the economic uncertainties, we are cautious as we finish a solid 2010 and plan for 2011. Here are our priorities.
First, maximize revenues by maintaining our high average daily occupancy, and working to increase rental rates, while recognizing that customers are likely to remain price sensitive.
Second, continue strict cost controls and high levels of capital spending to maintain and improve our properties.
Third, reduce offsite cost including G&A by continuing to simplify our business, for example, shedding non-core activities; continuing to simplify our capital structure, for example; acquiring partnership interest, and deploying new technology platforms.
Fourth, strengthen our balance sheet further by avoiding recourse debt, continuing to reduce refunding risk by extending the duration of our debt already more than one-third longer than the peer average, and continuing to take advantage of todays interest rates to lower our cost of leverage.
I might add here, we like our low-risk fixed rate leverage or its positive effect in magnifying the market improvements that we expect, and we like too its hedge against possible inflation.
Fifth, we also expect to invest more in new business. We have several redevelopment opportunities in our portfolio, with unlevered internal rates of return well above those available from property acquisitions. I expect that we will start a few of these in 2011, and fund our cost with non-recourse property debt and with proceeds of some property sales off the bottom of our portfolio.
We are actively pursuing property acquisitions, but were not very excited when we look at the prices being paid. Well continue to look at different opportunities. If we find some with acceptable risk adjusted pricing, I expect that we will fund them with property debt and with proceeds from property sales or perhaps well match some of the equity requirement with new share issuance via our ATM facility.
However, we have been cautious, are cautious, and will continue to be cautious about issuing new equity. Well not issue new shares unless the use of proceeds is clearly accretive to our shareholders.
With that Id like to turn the call to Tim Beaudin, our President. Tim?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. On todays call Ill discuss third quarter and year-to-date operating results with an emphasis on the top line, and Ill also provide a quick update on our capital recycling activities.Starting with property operating results, NOI a
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. On todays call Ill discuss third quarter and year-to-date operating results with an emphasis on the top line, and Ill also provide a quick update on our capital recycling activities.
Starting with property operating results, NOI across our entire portfolio was up 3.2% for the quarter and year-to-date was 90 basis points ahead of last year. Notably, this quarter marks the first since second quarter 2009, in which both quarterly and year-to-date portfolio NOI was positive.
Our operating team has maintained focus on maximizing total revenue and controlling cost. Its showing in our numbers. Breaking down operating results, total same-store NOI, which includes conventional and affordable same-store, was up 3% for the quarter and down 1% year-to-date. Affordable same-store NOI was up 6.2% for the quarter and up 2.1% year-to-date.
In conventional same-store, NOI was up 2.6% for the quarter and down 1.4% year-to-date. Conventional same-store occupancy for the quarter was 96%, which was 1.2% higher than third quarter 2009. Year-to-date conventional same-store occupancy was 95.9%, which was a 2.3% improvement over last year.
Id give you a bit more color on rental rates in a minute, but first expenses. Conventional same-store expenses were down 4.2% for the quarter primarily due to an adjustment of previously estimated real estate taxes after successful settlement of appeals during the quarter.
Controllable operating expenses such as marketing and turnover were also lower than third quarter 2009. Year-to-date conventional same-store expenses were up 20 basis points with lower marketing and turnover cost being offset by higher repairs and maintenance expenses as we continue to focus on the upkeep of our assets.
Moving on to the top line, revenue across our entire portfolio was up 30 basis points compared to third quarter 2009, and up 50 basis points on a year-to-date basis. For the third quarter and year-to-date, conventional same-store revenue was essentially flat, and predictable afford same-store revenue growth combined with lease up of our down units in our redevelopment portfolios pushed total portfolio revenue into positive territory.
It is worth noting that while conventional same-store revenue was virtually flat for the quarter and year-to-date, third quarter conventional same-store revenue was up 60 basis points compared to second quarter as we continue to build occupancy. On that note, as many of you may know for the last year or so we have been highly focused in driving revenue growth by building and maintaining high occupancy and being a bit more cautious about rate. We review the results of this approach on a daily basis through our revenue management process, and we are taking advantage of rate opportunities as and when they arise.
Should market conditions change, we have the flexibility to shift our focus and achieve our end goal, which is to maximize total revenue. When we focus on high occupancy and low turnover, renewals become key to growing NOI. When we keep our customers, we not only have more rate opportunity, we avoid turnover cost.
Specifically, within our conventional same-store properties, 67% of our customers whose lease expired during the third quarter chose to stay with us, which is an all-time high for AIMCO, so we are doing a good job in this area.
Renewal rates continue on a positive trend during the quarter with renewal rates 1.5% higher than expiring lease rates. This compares to renewal rates that were up 10 basis points in the first quarter, and up 1.9% in the second quarter. Year-to-date renewal rates were 1.3% higher than expiring lease rates. So, were keeping our customers and seeing positive renewal rates across our portfolio.
New lease rates also continue to improve during the quarter. On average, third quarter new lease rates were down 1.4% compared to expiring lease rates, but this compares to new lease rates that were down 7% in the first quarter and down 2.3% in the second quarter. Year-to-date, new lease rates were 3.1% below expiring lease rates. So the gap at new lease rates is shrinking.
As we finish up the year, we continue to focus on maintaining high occupancy and low turnover with the objective of further increasing pricing power and maximizing revenue. With this in mind, I am comfortable how we are positioned for the fourth quarter.
On a conventional same-store basis, occupancy is the highest its been all year with October coming in 96.9%, some indications of rate improvement, and as a result October revenue is above September in spite of seasonally lower traffic.
Moving on to capital recycling, during the third quarter we sold eight properties for $99 million with net proceeds to AIMCO of $27 million.
Proceeds from these sales were used primarily to repay the balance of our term debt in July. With the term debt fully repaid proceeds from the sale of lower rated assets in the future will generally be used to improve portfolio quality through redevelopment or acquisitions.
As to acquisitions, we have looked at several dozen prospective real estate acquisitions over the course of the year and we have bid on many of them. But the final sales prices we saw coming out of most of these deals just didnt make sense to us in light of what third-party experts are projecting for future revenue growth.
With acquisition pricing at levels that appear rich, we believe we have a more attractive reinvestment opportunities within our own portfolio primarily in the form of redevelopment, but also through the acquisition of limited partner interest.
These types of investments that have the unique benefit of being in real estate that we already own in markets we already know. We will continue to look for acquisition opportunities through marketed transactions, direct deals, and other opportunistic scenarios, but well only execute on those transactions we believe to be accretive to the company on a long-term basis.
So to wrap it up, our plans for the future remain simple and unchanged. We are going to focus on operating our portfolio well and improving portfolio quality and concentrating capital in our target markets.
With that I will turn it over to Ernie. Ernie?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. On todays call I will cover the following subjects. First, our financial results for the quarter. Second, our balance sheet, and third, I will provide fourth quarter and updated full year 2010 guidance.As to financial results, third quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. On todays call I will cover the following subjects. First, our financial results for the quarter. Second, our balance sheet, and third, I will provide fourth quarter and updated full year 2010 guidance.
As to financial results, third quarter total portfolio NOI, total same-store NOI, and conventional same-store NOI were all positive, year-over-year. Year-to-date, total portfolio NOI also turned positive with an increase of 0.9% from 2009.
Third quarter pro forma FFO of $0.40 per share exceeded the high end of our guidance range by $0.04 and the midpoint of guidance by $0.06 per share. Our favorable results were achieved through property operating income $0.03 per share above expectations, including $0.02 from conventional same-store primarily due to higher occupancy at 96%, and property tax adjustments that were not contemplated in guidance and $0.01 through conventional redevelopments as occupancy exceeded our expectations. Property tax adjustments also benefited conventional redevelopment results.
Additionally, lower G&A costs positively impacted results by $0.02. Weve made much progress in lowering G&A costs over the last couple of years and today AIMCOs G&A as a percentage of property revenues is below the apartment REIT average.
Turning to our balance sheet, with our term debt fully repaid in July, our only recourse debt obligation is our revolving line of credit, which other than collateralized letters of credit, was undrawn at September 30.
In late September, we amended our revolving credit facility to increase capacity from $180 million to $300 million, and to extend the facility maturity date to May 2014 inclusive of a one year extension option. The amendment also provides for a decrease in the LIBOR floor on the facilitys floating interest rate, which at current LIBOR pricing effectively reduces the interest rate under the facility by 50 basis points.
This amendment provides AIMCO with added diversification of our line participants, lower interest costs, and an extended maturity. Our planned uses of the facility are unchanged, which are only to secure corporate letters of credit and to meet short-term working capital requirements.
We have no property debt maturities during the fourth quarter, and $3 million coming due in the first quarter of 2011. For all of 2011, we have $105 million of property debt maturity. Of this amount $79 million occurs in the second quarter. We have rate locked that loan, and well refinance it in the first quarter of 2011, when it is opened for prepayment, so our net exposure next year is only $26 million.
Were continuing to look for opportunities to extend 2012 through 2014 property debt maturities to reduce refunding risk and to take advantage of current interest rates. We remain on plan to reduce somewhat AIMCO financial leverage both by cyclical recovery of property income and by scheduled amortization of our property debt, which averages about $80 million per year over the next few years.
Finally, on the balance sheet, in September, we issued 4 million shares of our Series U preferred stock raising $96 million after transaction costs. Proceeds from the issuance were used to redeem our Series G preferred stock with a coupon of 9.375% in October. These transactions effectively reduced AIMCOs cost of leverage by seven basis points.
Turning to guidance, we are increasing projected full year 2010 pro forma FFO from a range of $1.37 to $1.45 per share to a range of $1.47 to $1.51 per share. At the midpoint guidance is increased by $0.08, which reflects our $0.06 outperformance in third quarter and an upward adjustment due to projected fourth quarter NOI from operations.
Our updated guidance includes the following, which is also provided in our earnings release. We project total portfolio NOI growth that is 1% to 1.5% above 2009. This is an upward revision from a range of 50 basis points below 2009 to 50 basis points above 2009, based on operating results to-date and a slightly improved outlook for the fourth quarter.
We are also increasing projected conventional same-store NOI growth to a range of 50 to 100 basis points below 2009. This compares to our previous expectations of a decline of 1% to 2%.
For conventional same-store revenue, we expect revenues to come in at the more favorable end of our previously provided range, which is a decline of 50 basis points.
Similarly, we expect conventional same-store expenses to come in at the more favorable end of our previously provided range, which is flat. For the full year, we anticipate net income from transactional activity to approximate 1% of FFO, consistent with the guidance provided last quarter.
For the fourth quarter, pro forma FFO is projected to be $0.34 to $0.38 per share. Conventional same-store NOI 50 to 100 basis points above fourth quarter 2009 NOI.
With that, we will now open up the call for questions. Please limit your questions to two per time in the queue. Andrea, I will turn it over to your for the first question.

componenttextpreview: Eric, this is Ernie. I can address that. Our biggest initiative in order to reduce G&A is work were doing on our technology platforms. This year we were successful in outsourcing many of our IT functions to a local group here. Over the next year and a
componenttext: Eric, this is Ernie. I can address that. Our biggest initiative in order to reduce G&A is work were doing on our technology platforms. This year we were successful in outsourcing many of our IT functions to a local group here. Over the next year and a half, were putting a lot of our platforms, specifically our property management platform, as well as our general ledger into newer systems. We expect to have earned in over that throughout 2011, but the biggest impacts will be in 2012. Its a little premature for me to give you specific numbers on what the savings will be. But what I can tell you is that we do expect G&A to continue to come down over the next 18 to 24 months.

componenttext: No, I think well continue the discipline of selling off the bottom. We have a clear focus on our target, which is wed like to see our capital allocated to the top 20 markets in United States. They are deep and liquid and have predictable demand. And wed like to have our price point be 100% to 115% of local market averages. And so we will just continue to sell off the bottom and upgrade the portfolio, and keep it in that strike zone.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning. I had a question about; you said that you are seeing the acquisition market has been pretty expensive. Just given the fact that all the other REITs and in general, the (inaudible) family transactions have picked up, almost doubled over t
componenttext: Hi, good morning. I had a question about; you said that you are seeing the acquisition market has been pretty expensive. Just given the fact that all the other REITs and in general, the (inaudible) family transactions have picked up, almost doubled over the last year, what do you see it a function of, are others underwriting very large revenue growth, or is it in particular the B, B+ category which you are looking at?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Terry. Im not really in a position to comment on how others underwrite that. I assume they know what they are doing. But as we look at acquisitions today, we look at of course the most critical variable being revenue growth, and we look at all
componenttext:
This is Terry. Im not really in a position to comment on how others underwrite that. I assume they know what they are doing. But as we look at acquisitions today, we look at of course the most critical variable being revenue growth, and we look at all the different forecasters and we tend to use an average of three of them. Those kind of nets out the noise and thats one essential element. If you look at those revenue growth rates, then the outcome for very low cap rate investing is not likely to be very high returns.
A second factor is that if you look at very low cap rates as being influenced or correlated with a very low treasury rate then valuations are very sensitive to changes in that low interest rate. And I think the third then is you might say, well, what about the possibilities for upsides beyond what are conventionally forecasted. If those upsides result that would be good news for us as well. But I look at real final sales, for example, as very low for this stage in the recovery, and the withdrawal of fiscal stimulus, the withdrawal of inventory gains or the playing out of that, and Im just cautious as I look forward into 2011.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question on just you mentioned about your target markets versus the other markets, and just looking at your conventional same-store results, the other markets are the ones which are actually sort of outperforming in terms of year-on-year revenue
componenttext: I have a question on just you mentioned about your target markets versus the other markets, and just looking at your conventional same-store results, the other markets are the ones which are actually sort of outperforming in terms of year-on-year revenue growth, whether its Austin, Baltimore, and others. I mean, is this make you pause a little bit about your target markets or are you looking at more on a two year or five year out basis?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we do look at our market selection on a long term basis, and we do note the anomaly that our non-target markets have sometimes outperformed our target markets. But I think two things. First of all, I think that over time there is a great principle o
componenttext: Well, we do look at our market selection on a long term basis, and we do note the anomaly that our non-target markets have sometimes outperformed our target markets. But I think two things. First of all, I think that over time there is a great principle of convergence across all these markets and that market differences are easy to exaggerate provided you are not in an area of decline. Secondly, in our target markets, we think that the growth is both more predictable and the investments are more liquid, so those are other attributes we consider.

componenttext: Hi, I was wondering if you could comment on, it looks like your renewal rates are doing well. In the third quarter, I believe, it was up 1.5%. In the second quarter, it was up 1.9%. I was just wondering if you can comment on the slight drop in the growth rate.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michelle, Tim Beaudin. I think that Tony and his team, we continue to build on occupancy. I mean, I think that difference in the rates is there, but its not one were overly concerned with. As we pointed out, weve had a better month in October tha
componenttext:
Michelle, Tim Beaudin. I think that Tony and his team, we continue to build on occupancy. I mean, I think that difference in the rates is there, but its not one were overly concerned with. As we pointed out, weve had a better month in October than we had in September, so we like the trend were on. We like our occupancy. We tend to focus on total revenue. Rate is part of that equation and the other part is occupancy. And like everybody, were utilizing revenue management to manage that process. So I think we continue to be very focused on keeping our people in place. Again when we focus, and I know theres been a lot of discussion on rate, so Ill just address it right now.
The measuring stick has to be decided over what metric youre utilizing. What weve identified in our information here is lease to lease. So were talking very specific about lease A expires and what we got for lease A, and we do it every quarter, it didnt matter whether its a renewal or a new lease situation. I think there has been some confusion in the market. It appears to me when other people report and Im not here to talk about how theyre reporting, but just commenting on it that if I want to talk about similar leases, a similar lease from the beginning of the year to where a similar lease is today, and Ill use for example on our new lease rate, while we were kind of down 10%, 11%; now were only down 1% on similar leases.
Weve seen an improvement of 10%, but I like to comment specifically on lease to lease because its factually correct. So occupancy, we continue to be very focused on that. We feel like we have good traction come out of the busy season now to get some increase as we go into the year, but as Terry has mentioned, were going to continue to be cautious about that as we move forward.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010

componenttext: Yes, weve done some work around that. I think that and Tony can address it more in detail. I mean, some of them are nearing or at the same time point, but for the most part we still have not gotten back to peak. I dont know Tony, if you have.

componenttext: This is Tony. And then portfolio wide, wed be positive in the fourth quarter we expect.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Its actually a little bit of both. Its a good question. In the third quarter, we booked a little over $2.5 million that represented basically lowering accruals. To your point, with real estate taxes our policy is to accrue based on real estate
componenttext:
Sure. Its actually a little bit of both. Its a good question. In the third quarter, we booked a little over $2.5 million that represented basically lowering accruals. To your point, with real estate taxes our policy is to accrue based on real estate tax goals. So we got far enough along in the process and had a settlement in hand, where we had to adjust for 2010 activity. So that $2.5 million was really an adjustment of accruals from the first and second quarter, but it did bring our third quarter run rate down slightly.
So going forward, you shouldnt model another $2 million decrease. We are hopeful to have some more good guides in real estate taxes in the fourth quarter, but its a little bit too soon for me to put those in the guidance. We are very active on that, but it was pretty much a one-time event to catch up from earlier approvals during 2010.

componenttext: Bill, this is Terry and then maybe Ill ask John Bezzant who runs that transaction towards that color. I think that cap rates are very property specific. I think that the acquisition activity which we began quite focused on very prime 8 properties in the select few markets is spread as people look for yield. Yes, I think the cap rates are coming down both geographically and across the quality spectrum. John, do you want to add to that?

componenttext: These are similar to transactions weve done in the past and transaction that we believe to be mutually beneficial to AIMCO and to our LPs, they are really in the bane of simplifying AIMCO structure by increasing our ownership to a 100% in assets that are in our target markets. componenttext: Good afternoon, guys. Terry, given the sort of comments that youve been making on the call about dispositions in terms of some of your 40 assets in the non-core markets are doing well operationally and but theyre not longer term owner assets, is there a chance here that you guys are going to materially increase the pace of dispositions over the next couple of quarters, given how low the 10-year warrants are being to take advantage of that?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rob, I dont think so. I think were going to try to be steady if she goes, that we will have expectation in most years of disposing of 5% to 10% of our portfolio, which would connect with the 10 to 20 year holding period, so I dont think thats
componenttext: Rob, I dont think so. I think were going to try to be steady if she goes, that we will have expectation in most years of disposing of 5% to 10% of our portfolio, which would connect with the 10 to 20 year holding period, so I dont think thats unduly rapid pace, and we will look at the reinvestment of those proceeds. So, its partly a question of selling on an opportunistic basis, but its also a question of reinvestment, matching up those two.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Good morning, everybody out there. Terry, regarding your early comments about the economy being cautious for 2011, can you identify some specifics multifamily fundamental parameters that are kind of behind that conservative tone beyond just a gene
componenttext: Thanks. Good morning, everybody out there. Terry, regarding your early comments about the economy being cautious for 2011, can you identify some specifics multifamily fundamental parameters that are kind of behind that conservative tone beyond just a general view of where the economy is going? In other words, maybe rent to income ratios, or anything like that that is kind of spooking you, to use a word during Halloween?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, when you call I know its a trick or treat, and Ill regard it as a treat today. Its good to hear your voice. I think that there are a lot of positive things that we know about the apartment business. The demographics are terrific. The supply
componenttext:
Rich, when you call I know its a trick or treat, and Ill regard it as a treat today. Its good to hear your voice. I think that there are a lot of positive things that we know about the apartment business. The demographics are terrific. The supply growth has been constrained, and I think that inside the unemployment numbers, you have the interesting phenomenon that young people are gaining jobs faster, while older people are losing jobs, so those are all positive.
I think the two elements of caution that I would point to is that were at a time of enthusiasm, when starts are likely to accelerate. Ive just talked to a number of people in the business and outside the public arena, and theres a recurring refrain that there arent going to be any starts, so Im doubling my own activity. I think well be impressed on the upside at the number of new starts. So particularly its the high end that makes me a little cautious.
Secondly, in terms of rents generally if we have a continuing high rate of unemployment, which I think we will have already as opposed to forecasters foresee, I think its going to be difficult to have wage growth, and so people as they get jobs, so as young people get jobs, will rent an apartment, but theyre going to remain price sensitive, I think.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the second question is another comment you made at the start was nothing really new here, but selling non-core businesses, but is there any kind of renewed energy to sell non-core businesses maybe the tax credit business, or whatever I mean is th
componenttext: And then the second question is another comment you made at the start was nothing really new here, but selling non-core businesses, but is there any kind of renewed energy to sell non-core businesses maybe the tax credit business, or whatever I mean is there a new motivation to get something done sooner rather than later?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, again what I think will drive our planning is steady as she goes, so weve been on a multi-year course to reduce the number of our activities and to simplify our portfolio and to lower our offsite cost including G&A, and I expect we will continue.
componenttext:
Rich, again what I think will drive our planning is steady as she goes, so weve been on a multi-year course to reduce the number of our activities and to simplify our portfolio and to lower our offsite cost including G&A, and I expect we will continue. It plays off across a number of activities, including affordable assets in which we have a very low percentage of ownership, so for example you heard John talked about earlier today that sale of the clunkers, but they were clunkers in which we had a 4% ownership stake.
You can talk about the reduction of our (inaudible) business or our SPI businesses, which were legacy businesses from the Insignia and Casden acquisitions, which are not very important to us in terms of contribution today, but take a certain amount of cost and management time. We dont think of ourselves today as being in the tax credit business. We think of tax credit as a financing tool in support of our primary business which is 90% conventional, 10% affordable and just another financing tool that is helpful in lowering our cost of capital.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So just to follow on that question. Do you sense that there is some interest in some of these sort of non-core businesses out there these days?
componenttext: So just to follow on that question. Do you sense that there is some interest in some of these sort of non-core businesses out there these days?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010

componenttext: Sure. I think theyre all profitable activities, and theyre ones that may be more suited to other peoples business plans, and there is interest in them.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, guys. Terry, Id like to go back to an earlier question for a sec. Can you talk more specifically about the size of the opportunity for buying in some of these partnership interests? I guess, Id like to better understand how large the opportunit
componenttext: Hey, guys. Terry, Id like to go back to an earlier question for a sec. Can you talk more specifically about the size of the opportunity for buying in some of these partnership interests? I guess, Id like to better understand how large the opportunity set is, what the range of returns we should expect, and how those returns stack up versus your other investment alternative in your cost of capital?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Haendel, those are good questions, and Im not sure Im going to give you an answer that youll be able to model, but I can give you an answer thatll tell you how we think about it. Today, limited partnership interest in our conventional assets a
componenttext:
Haendel, those are good questions, and Im not sure Im going to give you an answer that youll be able to model, but I can give you an answer thatll tell you how we think about it. Today, limited partnership interest in our conventional assets are only about 8% of the total value, so the opportunity is much more constrained than it was say 10 years ago.
And inside that opportunity, its subject to pricing and alternatives. If we look at particular property and we think that were more optimistic than the third-party experts than wed be inclined to acquire there. That wont be through across the entire universe of that portfolio. There is some room there and what activities we take there will be ones that are accretive.
When we look at accretive we look at that first on any rebases if where we look at free cash flow and expected growth after capital replacement spending, and then we look at our cost of capital being primarily in the case of property debt or in the value of our equity as expressed in our view of its net asset value.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ernie, I guess one for you, with interest rates being so low, can you talk more about the opportunity for addressing some of the property that matures particularly the once beyond 2011?
componenttext: Ernie, I guess one for you, with interest rates being so low, can you talk more about the opportunity for addressing some of the property that matures particularly the once beyond 2011?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely Haendel, its been first and foremost in our mind really for the last two and a half to three months, working with Patti Fielding. Shes been very focused and really going down in list of our lenders and starting with our largest lenders th
componenttext:
Absolutely Haendel, its been first and foremost in our mind really for the last two and a half to three months, working with Patti Fielding. Shes been very focused and really going down in list of our lenders and starting with our largest lenders that we currently had and really see if there is a negotiation and there is a deal to be made that benefits them, maybe helped them, the balance of your portfolio, as well as it benefited us.
So, were very active in looking for opportunities to go ahead and take care of 2012 to 2014 maturities, see if we can negotiate something from an economic standpoint to make sense for both parties. Well keep working out hard for the fourth quarter here and into the early part of next year, while we are in such a favorable environment with regards to interest rates.
